I know you are not too worked up about that particular point, but I just want to say that we have followed a precedent—and I acknowledge the honourable member's thanks.

The member for Kingston asked why expatriates are not being dealt with in the review of the international tax arrangements. The expatriates measure was a Ralph Review of Business Taxation recommendation. Ralph did not look at international tax issues in a comprehensive way; instead, Ralph identified the most pressing areas for reform. Expatriates were identified as being so important. It was seen to be a real barrier to the flow of skilled workers into Australia, and this impediment was recognised as affecting Australia's international competitiveness. So the expatriates measure is a stand-alone measure. There is nothing in the review that would change or affect the expatriates measure. On the contrary, the review is based on the enactment of the measure. The measure has already been subject to extensive consultation, both during and after Ralph, and there is considerable support from a wide range of groups.

The member for Mitchell spoke on this bill, as he does on many of the bills involving taxation, and made the point that this bill complements the government's earlier measure to allow temporary residents to access their superannuation upon permanently leaving Australia. I want to thank the member for Mitchell for his contribution and also for his assistance to the processes of the House, for which the member for Perth also gave him credit. The government is committed to sensible changes to ease the disincentives faced by those who contribute skills to the Australian labour market. The member for Mitchell also asked the question: would the provisions affect entertainers and will earnings be tax free? Entertainers would be subject to tax on Australian income; there is no exemption from tax on Australian income. The measures are directed at expatriates who would be taxed as a resident on their worldwide income—that is, overseas income.

In this bill the government continues to deliver on its promise of tax reform. I have noted that there is some concern with regard to the measures to give foreign income tax exemptions to temporary residents, but I am not at all convinced that it is justified. As has been done before, the opposition has attacked the measure as a special concession for rich foreign executives. This kind of criticism in the circumstances is unwarranted, particularly given my response to the point made by the member for Kingston just a moment ago. The measure will apply to people who would have been Australian residents for tax purposes but are only here on temporary entry visas.

Labour market intelligence undertaken by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations in the latter half of 2001 identified that there was a national shortage of accountants, registered nurses, pharmacists, occupational therapists, radiation therapists and information and communication technology professionals. These workers are hardly rich foreign executives. People granted a temporary resident visa to come to Australia to alleviate the above skill shortages will benefit from the temporary resident tax exemption. In 2000-01, the top five occupations sponsored by employers under business long stay visas were computing professionals, applications and analyst programmers, general managers, registered nurses and accountants. These are the people who benefit most from this measure and not, as I repeat, the rich foreign executives that Labor talked about.

I think the next question is: why should an Australian accountant, for instance, be taxed differently from his or her colleague who does the same work but is here on a temporary visa? In effect, they will not be taxed so differently. Because both the Australian accountant and the temporary resident are taxed in Australia on their salary and wage income, they would pay the same tax on the same income. The difference is in relation to offshore assets. As an Australian resident, the Australian accountant pays tax to the Commonwealth on his worldwide income, including income generated by assets overseas. The temporary resident, however, will now have a period of four years during which he or she will be exempt from Australian income and capital gains tax in relation to foreign assets. Instead, subject to any treaty obligations, he or she will be likely to pay tax on income from that asset overseas. It is not as though the income escapes tax altogether.

In relation to the exemption from withholding tax liabilities for a period of four years, this will mean that temporary residents will not incur additional expenditure in borrowing money. An Australian resident does not have to pay interest withholding tax on his or her mortgage payments. Now a temporary resident can also pay a mortgage without any withholding tax issues. The exemption from the foreign investment fund lasts for as long as the temporary resident holds a temporary visa. These rules are largely intended to address anomalies which arise because otherwise the temporary resident is taxed in Australia every year on the increase in value of a non-employer sponsored superannuation fund. This can be particularly unfair if a credit is not given in the home jurisdiction because the fund is not taxed until realisation.

Convincing representations were made to the Ralph review and the government about the impact of tax considerations on the willingness of firms to bring temporary employees to Australia from overseas. Costs relating to temporary resident employees are an important consideration in the establishment of regional offices and headquarters, and in making Australia a financial centre. Other countries in the region that compete for this kind of investment also have special arrangements for temporary employees. The New Zealand government has indicated that it will be considering a similar measure. Singapore is extending its already concessional tax treatment and China is emerging as a further competitor in the international skilled labour market. Under the proposal of the government, Australia will benefit from the dynamic effects of having more and better businesses located here as well as from the expenditure and local employment that they will generate. Australia also benefits through the transfer of new management and other skills that key personnel can bring to Australian business.

The bill contains a number of other important changes to the tax law. The bill exempts from income tax compensation payments for the loss of defence remuneration where the remuneration itself would have been exempt from income tax. This ensures that where the ADF member returns to Australia because of an injury sustained in service, the lump sum compensation payment received for the loss of the deployment allowance is exempt from tax. The government has undertaken this measure as part of its commitment to the military effort and in support of the ADF personnel engaged in the Iraq campaign and their families. The personnel serving their nation in the Middle East can be assured of the full support of the government for them and for their loved ones.

The bill also amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to treat previously assessable income as not assessable where it must be repaid and that repayment occurs in a later year of income. It also amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to permit amendments of income tax assessments for the year in which the amount was originally treated as assessable income, despite the time limit for amendments to assessments being exceeded. The bill will also increase the level of expenses above which the medical expenses tax offset applies from $1,250 to $1,500 per annum. For the 2002-03 and later income years, the medical expenses tax offset will be available at a rate of 20 per cent of any net medical expenses above $1,500 in an income year. This measure was announced in the 2002-03 budget.

Finally, an income tax exemption is, as I have mentioned before, granted to the Commonwealth Games Federation. The exemption will apply to income received by the federation in the course of staging the Melbourne Commonwealth Games in 2006 and applies to income derived by the federation on or after 1 January 2000 and before 1 July 2007. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 2002 is a very important initiative of the government. I commend the bill to the chamber and I urge the chamber to reject the second reading amendment moved by the honourable member for Kingston.

talk.start.para: (Hon. B.C. Scott)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Kingston has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

interjection.para: Question agreed to.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —I move opposition amendment (1):

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, page 4 (line 1) to page 9 (line 31), omit the Schedule.

This amendment would delete schedule 1, which provides foreign expatriates with a series of tax concessions. I listened very carefully to the parliamentary secretary's defence of that measure. I point out that, while it was recommended by the Ralph Review of Business Taxation, the Ralph review was undertaken on the basis that the reforms it contained would be revenue neutral. The government made certain commitments to the opposition to secure passage of many of the reforms. These involved the government enacting certain legislation to deal with the tax treatment of trusts and to remove abuses of trusts for the purposes of tax avoidance and evasion. The government subsequently reneged on that agreement and, as a result, the Ralph Review of Business Taxation reforms were very far from being revenue neutral.

The measures before us that are now contained in the review of international tax arrangements—and they are in the discussion paper that has been circulated by Treasury to assist the Board of Taxation in its consultations—have been considered by the professional tax community in the context of that review. This is despite the minister's denials, the parliamentary secretary's denials and the minister's suggestions that the review assumes that they would be passed. The government may have assumed that they would be passed, but the opposition does not assume that they would be passed.

The review of international tax arrangements does not come with any caveat that the reforms will be revenue neutral. In fact, most of the substantial reforms in the review would have a significant negative effect on the budget bottom line. It is for that reason that the opposition believes that all of the measures, including the tax treatment of foreign expatriates, should be considered as a part of a package so that the parliament considers the costs and the benefits of all those measures together.

At the moment the government is proposing to cherry-pick foreign expatriates at a cost of about $40 million or $50 million per year. If the government were really serious about international tax reform, it would be a lot tighter with the rest of its budget and it would have much more fiscal capacity to provide reforms which would increase Australia's international tax competitiveness, and it would also have the fiscal flexibility to provide meaningful tax relief to Australian taxpayers.

At the moment, because of the government's profligacy and lack of fiscal discipline, it has dissipated its fiscal flexibility. It is my very great fear that it will be able to provide neither significant reforms to Australia's international tax regime nor tax relief for ordinary Australians to compensate them for the large amount of additional revenue it is collecting as a result of bracket creep. According to Access Economics, this additional revenue will amount to an extra $6.2 billion a year in 2005-06. I commend the amendment to the House. I do not anticipate that the amendment will succeed here but I am optimistic that the amendment will succeed in the Senate.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —Whenever I speak opposite the member for Kingston, I seem to disappoint him insofar as I am not very often—or, perhaps, even ever—prepared to accept the amendments he moves. Again, the government cannot accept the amendment moved by the member for Kingston. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 2002 demonstrates the government's commitment to address barriers to international competitiveness in the tax system. This proposal will create employment and investment in Australia by removing competitive disadvantages to the development of Australia as a strong financial centre. This objective has been supported by successive federal governments, state governments and a wide range of industry groups.

speech.para: The changes will remove counterproductive taxes imposed on foreigners posted to Australia, including taxing them for deemed capital gains on assets held offshore during their stay in Australia. It is disappointing that the opposition appears not to see that these unfair taxes apply to the many middle-ranking management and specialist staff who come to Australia to grow business, provide better products and enrich financial sector skills in this country. It is also disappointing that the Labor Party appears not to recognise that this measure will help to meet identified shortages of registered nurses, pharmacists, occupational therapists, radiation therapists and other professionals. Shortages of this kind are often temporary, and the short-term contribution of foreign workers assists the Australian community greatly during these periods. It is unfortunate that the opposition cannot support a sensible policy change to make Australia more attractive to these foreign workers. I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Question negatived.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments (1) to (3):

quote.para: (1) Schedule 3, item 1, page 12 (line 8), omit “(apart from subsection (3))”.
(2) Schedule 3, item 1, page 12 (line 9), after “amendment”, insert “, at any time,”.
(3) Schedule 3, item 4, page 13 (lines 22 to 27), omit subsection (3), substitute:
(3) This section does not apply to an amount you must repay because you received a lump sum as compensation or damages for a wrong or injury you suffered in your occupation.

speech.para: Amendments (1) and (2) allow taxpayers to request an adjustment of their previous tax assessments at any time to exclude previously assessable income that has been repaid. The amendments are necessary as some taxpayers may not be required to repay amounts until after the expiry of the usual time limits for adjustment. Without the amendments, those taxpayers will be disadvantaged by the requirement to request an adjustment within those time limits. Amendment (3) clarifies that repaid amounts cannot be excluded from a taxpayer's assessable income where a lump sum workers compensation payment has been received.

The bill, as it currently stands, suggests that this only applies where the lump sum workers compensation payments include an amount equal to and on account of the income tax payable on the repaid amount. That is not intended. This amendment will make it clear that, regardless of the composition of the lump sum workers compensation payment, no repaid amount can be excluded from a taxpayer's assessable income where such a payment has been received. I commend these amendments to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Mr SLIPPER (Fisher—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (12.48 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 12 December 2002, on motion by Mr Truss:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —We have before us the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002. This is not the simple bill the minister would have us believe it is. It requires careful consideration. On behalf of Australian grain growers, we on this side of the chamber will ensure that that occurs. The bill amends the Wheat Marketing Act 1989. It provides for the imposition of a levy on the grains industry to fund the Wheat Export Authority. The authority was set up in July 1999, as part of the restructure of the former Australian Wheat Board, to independently monitor the management of single desk export power by the new privatised entity AWB International. The bill also changes the objects of the act to require the Wheat Export Authority, in performing its export control functions, to complement any objective of AWB International.

speech.para: Under item 1, the explanatory memorandum refers to the making of regulations under the Primary Industries (Customs) Charges Act 1999 to impose a wheat export charge. The opposition believe that proper consideration of this legislation is not possible without consideration of access to regulations. Without these regulations we have no way of understanding how the levy will actually work. The explanatory memorandum only endorses a recommended option, but even that contains scant detail. We now know, following advice from the department, that there will in fact be three sets of regulations required for parliamentary and accounting requirements. There will be regulations under the Primary Industries (Customs) Charges Act to set the levy. There will be a regulation under the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act to collect the levy. There will also be a regulation, under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989, which directs the levy to the purposes set out in the legislation.

Members will be surprised to hear that, despite the urgency adopted by the minister in relation to this matter, these regulations have not even been drafted. So the minister is asking the parliament to pass this bill before the precise form of a levy to be imposed on growers and the manner in which it will be imposed has been determined. I would ask the minister to have these regulations drafted and provided to the opposition as soon as possible so that we can see, and indeed the industry can see, how the levy is proposed to work in practice.

Item 2 of the bill varies the functions and powers of the Wheat Export Authority by inserting into the act proposed sections 5A and 5B. If this amendment is accepted, the authority will be required to seek to complement any objective of company B to maximise net returns for pools operated by that company, the company being AWBI. The minister presents this amendment as being simple housekeeping. We on this side do not consider that to be so. Changing the objects of an act is just that. The inclusion of these clauses makes the purpose of the bill not simply about the imposition of a new levy on grain growers; it formally changes the relationship between the WEA and the holder of the single desk monopoly power, AWBI. I note evidence to the Senate inquiry into this bill by the CEO of AWB Ltd, Mr Andrew Lindberg. Senator O'Brien put to him that this amendment was not a simple clarification but imposed a special and clear obligation on the authority. Mr Lindberg said, `Yes. We would agree.'

Item 3 provides in part for the Commonwealth to recover costs associated with the collection of the levy from growers. As I understand the proposal, levy funds will flow to consolidated revenue and will then be provided to the authority less any costs associated with collection and management. The department has advised us that the cost of setting up this new levy will be in the order of $20,000. There will also be some ongoing collection and management costs. Item 4 simply corrects a drafting error in the act. Item 5 provides for new clauses 58 and 59, which propose new arrangements for dealing with minor variations to export consents by the authority. According to the explanatory memorandum, a minor variation is defined as being less than 500 tonnes. The explanatory memorandum states that other matters, such as the grade of wheat, may be considered minor but the authority must consult AWB International.

Under the subheading `Consultation', the regulation impact statement for this bill advises that consultation on a broad range of funding options was undertaken with the main stakeholders. The stakeholders were identified as being the WEA, the Grains Council and AWB International. Evidence to the Senate committee inquiring into this bill confirms that the government did not consult any other stakeholders. For the record, it is useful to look at the Hansard of the inquiry of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee into the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002. I refer to page 7 of the 6 March transcript and an exchange between Mr David Mortimer, the Executive Manager of Food and Agriculture in the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, and Senator O'Brien, who is the shadow minister for primary industries and has major carriage of this area. This exchange is significant because the issue of consultation, not just on this issue but on many more that this minister has been involved in, is very important. The exchange is as follows:

quote.para: Senator O'BRIEN—In the regulation impact statement under the subheading `consultation' we are advised that consultation on a broad range of funding options was undertaken with the main stakeholders. The stakeholders were identified as the Wheat Export Authority, the Grains Council and AWB International. Was there consultation with any other stakeholders?

Mr Mortimer—That statement specifies the fact that the minister wrote formally to those organisations, because of their roles, seeking their views. The minister also put this issue on the table in a public speech to Grains Week last week ...

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: Senator O'BRIEN—So the extent of the consultation was a speech at Grains Week and the letters to those three bodies?
Mr Mortimer—That is the extent of the formal consultation.

speech.para: Further on, the exchange continues:

quote.para: Senator O'BRIEN—So the only formal process was the one you described—a speech to Grains Week and three letters?
Mr Mortimer—That is right.

speech.para: Senator O'Brien has asked for advice on other consultations undertaken, and the opposition looks forward to seeing those details. Even without that advice, it is clear that, while the government has consulted with a small number of peak organisations, it has all but ignored wider industry interest in this matter.

The referral of this bill to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee highlights the wide interest in the provisions of this bill. The committee has received 37 written submissions. It took evidence from nine organisations and two individuals in Canberra. In Perth the committee took evidence from seven organisations and three individuals, and I am aware of requests for further hearings since those hearings.

The minister has argued that this legislation is urgent. He has argued that, if it is not passed in a speedy fashion, the authority will run out of money. His office has argued that the bill must be through the parliament by 27 March to prevent this occurring. In contrast, the department has advised the Senate that the government's timetable is based on the legislation being finalised by the parliament in May. Perhaps I should quote evidence from Mr Mortimer to the same Senate inquiry I referred to earlier; in particular, pages 12 to 13 of the Hansard make interesting reading. Mr Mortimer said:

quote.para: ... there are a number of weeks of parliamentary sittings in May during which the parliament can finalise its position on this.

speech.para: There are other options available to the minister to meet the authority's funding needs in the short term. Mr Mortimer confirmed that it would be possible to provide funding by way of a loan from consolidated revenue, to be serviced from future levy income. Mr Mortimer further said that the mechanics of such an arrangement could be the provision of funding, as a new policy proposal, through Appropriation Bill (No.2). The Wheat Export Authority could also borrow funding if it had ministerial approval to do so. The loan could then be serviced from future income through the levy, as has occurred with funding for waterfront redundancies, for example. Mr Mortimer also confirmed in the same exchange that, given the limited time available for the consideration of legislation by this place, the bills presented by the government reflect its priorities. He was stating the obvious. So one can only conclude that this matter has not been given priority in the past.

Now we have the minister pressuring this place to give the bill priority to the point of compromising our proper assessment of what its implications might be for grain growers. It appears that the minister's desire for the parliament to give this legislation a speedy passage is all about avoiding proper scrutiny and has little to do with the timing of an income stream to fund the authority. In fact, the minister has been considering this matter for some time. Despite the limited consultative process with people who will have to pay this levy, both the minister and his staff have been discussing this matter over a long period of time, but with a select few.

Mr Jock Kreitals from the Grains Council of Australia told the Senate inquiry that the council had had discussions with both the department and the minister's office as far back as 2001. He said that there had been a number of discussions within the council executive about the levy prior to the minister's speech to Grains Week last year. He said that there had also been correspondence with the minister's office on the issue of the levy following the Grains Week speech. So this matter has been on the minister's desk since some time late in 2001.

Despite the passage of 18 months, we still have no detail about the levy: what it looks like, how much it will be and how it will be collected. Yet here we are having this bill pushed through the parliament. If the minister is not prepared to do his job properly, to consult widely and to fully inform the parliament by providing not only the bill but also the associated regulations, he should not expect Labor's support. And it is very much a matter for the minister. Let me again quote his department's evidence to the Senate inquiry. Mr David Mortimer said:

quote.para: Essentially, the minister has to make the decision on behalf of government as to the best way to do this ...

speech.para: There is no doubt where the buck stops.

I suspect that the current minister is being distracted by other things. In particular, I read with great interest an article in the Australian Financial Review today, headed `Nationals' leadership doubts'. I suspect that the member for Wide Bay has been distracted by these events. It is very interesting, and I wish to share this with my colleague at the table, the member for Werriwa. The article says:

quote.para: Doubts have emerged about whether Deputy Prime Minister John Anderson will lead the National Party to the next election after he was unable to give a clear answer on his intentions when asked by several senior MPs ...

speech.para: It goes further:

quote.para: Another federal National Party MP said there was concern at the state branch level that Mr Anderson lacked the discipline to fight another election as leader.

speech.para: I will read the words of one of the senior federal MPs of his party—and I notice we have one of those members in the House today:

quote.para: I've heard that people at the state level are concerned John lacks the fire in his belly to take us to the next election, certainly compared to some others waiting in the wings.

speech.para: I believe a spokesman for Minister Anderson said:

quote.para: John has always said that provided he has the support of the party and important issues to address, he will remain as leader.

speech.para: So there is no doubt there is a distraction going on in the National Party.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I remind the opposition member that this has nothing to do with the bill before the House. I ask you to bring him back to the bill before the House.
(Ms Corcoran)—The member for Braddon will get back to the topic.

—I was not going to reflect on the member for Maranoa in this; I was not suggesting that it was him, but he may have outed himself by that comment. Anyway, I will move on. I was just trying to account for the primary industry minister's distraction at the moment.
—The member for Braddon will refer to the bill.

—The current structure of the Australian wheat industry is under pressure from without and within. The United States has clearly set its sights on ending single desk marketing arrangements around the world. The US is currently challenging the export monopoly held by the Canadian Wheat Board through the dispute mechanism under the World Trade Organisation. Let me quote from a statement from the Office of the United States Trade Representative, dated 6 March this year. The statement is entitled `United States Requests WTO Panel in Dispute on Canadian Wheat Board'. It says in part:

quote.para: ... the United States has proposed eliminating export monopolies so that any producer, distributor, or processor can export agriculture products.

speech.para: That view is consistent with the placement of the single desk for wheat which was on the table during the current free trade agreement negotiations with the United States. I note that the United States also has our quarantine system firmly in its sights as part of these trade talks.

Australian grain growers are currently caught up in the conflict in the Middle East. Members will be aware that Iraq has been a key market for Australian wheat for many years. As a result of the actions of the United States, and Australia for that matter, the United Nations has announced the suspension of the oil for food program. That has brought a halt to our wheat exports to Iraq. AWB Ltd now have two shiploads of wheat stranded in the Persian Gulf. The AWB Ltd chief executive, Mr Lindberg, recently expressed concern that, in a postwar Iraq, our share of grain exports will be further cut because of US led aid programs. If that happens, it will be a further and significant blow to growers.

In this context, comments from the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources on the Sunday program last weekend are alarming. The minister, a former president of the Grains Council of Australia, said:

quote.para: When we went with the Americans into Vietnam, while they stole our wheat markets in different parts of the world; they did exactly the same thing in the Middle East when we went into conflicts with them there.

speech.para: We on this side of the chamber are concerned that history will repeat itself when it comes to postwar Iraq.

While there is little wheat grown in my state of Tasmania—though the area under cultivation is indeed increasing; and let me tell you it is quality—it is still an important grain. It is important as feed for the chicken, pork, feedlot and dairy industries. And it is important as an import for the milling and baking industries.

talk.start.para: —Great bread.

—Indeed, great bread. The Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme underpins these industries by removing the freight cost disadvantage that would otherwise be imposed on them and, in so doing, supports up to 1,600 direct and indirect jobs. This scheme is constantly under threat from the Treasurer, Mr Costello. Only recently, the Howard government was forced by political pressure from this side of the parliament to commit the funds to the program for the next financial year, for bitter experience has shown that funding in the out years for any program has never been a guarantee of future funds. This is especially the case at times of conflict and war. The bill is now getting the scrutiny it deserves through the Senate, so the opposition will not oppose the bill in this place.
—Hear, hear!
—But, my good friend the member for Kalgoorlie, until the Senate has completed its inquiry, properly considered the evidence and reported, the minister will not get his new levy.

—I rise today to address the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002. I have some disappointments, I confess, with the bill because in my opinion it raises many more questions than are, at this stage, satisfactorily answered. The bill's main purpose is to provide funding to meet the operational costs of the Wheat Export Authority by the wheat industry. The authority was designed to regulate and monitor the activities of AWB International Ltd, the wholly owned subsidiary of the AWB Ltd that was granted the single desk for export wheat. AWB International Ltd operates under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 and is responsible for maximising net returns to growers through export sales and pooling. The Wheat Export Authority was established in July 1999 after the transfer of the government's wheat marketing and selling role to the grower owned company, the Australian Wheat Board Ltd.

speech.para: One of the key issues of concern for the Australian wheat industry is the independence of the Wheat Export Authority. There is a general feeling that, in its current state, the Wheat Export Authority is not doing its job. The Wheat Export Authority is expected to carry out two functions: firstly, to control the export of wheat from Australia; and, secondly, to monitor the performance of AWB International Ltd in relation to the export of wheat and to examine and report on the benefits to growers resulting from that performance. In performing its functions, the Wheat Export Authority is required to work closely with AWB International Ltd. At issue is the perception of insufficient autonomy in the relationship between the parties, resulting in problems with transparency and accountability. At this juncture, I would point out the fact that the general consensus across my very extensive wheat producing area is that the Wheat Export Authority, at this stage, is not performing satisfactorily and, therefore, the question of how it ought to be funded is perhaps secondary to whether it should be funded or not. That is an alarming consideration, given that we are moving for the passage of this bill. At issue, as I said, is the perception of insufficient autonomy.

Subsection 57(1) of the act provides that a person shall be prohibited to export wheat unless the Wheat Export Authority has given its written consent. But, under subsection 57(1)(a) of the act, this does not apply to the AWB International Ltd. Subsection 57(3)(a) requires that the Wheat Export Authority consult with AWB International Ltd before issuing consent for bagged and container wheat exports, and must obtain approval from AWB International Ltd before issuing approvals for bulk wheat exports. This places significant limitations on the Wheat Export Authority's power to execute its responsibilities. The power of veto that AWB International Ltd has over the export of any of wheat outside its own export pools may potentially influence the Wheat Export Authority and its decision to issue consent.

It is also impossible for the Wheat Export Authority to monitor AWB International Ltd's performance, when it relies on AWB International Ltd to provide the data required. The system of the Wheat Export Authority granting export consents, case-by-case, can bring delays and, as such, impede the development of small markets of wheat outside the bulk market maintained by AWB International Ltd. As these exports are usually niche markets developed mostly by grower-owned and operated business, there is the potential for the loss of business and resultant export income for these companies. The government has continued in its support of a wheat single desk and will maintain this backing whilst there is a benefit to the Australian wheat growers and the nation's export performance.

There must also be some form of flexibility in the consent system for the export of wheat in containers and bags so that the small exporter can capture the niche markets. The Wheat Export Authority must broaden its monitoring and reporting performance of AWB International Ltd. They must broaden their reporting because it is imperative that in 2004 the WEA hand down a report on the single desk and its operation and efficiency, and on its benefits to growers. Therefore, we have this conundrum: we have to fund the Wheat Export Authority to do the job and hand down a vital report in 2004; and we have this niggling concern that they are not doing their job satisfactorily. We also have this urgent consideration as to how to fund them. As I have already said, we want to have a situation that is both transparent and above board.

This amendment bill is to provide for alternative funding of the Wheat Export Authority. I consider it is appropriate that the wheat industry should fund the regulatory body as the wheat growers are the main beneficiaries of the Wheat Export Authority and the single desk. I do not agree that taxpayers meet some of the authority's costs. I do agree that we ought to be charging for export licence applications. The argument that the government should contribute to the funding of the service, as a key role of the Wheat Export Authority is to inform the minister in detailed quarterly reports about the performance of AWB International Ltd, does not constitute the Commonwealth as being a user.

The former Australian Wheat Board directly controlled the single desk, and growers paid for the regulatory aspects out of pool administration costs. The Wheat Export Authority has been funded by a $6 million grant that essentially came from grower money held in reserves from the former Australian Wheat Board. If the former Australian Wheat Board could be self-funded, there is no reason why the Wheat Export Authority cannot be self-funded by the growers. The proposition that only exporters should fund the Wheat Export Authority should be dismissed. All wheat producers should fund the Wheat Export Authority, not only the exporters.

The reason I make much of that statement is that in my state of Western Australia 95 per cent of the wheat grown is exported. It is also the case that in South Australia a very high proportion of the wheat grown is exported. In fact, it is fair to say that South Australia and Western Australia collectively produce the wheat exported from Australia. It is not the case generally that wheat produced on the eastern seaboard is for the export market. It would be unfair, however, to simply say that the exporters of wheat should fund the Wheat Export Authority, because there is a direct nexus between the overseas price for exported wheat and the domestic market price for wheat. There is that direct nexus, and I do not believe anyone would argue that point.

It therefore seems absolutely logical that all producers ought to carry some responsibility for the cost of supporting the Wheat Export Authority, given that part of the authority's role is to maximise returns to growers. If they are doing their job and maximising the overseas price for Australian wheat, and that is tied to the domestic market price of wheat, it follows that all producers enjoy the activities of the Wheat Export Authority and therefore should contribute, on the basis of their production, to the financial support of the WEA. The sellers will always chase the best price, and the fluctuations of the domestic market and export market prices are directly relative. If all the wheat growers in Australia contribute towards the funding of the Wheat Export Authority in the form of a fee per tonne of production, the shared cost across the industry would be demonstrably significantly less. I can recommend this bill to the House as long as it finally reflects a situation that places that cost of support for the WEA across the broad range of wheat producers in Australia.

I thank the member for Braddon for his significant contributions to this debate in outlining the detail of the legislation. I do, however, feel that he fell down on the significance of the Tasmanian wheat product: we could put the Tasmanian wheat production into a very small part of the Western Australia production. We are proud of being wheat producers in Western Australia and I am very proud to have a very large number of those producers in my vast electorate.

I look forward to the result of the Senate committee's deliberations, which will have a great bearing on the final passage of the bill. But it cannot be overlooked that all wheat producers must contribute to supporting the Wheat Export Authority. The authority need to be more independent and to prove to growers that they are more independent. The fact that is there is suspicion that they are not independent is enough to call for changes to be made eventually that will indicate that they are truly independent. Whether they are going to continue to do their job will depend upon the significance of their report in 2004, and the existence in the long term of the single desk will depend on the appropriateness and thoroughness of that report by the Wheat Export Authority. Even though I accept that there are many more questions to be answered, generally I applaud the passage of this legislation because I recognise in practical terms that we have to give teeth to the Wheat Export Authority so they can do their job, because their job will determine the destiny of the single wheat export desk in this country.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002 and do so from a background of representing an electorate in Queensland which is a very large wheat growing region. In fact, the most significant part of the wheat grown in Queensland would be grown in my electorate of Maranoa. The Wheat Marketing Act—for which we are putting forward amendments today with the new structure of Australian Wheat Board Ltd and Australian Wheat Board International—is now some four years old, so it is appropriate that there are amendments to be made. That is why, in looking at the amendments, I would like to quote some of the points made by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry in his second reading speech on what this bill seeks to do. He said:

quote.para: The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill forms part of the arrangements to provide a funding mechanism—

speech.para: which the previous speaker, the member for Kalgoorlie, was focusing very strongly on—

quote.para: for the wheat industry to meet the operational costs of the Wheat Export Authority (WEA). In order to raise the main stream revenue for the continued operation of the WEA it is proposed that a charge will be applied to all exports of wheat, commencing during the first half of—

speech.para: this year. The new Wheat Marketing Act was some five years in its development. There was a very wide debate. The member for Parkes, who represents a large wheat growing region in New South Wales, was involved very heavily prior to coming into this place. The structure was debated by wheat growers all around Australia. It was important that we had that debate, because at the end of the day the wheat industry belongs to the growers of Australia—it is their industry. It is essential that the control of the wheat industry is not taken over by other authorities or by the government, and that is why we bring forward this legislation to complement and support the new Wheat Marketing Act. In the five years of development its new structure was, from time to time, debated very heavily and furiously—and, I might say, debated by elements with vested interests in the wheat industry.

The other element of the amendments points to the privatisation of the wheat marketing financing arrangements in 1999, which, through the grower controlled Australian Wheat Board Ltd, are associated with the activities of the single desk arrangement for the export of wheat. The single desk export status for the Australian Wheat Board is absolutely critical to ensuring that the wheat growers of Australia are able to maximise their returns when their wheat is sold into export markets. It is no secret that there are corrupted world markets in relation to many products, including, in this case, wheat. That is why the government has so strongly supported the single desk export status for the Australian wheat industry. It has stood the test of time for decades and for decades single desk has repeatedly delivered for the wheat growers of Australia as they compete in corrupted markets around the world.

The other important element is the fact that the single desk export status for the Australian Wheat Board has the support of 90 per cent of growers. I take this opportunity to say that, when the new act was brought forward with the single desk export status being assigned to the Australian Wheat Board, it was supported by all political parties. Today's debate is an important opportunity for members on the other side of the House to say quite clearly that they continue to support that policy. Whilst many of them may not fully understand what it means or the intricacies of the wheat industry, we on this side of the House are always happy to counsel them on this issue.

I know that there are some economic rationalists, including one sitting at the table, on the other side of the House. I would urge the member for Werriwa to get across the issue and remember that the single desk export status for the Australian Wheat Board has the support of 90 per cent of wheat growers of Australia. For decades it has helped the wheat growers of Australia to make sure that the maximum amount of the value of wheat exported from this country is returned to the growers. There are certainly those who want to change it, but I have often found when I have travelled around that they are the ones who want to get into the industry as a single exporting entity and want to make money out of it. That is all very well, but our interest on this side of the parliament is about how we support the growers maximising their returns. Whilst those who wish to change the system seek to grow their profits in the interests of their shareholders, that stands in stark contrast to the objectives of the government of having a single desk export status for Australian wheat growers' interests.

As we negotiate our free trade agreement with the United States, it is absolutely essential that the single desk export status for the Australian wheat industry remains non-negotiable. I have spoken to the Minister for Trade and other colleagues on this side of the parliament. I know the member for Parkes would agree that this must remain a non-negotiable element in any discussions with the United States about our free trade agreement with them. That is why we give the Australian Wheat Board the charter to be the single desk export authority for wheat in this country. We know that under the charter we are able to make sure that they maximise the return for the Australian wheat grower.

Whilst it may not be directly related to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002, I think it is important to take this opportunity to talk about a new investment of the Australian Wheat Board. The Australian Wheat Board is, at the end of the day, acting in the best interests of growers in my electorate. Recently they have announced that they are going to put two new super wheat dumps in my electorate, one at the small community of The Gums in a very good wheat growing region and the other at Talwood, west of Goondiwindi, in another premium wheat growing area. In both of those communities, investments are going to be in the order of $8 million to $11 million. It is obvious that benefits will flow to those communities through that investment in the construction phase, and at the end of the day the wheat growers will benefit from the new wheat dumps.

One of the great benefits from the wheat growers' point of view is that these new super wheat dumps will be able to receive wheat 24 hours a day, seven days a week and shorten the turnaround time for the delivery of wheat from the farmer to the wheat receival point. That has real benefits and savings for growers and, under the charter, the Wheat Board will be delivering those savings in lower cost charges to the wheat growers.

Once again—and I am sure that the member for Parkes, who has a number of these super wheat dumps in his electorate, would agree—this demonstrates how the Australian Wheat Board is working in the interests of the growers' pie; in other words, the returns to the Australian wheat grower. These investments in the new super dumps that are coming into my electorate in Queensland are, firstly, about greater competition, and also about ensuring that the Wheat Board can, importantly, maximise returns to growers. From the growers' point of view, being able to deliver 24 hours a day, seven days a week—rather than from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. or 6 a.m. to 6 p.m., as has been the custom in the past with some of the other wheat receival points—will mean that they will no longer have to put up large structures on their properties to store wheat when they are unable to deliver to the dumps. This will ensure that the wheat is delivered as soon as possible after harvest to maximise quality and enable wheat quality and storage to be more closely monitored by the Wheat Board itself. The Wheat Board will also be able to oversee quality in terms of residues of pesticides that would be used once the wheat is received for storage. For growers it is so often an issue of making sure that the grain during storage on the farm is protected from insect pests and other undesirables.

Rail has a very important place in the transport of bulk commodities such as wheat to our ports. Another benefit of these wheat dumps is that they will give greater security to the rail lines in these areas—the Dirranbandi line and the line out to Glenmorgan are two examples—and with that goes jobs with our railways. Once again, this is regional development and regional jobs which benefit the whole community.

The other thing I would like to quickly raise is the issue of the charges that Queensland Rail, in particular, impose for the freight and handling of wheat from the wheat growing dumps in Queensland to the export ports. Their access costs are quite unreasonable and very uncompetitive, even with states like Victoria and New South Wales. I call on the Queensland government to very seriously look at and address this issue. I call on them to look at what is happening in Victoria and New South Wales and allow the Wheat Board, as they do in New South Wales, to run some of their own rolling stock. The Wheat Board are not going to invest in this rolling stock unless they can get greater control over the associated costs with the movement of grain from their dumps along Queensland Rail's lines to the export harbours. I ask the Queensland government to look at this because, at the end of the day, the inefficiencies that they have built into their system are costs that are ultimately borne by the Queensland wheat grower.

We have been suffering from the worst drought in history in so much of eastern Australia and, as the opportunity for wheat to be planted this year is rapidly approaching, wheat growers will want to maximise their opportunities to plant wheat in drought affected areas if the drought—hopefully—breaks this year. The Wheat Board is going to want to maximise its returns to growers in order for them to be able to pay back some of the debt that they have built up during the drought. The Labor Party in Queensland and the state Labor government, through their inefficiencies and their failure to address this issue, will be costing the wheat growers in Queensland dearly. I ask them to look at that, particularly as farmers recover—and, hopefully, this is the year that they can recover—from the worst drought in 100 years.

In conclusion, this bill is part of the ongoing support that this government gives to the industry itself to determine its own future. It also ensures that the single desk export status for the Australian wheat industry is one that is vested to them, because we know that that is the way that the maximum returns to wheat growers will be assured.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002 as somebody who is very much involved in the industry, being a long-term grower of wheat and somebody who has dealt with wheat growers for a long time. Wheat is Australia's most important grain crop. Australia exports $3½ billion worth of wheat, on average, every year—although probably not at this current time—and accounts for 17 per cent of the world's export demand. It is our dominant grain crop, representing one-quarter of all Australian farm production. Wheat accounts for approximately 16 per cent of Australia's total farm exports and contributes around $8 billion in annual revenue to the Australian economy. Well over 100,000 farming family members and 70,000 direct employees depend upon wheat for most of their income. The wheat crop affects over 550,000 people, most of whom are in rural and regional or country Australia and in small enterprises. Wheat is particularly important in my electorate of Parkes. Parkes is the largest federal electorate in New South Wales and home to some 3,000 farmers, most of them operating a mixed farming enterprise with a very significant annual wheat production as part of that enterprise.

speech.para: Average Australian wheat production in the last five years was over 21 million tonnes—about four per cent of the world's output. Record production of 24 million tonnes was achieved in 1999-2000 but, as most people would remember, that was a downgraded crop. Those were the years in which the top half of New South Wales was inundated with rain and flooding. It was a very big crop but a very downgraded crop and therefore not as profitable as some. Australia exports about 16.5 million tonnes of wheat each year, or 16 per cent of the world trade, worth around $4 billion, making us the third-largest exporter of wheat in the world, behind the United States and Canada.

We as a government recognise the value of wheat production to the Australian economy and certainly to country people. As a commodity wheat is vital to the strength and prosperity of our whole economy and, again, definitely vital to the rural economy. It has made us a very powerful player in international trade and a very respected agricultural exporter. Over the years the Wheat Board has gone out of its way to educate buyers—to teach them how to use our wheat to produce the sorts of bread that each particular country wants.

One of the reasons why we are respected was underlined very recently when our government purchased 100,000 tonnes of wheat which, because of the war, obviously could not be sold directly to Iraq and was stranded. The government purchased the wheat by agreement with Australian Wheat International, and it is going to be given to Iraq as a humanitarian gesture. That will also stand Australian wheat growers in very good stead when we sit down after the conflict to work on the 50 years of trading harmony that we have had with Iraq—not with those who run Iraq but with those who deal with the grain, those who mill it. This gesture of 100,000 tonnes of wheat bought by the government to give to the citizens of Iraq will stand us in very good stead in the future. Our government is very keen to protect that market. That is why we are moving to protect our international reputation as a wheat dealer and that is why we are moving to amend the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 to provide for the continued funding of the Wheat Export Authority, the WEA, by the wheat industry.

The Wheat Export Authority is an independent statutory authority which was established on 1 June 1989 as part of the restructure of the Australian Wheat Board when it was privatised to basically give growers control of their own board. The WEA was set up to control the export of wheat after the transfer of the government's wheat marketing and selling role to AWB Ltd, a private company controlled by wheat growing shareholders. The Wheat Export Authority operates independently from AWB Ltd and its subsidiaries, which include AWB International Ltd.

The WEA operates under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 and has three main functions. The first of these is to control the export of wheat from Australia—in other words, who can do it. Obviously the single desk means that all bulk wheat and a very high proportion of container wheat can only be exported by AWB International. The WEA's second role is to monitor AWB International's performance on wheat exports and examine and report on the benefits to growers of that performance. Its third role is to conduct a review of, and report to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry on, the way AWB International Ltd uses its wheat export rights under the legislation before the end of 2004. I will come back to that. The 2004 review is an important time in the lives of wheat growers and of the AWB in terms of how it performs its role and how the single desk continues.

With this bill we are proposing to set up a funding mechanism which would allow the wheat industry to meet the running costs of the Wheat Export Authority. The first component of the bill consists of a charge applied to all wheat exports to commence during the first half of 2003. Essentially, this means that the industry would continue to fund the body that represents them. I believe that the wheat industry, rather than the government, should fund the Wheat Export Authority. We have privatised it. It is no longer run and controlled by government; it is controlled by the growers. We want the WEA to do a job for us in reporting to the government on how the AWB is doing but, more essentially, the Wheat Export Authority has to monitor the way in which the single desk and niche markets are utilised. It is doing that on our behalf, for our profitability, and I think that we are the ones who should fund it.

Without a doubt, wheat growers are the main beneficiaries of the Wheat Export Authority and the single desk marketing system it represents. As the previous speaker, the member for Maranoa, said, without doubt the vast majority of growers do support the single desk. I fully support the wishes of wheat growers—I am one myself—and I certainly support the single desk. I have not been much of a wheat grower this last season, though. A lot of us in New South Wales, especially those in the west, have had to take a bath as far as any wheat—let alone wheat exports—is concerned. But let us be a bit optimistic for the future.

We must have a system whereby those who seek out profitable small markets can take advantage of them on behalf of the grower, because this is essentially about the grower and about niche markets. Any system you set up to monitor and report has to be funded; it is as simple as that. This bill is about ensuring the harmony of the wheat industry. I repeat: it is about ensuring the harmony and progress of the wheat industry, essentially the export industry. Although some growers put their money into the pool through the Wheat Board, many do not. In New South Wales we have a huge domestic industry; in fact, the majority of wheat in New South Wales is consumed domestically. Western Australia has a huge export industry; far and away the majority of Western Australia's wheat is exported. In this day and age there are many options for the wheat grower, both domestically and internationally. If growers or their agents are able to seek out container markets—niche markets—with obvious profitability, we need to look after them. A lot of the time the Wheat Board, dealing in bulk wheat, has neither the resources nor the desire to do so.

The Wheat Export Authority's functions have to be funded and it stands to reason that, as we privatise wheat boards and grain handling authorities, government is now merely the factor that legalises the way in which wheat is dealt with, not the factor that controls it. That is essentially in growers' hands. I very firmly believe that it is up to the industry to fund that process. We cannot have our cake and eat it. This legislation is necessary and I very much support it.

I totally support the single desk and at the same time I also support the right of exporters or growers, who find niche container markets, to take advantage of a price above the norm. For that to happen we have to ensure that growers contribute to, and have a certain degree of control over, the body that represents them. The levy proposed in this bill asks growers to contribute to the Wheat Export Authority, the body that represents the single desk and the export value of their commodity. But the Wheat Export Authority needs money to work. Wheat growers agreed—in fact, they expressed a desire—to privatise the wheat board, and that includes the responsibility to fund it.

There are varied views about niche markets and container traffic and there are many arguments as to why grain dealers should be able to export to niche container markets. Most of these markets are small but profitable. The containers quite often go to ports that cannot take the deep draught of a bulk ship. Quite often millers simply cannot handle the vast quantity of bulk grain on a container ship; they can only handle containers and small amounts of grain—but by and large they are profitable. Sometimes it is simply a matter of the importers not being able to use bulk wheat because physically the ships cannot get in. But those markets are real, they are there and they are genuine.

As I said, bulk wheat shipments should remain under the single desk system. However, I believe that the Australian Wheat Board would be well advised to take note of the activities of those who want to take advantage of niche markets, strictly in container traffic—I am not suggesting for one second that this would ever be part of the bulk market. Given that there is no question of bulk wheat shipments going outside the single desk—certainly not at this time, because I agree that the vast majority of growers believe utterly in the single desk—the Australian Wheat Board would be well advised not to be overprotective in its advice to the Wheat Export Authority when applications are made by exporters for container shipments.

Container traffic is well under five per cent of total wheat exports and not likely to go above that. But it is a good market. It is one that brings profitability to a lot of people and exporters who work on the growers' behalf—as does the wheat board. It is unfortunate that so many people, especially grain growers, have been affected by the drought in recent times. As we get nearer to late April and May—we only have a month—people will be looking to sow. Many areas of Australia—and certainly in New South Wales, including my areas in the west—have not had rain and that would lead us to believe that we will not be able to get in a big crop. However, I hope that this year we will get a good crop. I commend this legislation to the House and to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak briefly to the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 2002. I support the bill. I believe that it will get through the Senate without any great difficulty. As a former member of the Grains Council of Australia and a grain grower myself, I am very interested in the changes that take place from time to time in the grains industry—in this case, specifically the wheat industry. I will not reiterate some of the issues that have been raised by previous speakers.

speech.para: The member for Kalgoorlie spoke about autonomy issues in relation to the Wheat Export Authority, other issues within the wheat industry and transparency issues—issues which have been raised from time to time. These are matters of concern to many growers and the government should be aware of and keep a constant eye on them.

As the previous speaker, the member for Parkes, has said, there will be a very important review of the wheat industry in a couple of years time and there will need to be ongoing monitoring of the Wheat Export Authority and its relationships with the Australian Wheat Board Ltd and other players in the wheat industry. There is concern that there may be a coming together of many of the major players in the grains industry and that the growers may not be included in a lot of the negotiations. I do not think it is fair to say—as most speakers have said—that the wheat growers should be funding the levy. Previously they have been funded by a $6 million grant. I think it is fair to put on the record that there are a number of views out there—obviously the government would rather get out of making a contribution, and I can understand that—that the community would benefit from the work of the Wheat Export Authority and as such should make a contribution, through government, to the operation of that authority.

A number of other issues have been raised in recent years in relation to the operation of the wheat industry, and other speakers have spoken about the single desk and its impact on growers across the nation. There was great concern in the durum wheat industry a couple of years ago, which demonstrated that where there are niche markets there needs to be a little more flexibility in how those people can operate. I believe that a number of very good proactive and innovative growers were damaged by the way they were treated with the work that they had done in the development of what is loosely called the spaghetti and pasta wheat industries and those markets, both within Australia and externally.

This bill is essentially about the Wheat Export Authority. There has been a lot of talk about the export of wheat; how we are essentially an exporting nation and we do need to export to generate the income that the country survives on, or partly survives on. I would like to take a bit of leave from the bill and talk about an issue—which was raised again yesterday—which is not about export; it is about export replacement and import replacement. That is the issue of ethanol and the way in which the grains industry can make a contribution to the fuel industry. Rather than exporting our grains to purchase our fuels, particularly given the uncertainty in the Middle East which could flow into the oil industry and have significant impact, we have an opportunity within Australia to grow our fuel—not only through the wheat industry but also through the sorghum industry, the corn industry and, to a lesser extent, the sugar industry and other sources, but obviously the wheat industry is the largest.

I see people are coming into the public gallery; obviously they are very interested in this issue, so I will give them an example in relation to a proposal for an ethanol plant in the Gunnedah area. The member for Maranoa spoke earlier, and he has a similar proposal in relation to his electorate. These proposals are $60 million private sector investments. They would produce 60 million litres of ethanol annually and provide an enormous impetus to the grains industries within those regions. One ethanol plant of that magnitude produces one-quarter of one per cent of Australia's fuel needs. That one-quarter of one per cent, in terms of the impact it would have on agriculture, would have an effect on about 200,000 acres of cropland. If we are talking about a mandatory 10 per cent ethanol included in our fuel, as many of us are, you are talking about 40 of these plants, which is something like $2.4 billion worth of private sector investment to replace 10 per cent of what we now import into this country from overseas sources. So there is an enormous opportunity.

I am glad to see some of the cabinet ministers coming in now. I believe the issue of ethanol is before the cabinet at the moment. The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry is just approaching, and he is well aware of this issue. I am sure he will be trying to get his cabinet colleagues to get on top of this and support the issue of ethanol from grain. As I said, this bill has been about the Wheat Export Authority, but we also have opportunities within agriculture in Australia to replace the need to export some of our grain and instead produce fuel from that grain. Obviously there would be benefits not only for grain growers; there would also be an impact on the price of fuel. With the current uncertainty overseas, we have got to look very seriously at the investment regime that we have the opportunity to put in place.

I am well aware—as the minister for agriculture is probably also aware and doing the honest battle in relation to this issue—that we need to encourage the ethanol industry so that we do not have to export so much grain and to find markets that are essentially corrupted internationally. To encourage the development of this industry we do need a 10 per cent cap placed on the ethanol industry. We do need the ongoing removal of the 38c per litre excise, which is currently removed for one year for one of the friends of the Prime Minister. That is something that has to be put in place to give investment certainty for people who are keen to invest in the ethanol industry.

While I am on my feet, I would like to raise the issue of the cost-effectiveness of the transport area within the wheat industry and the dealings of the Commonwealth with the New South Wales government in relation to the Australian Rail Track Corporation and access to New South Wales tracks. I think there have been some problems there; hopefully they will be overcome now that the New South Wales election is over. I would suggest to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, and others who are interested in getting the price of freight down in Australia, that within New South Wales—in the electorate of Gwydir—they look very seriously at the Murrurundi tunnel issue, which does require some degree of investment. I am not suggesting that the federal government make that investment but, in relation to the dealings with the New South Wales government, I think that it should be on the agenda rather than off it.

The other issue in relation to getting the costs of rail freight down is the inland rail corridor, which is a proposal that has been about for quite some time. I would hope that the Prime Minister, who is in the chamber at the moment, would look very closely at the assistance that the government can give to the creation of an inland rail network.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

subdebate.1.para: Mr TRUSS (Wide Bay—Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry) (2.00 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be absent from question time today. She is attending the state funeral in Brisbane of World War I veteran Eric Abraham on behalf of the government. The Minister for Foreign Affairs will answer questions on her behalf.

talker.name: Crean, Simon, MP
Mr CREAN
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports today of the growing concerns of the Secretary-General of the United Nations at the humanitarian casualties of the US-led war in Iraq and his observation that the belligerents are responsible for the welfare of the civilian population? Prime Minister, what are your comments in response to those observations of the Secretary-General? Can the Prime Minister report to the House what the latest estimate of humanitarian casualties is and reassure the House that all necessary steps are being taken to protect civilians?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I have been aware of the remarks made by the Secretary-General of the United Nations—and they are understandable. The concern that he has for the safety of civilians in this conflict is understood and is very much in the minds of the governments of the United States, the United Kingdom and Australia. Of course, it is not in the mind of the government of Iraq. I have no doubt that the Secretary-General's comments were in part the consequence of the reported deaths of some 15 civilians in Baghdad—and I will have something to say about that and about the issue generally. On the information in my possession, I am satisfied that the incident was not the result of deliberate targeting of civilians by the United States or of an indiscriminate bombing policy. At this stage it is unclear as to whether it was caused by accidental United States action or action of the Iraqis. Any civilian casualty in war is tragic. I have to say that in this particular conflict unprecedented steps have been taken by the coalition to avoid civilian casualties.

answer.para: I say very directly through this parliament to the Secretary-General and to others who are legitimately concerned about civilian casualties: I contrast the policy of the United States government, the British government and the Australian government to the behaviour of the Iraqi regime. For example, Iraq is deliberately placing air defence and other military assets in close proximity to civilian sites in Baghdad. Saddam Hussein's forces have also used a hospital at An Nasiriyah as a headquarters for the storage of arms. There are other examples where deliberate action has been taken as an instrument of war and as an instrument of political propaganda to use civilians as shields and to deliberately play upon the very legitimate and genuine humanitarian concerns of civilian populations in democracies such as Australia. Given the intensity of the attacks that have taken place, civilian casualties so far, on our advice, have been remarkably low. I cannot give the Leader of the Opposition a precise figure, but all the advice available to us indicates that, because of the policy being followed by the United States and by the British, it is remarkably low.

Some commentators have even suggested that the targeting policies of the allies in this conflict have been such as to put at greater risk the lives of defence personnel serving on behalf of the United States and the United Kingdom. That is not an assessment that I make and it is not an assessment that the government makes—it is an assessment made by many commentators.

It is always unrealistic to imagine that you could have a conflict of this kind without some civilian casualties. But I repeat again that unprecedented steps have been taken by the Americans, the British and by us to keep those casualties to an absolute minimum—and that is in stark contrast to the deliberate policy of the Iraqi regime to put the lives of their own civilians at risk as a political instrument and as a psychological instrument against the forces that are aligned against them.

Let me also say that it ought to be remembered by this House that if Iraq had complied with multiple Security Council resolutions, military action would not have been necessary. I think it is important to remind ourselves every day, as we respond in an episodic fashion to individual incidents, that the reason why the action has been taken is that Iraq failed to comply with multiple resolutions of the Security Council of the United Nations. That is something that I say not only to the Leader of the Opposition but to others who have been critical.

It remains the case that the Australian government is adhering to all of its international legal obligations in relation to targeting policy and to the activities of our armed forces. It is a primary concern in all Australian Defence Force operations to protect civilians. The Australian Defence Force follows a rigorous process to minimise the risk to civilians and to buildings and infrastructure used for civilian purposes. Targets selected by Australian forces are analysed and approved through a comprehensive Australian approval process that includes ministerial oversight. Access to legal advice is an integral part of that process; legal officers have been placed in the theatre to advise our commanders and our troops of their legal obligations and to assist in determining the validity of targets.

Those are some of the steps we are taking. Similar steps are being taken by the British and the Americans. Of course, no such steps are being taken by Saddam Hussein—no such steps are being taken by the Iraqis. I simply ask the Leader of the Opposition and, indeed, the Secretary-General of the United Nations, whose concern I share, to please examine the relative behaviour of the British and the Americans and the Iraqis. Any suggestion of moral equivalence between the coalition and the Iraqis on this occasion I totally reject.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister update the House on the latest developments regarding the delivery of humanitarian aid to the Iraqi people?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr DOWNER
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Macquarie for his question and for his interest. As members of the House know from the answers I have given to previous questions on this matter, we are very focused, as a government, on the humanitarian situation of the Iraqi people. We welcome the call yesterday by the United Nations Secretary-General for unity in the Security Council and, in particular, for the quick resumption of the oil for food program. Our permanent representative to the United Nations, John Dauth, underlined this in a statement that he made to the Security Council during the course of this morning in what still is the open debate in the Security Council on the Iraq issue:

quote.para: We very much hoped that the members of the Security Council focus on what is at stake and provide the guidance the international community is waiting for on humanitarian needs and long-term reconstruction.

answer.para: On the specifics, members will be aware that our Navy divers are making Umm Qsar port safe to enable aid deliveries. Umm Qsar is the only deepwater port in Iraq. It is crucially important that this port remains open, and it is a great tribute to our Navy divers that they are making the port safe. We expect two ships carrying Australian wheat to berth at Umm Qsar possibly this weekend. We have sent an Australian aid expert to Kuwait to work with the World Food Program and the United States on the logistics for the distribution of the wheat. Some humanitarian supplies from Kuwait have now arrived in Iraq, and they will be distributed shortly.
