subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to speak today on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. The bill has various elements to it, and it is a very important bill. I am somewhat disappointed that I adjourned the House to allow the sideshow that eventually occurred with the member for Werriwa and all his stunts. But we are back here to debate the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, and there are some serious issues to discuss. This bill has five schedules, and they are very important schedules that make quite an impact. Schedule 1 makes an amendment to the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997 to allow the inclusion of written material which changes in the future under that act. Schedule 2 makes amendments to the FOI Act 1982. Schedule 3 makes amendments to the Radio Communications Act 1992. Schedule 4 makes an amendment to the Telecommunications Act 1997. Schedule 5 makes amendments to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999.

speech.para: I would like to start by discussing the FOI Act amendments, because they are the ones that I think attract the greatest attention in this place. In fact, they are the subject of an amendment that has been put forward by the opposition. But, in addressing those issues, I was stunned to hear the comments of the member opposite who attacked the government over changes to FOI, accusing the government of wanting to undermine FOI and its value to the Australian community. I think that smacked of rank hypocrisy, coming from a member of the Labor Party—the same party in Queensland that is currently proposing to introduce FOI on the media. Can you imagine a more ridiculous and repressive idea than to impose FOI on the media? I would like to quote from an article in Wednesday's Courier-Mail headed `Beattie accused of wanting to boost media censorship'. It states:

quote.para: Premier Peter Beattie wants his Government to regulate the free press.

speech.para: This is the same party that is accusing this government of wanting to do something to limit FOI and to limit freedoms in Australia. Bizarre, isn't it, that Premier Beattie—the Labor Party—is proposing to regulate the free press? The article continues:

quote.para: Mr Beattie said the Commonwealth had the power to regulate radio and television, but his Government retained the right to regulate newspapers and could possibly extend Freedom of Information laws to do so.

speech.para: The article went on to quote Mr Beattie. He said:

quote.para: `They are able to publish their opinions without fear of contradiction—

speech.para: terrible, isn't it—

quote.para: and, all to often without supporting evidence.
I do not believe journalists should be responsible to government.
But I do argue they should be responsible to the public, in the same way ministers are responsible—through public scrutiny of their actions.'
Opposition Leader Lawrence Springborg—

speech.para: and good on him—

quote.para: said the proposal would discourage whistleblowers and allow the government to influence editorial policies.
`Are we going to have a regulated press now with reporting standards handed down by Generallisimo Beattie?' Mr Springborg asked.

speech.para: I agree with him. On the face of it, it is a ridiculous suggestion, but it is at the same time very sinister. The member for Werriwa was saying before that government members were going to go back to their offices and watch Baghdad on the TV. He and his mates over there are trying to emulate a Baghdad kind of proposal; they basically want to regulate the free press. I do not know what they think they are doing, and I think they have a hell of a hide in trying to pick on this government and accuse us of trying to manipulate freedom of information laws. The debate is still going on up there. Mr Beattie's shameless way is just about as shameless as members opposite are with their continuous calls for quorums—and I suspect the member for Rankin is going to do that in a minute. (Quorum formed)

I return to the sins of the Beattie government and their crazy plan to impose FOI on the media in Queensland. As my friend the member for Hinkler just remarked to me, any government that starts to try and control the media is indeed troubled; I suspect that is probably the case for the media tart Mr Beattie and his government. The debate is continuing, and they are determined to maintain this line. Today in the Courier-Mail there is another article about the Premier launching off against the media again. It is entitled `Beattie sees need for media ombudsman' and reads:

quote.para: The media should be answerable to an ombudsman and have their internal workings exposed under Freedom of Information laws, Premier Peter Beattie said yesterday.

speech.para: What have the media done to Mr Beattie? Do the government want their internal workings exposed to FOI? What are they going to discover; are they going to discover what the food is like at the Courier-Mail or just how bad the canteen at the ABC is? We hear a lot about that on the ABC in Queensland. Honestly, cracking down on the media in this way has a Stalinist feel to it. It really is just right over the top, and Premier Beattie and the Labor Party ought to pull their heads in. Frankly, to come in here and attack us over FOI when Premier Beattie is doing that is absolutely hollow. The article closes:

quote.para: A spokesman for Mr Beattie last night clarified that section 51 of the Constitution gave regulation of wireless and telegraphy to the Federal Government and, by omission, left the regulation of print media to the states.

speech.para: Is it our fault? Is it our fault that Premier Beattie wants to go and attack the media in his state? It is absurd. The issues covered in this bill are very important. The issue raised in relation to FOI is important, because the amendments proposed are to stop people using FOI to access banned Internet sites. Those banned Internet sites include sites such as those that have been refused classification in Australia, that are classified X or that are restricted—in other words, that have an R classification—but are not subject to an ABA authorised restricted access system. I am a member of the parliamentary committee on the Australian Crime Commission. That committee has recently announced that it is conducting an inquiry into cybercrime.

One of the things that is beginning to emerge for members of that committee is that practically the entire range of criminal activity can be augmented through some kind of Internet or cybercrime dimension. By utilising the Internet, there can be a new dimension in crime that I think is going to concern many people. It ranges across every type of crime, from simple confidence tricks to terrorism. Each of these things have a potential place on the Web. Across Australia, police and law enforcement bodies are scrambling to come to grips with these new criminal activities. The Australian Federal Police does deserve credit for the steps it has taken in order to address the growing problem of cybercrime, but all police forces across Australia and, indeed, all governments need to cooperate to make sure that, as these criminal opportunities are exploited on the Web, governments are acting responsibly to address them. The inquiry that is being conducted by the parliamentary committee is timely. I would urge all those law enforcement bodies and anybody involved in the IT industry—ISP providers and those sorts of people—to get involved in the inquiry and to seek to come to grips with the problems that it addresses.

As the member opposite said, there have been something like 170 different refused classification descriptions, and 263 decisions in all, that have been covered since this issue first emerged. But the fact that those decisions have not been queried under FOI does not mean that they will not be. The fact that we are having this debate here tonight indicates that this is coming to the forefront. It is something that is becoming apparent. I think I should highlight the fact that it all came to light because of the activities of a group called Electronic Frontiers Australia Inc, a non-profit organisation representing Internet users. They are concerned with online freedoms and rights, and they have been probing these issues. I suppose, from their point of view, it is ironic that their probing has resulted in an effort to clamp down on this issue but it is entirely appropriate that we should do so, because what they have unearthed in looking at the issue is the fact that it is possible for people to seek the Web addresses of banned sites under FOI.

This is something that this legislation addresses, and it is entirely appropriate that it should do so. It is important that we monitor what happens on the Web, because opportunities to spread child pornography and those sorts of things should not be made—(Quorum formed) The point about the prevalence of, for example, child pornography on the Net is well reported in an article that was in the Australian this week, headed `Child porn on peer-to-peer'. It is talking about a style of Internet program called peer-to-peer type processing. It reports findings from the US General Accounting Office which searched a popular file sharing program using 12 keywords associated with child pornography and found 1,286 files, of which 42 per cent were associated with child pornography and 34 per cent with adult pornography. There was a similar search done by US Customs, and that agency also searched using innocuous keywords, such as cartoon characters' and singers' names. Of 177 images downloaded, 55 per cent were pornographic. Clearly, there are opportunities with the Web for the prevalence of this type of material. If people are determined to get access to it and they seek to use all kinds of devices to do it, the opportunity to use FOI incorrectly to get access to, for example, child pornography, is something that we need to address.

The member opposite also spoke for a time about mobile phone towers and how he did not want them in various parts of his electorate. I wish I had the luxury of being able to refuse mobile phone towers in my electorate. I want to see more of these mobile phone towers, particularly in places such as around Linville in Blair. That is a hilly area less than 100 kilometres from Brisbane, which means of course that it is quite difficult.

talk.start.para: —Not unlike Conondale; it needs one too.

—It is not unlike Conondale. It is very similar to Conondale; in fact, it is right next-door. It is a similar sort of area, and the minister has the same sort of problem. In an area like that, I am going to welcome a mobile phone tower, if I can get it, because it improves signals and provides services to members.
—For security to the farmers.

—To the farmers, to the local people, to everyone in that area. It is just unjust for members opposite to continue to follow the NIMBY tradition—the tradition of `not in my backyard'—to the disadvantage of their local communities. It is important to provide those sorts of services to ensure that we are adequately served in our electorates. (Time expired)

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr Hatton) adjourned.

Ms WORTH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: These amendments to the Health Insurance Amendment (Diagnostic Imaging, Radiation Oncology and Other Measures) Bill 2002 are very simple in nature and relate to dates only, omitting 30 April 2003 in relevant places and substituting a single day to be fixed by proclamation or the first day after the end of the period of six months, beginning on the day on which this act received the royal assent. It will be the earlier of either of those.

talk.start.para: —I was here on Tuesday during the debate on the Health Insurance Amendment (Diagnostic Imaging, Radiation Oncology and Other Measures) Bill 2002, to let the House know, on behalf of my constituents of Lowe, about the need for the provision by the federal government for a licence for Concord Hospital to get an MRI machine. On 11 February this year, the New South Wales health minister, Mr Craig Knowles, acceded to the wishes of the Labor candidate for Drummoyne in the recent state election to pay for the cost of an MRI machine and for the installation of that machine, subject to Senator Kay Patterson providing a licence for an MRI machine for Concord Hospital. This is a very important issue for my electorate, and it is one that I have been campaigning for for almost 12 months. Last year, I was approached by the head of the radiology department of Concord Repatriation General Hospital about the need for an MRI machine, which is a very important diagnostic tool, for Concord Hospital.

speech.para: For your information, the Concord Repatriation General Hospital, which is in the heart of my electorate of Lowe, is a major teaching hospital of the University of Sydney and has been denied an MRI licence by Senator Patterson. I have asked her two questions on notice, and I have been given the smoke and mirrors response that it is not possible to indicate when Concord Hospital would be entitled to an MRI machine. That is not good enough for a major teaching hospital of the University of Sydney, when the minister has confirmed in her answers to my questions in this House that nine of the 13 teaching hospitals, or 70 per cent, provide Medicare eligible MRI services. In my electorate, the constituents that I represent presently have to travel from Concord Hospital to Westmead Hospital, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital or Royal North Shore Hospital. It is clearly unacceptable for patients to have to be transported from Concord Hospital to those hospitals because the government will not give an MRI licence to Concord Hospital.

I remember when Dr Wooldridge was under siege with the scan scam; we all remember that. Selected and privileged radiologists were tipped off with regard to the lucrative rebate that was available if they purchased an MRI machine in a very short period of time. It is not good enough for the government to look after selected radiologists but not provide an MRI machine or a licence so that one can be installed at Concord Hospital, which is in the heart of the inner west. It is a very important diagnostic tool, as I have said. I have tabled two petitions in this House, in addition to the questions that I have put to the minister, and I have a further question which has still not been answered. I put question No. 1503 to the minister to draw her attention to the press release of Minister Craig Knowles—the health minister of New South Wales—which guarantees that he will provide the funding for the purchase and installation of an MRI machine for Concord Hospital.

This is a very serious issue for my electorate. Concord Hospital desperately needs an MRI licence, desperately needs the MRI machine. My constituents, and certainly the people of the inner west, need to know that the federal health minister will grant the licence. I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary here tonight whether she would go back to Senator Patterson and ask her to expedite the request that is coming from Concord Hospital to provide that licence on behalf of my constituents. Close to 3,000 of them signed the petition, and there are more petitions being signed as I speak. This is something I am going to continue to campaign on; I have been going 12 months now. The government should know that the New South Wales health department is prepared to pay for the cost and the installation of it. All we want is the licence from the health minister. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. We have had a couple of speakers on the bill so far. We heard from the member for Blair on the other side. Our shadow minister for communications, the member for Melbourne, Lindsay Tanner, opened the batting on our side today. Previously, we heard from one other speaker, on 27 June 2002, when this bill was introduced—a pretty long time ago now, when we are actually getting down to dealing with it. We can take it that the government do not consider this bill to be of the utmost priority. In fact, in what they see as a relatively slow time, they are finally bringing it forward.

speech.para: Why might we figure that? It is because you could categorise this bill as a sort of grab bag of different measures. There are five schedules to the Telecommunications Act 1997, which seek to change the operation of the act in a series of different ways and that deal with particular problems. Partly in the minister's second reading speech, primarily in the thrust of the shadow minister's speech and for almost all of the member for Blair's speech, the debate has focused on the question of Internet content, the freedom of information legislation and the case that was before the ACA. That case was headed by Electronic Frontiers Australia on the question of whether or not it was possible to get access to Internet content that had been proscribed. It was not to get at the URLs, not to get at the Internet addresses, but to in fact be able to see what had been done and whether or not it was appropriate that the Australian Communications Authority took the action it did.

As pointed out by the shadow minister and as reflected in our amendment—which I may come back to later—along with action we intend to take in the Senate, Labor does not support schedule 2 of the bill. The fundamental reasoning behind that is quite simple. The member for Blair spent some time trying to put the counterargument that you could trust this government not to muck around with freedom of information and that you could trust this government not to try to make it more difficult for people to find out what they were doing in practice. I have had reasonable experience of this government since March 1996. I have also had a look, over a long period of time, at their progenitors. The last thing I think you could argue is that a conservative government could be trusted fully when it comes to the question of the Freedom of Information Act. It is not theirs, they do not fundamentally believe in it and they take every action they can to step aside from accountability.

One of the ways in which you can see that is not through what has been done in regard to schedule 2, but what has been done in regard to schedule 1 of this bill. You almost need to be a solicitor or a barrister who has specialised in admin law and the Acts Interpretation Act—rather arcane matters, let me say—to carve your way through schedule 1. The core of the question is how you deal with government by regulation and whether or not legislation should be made in this place, governed as it is by the executive. With the executive having belted it through this House, it then has to get to the house of review, the Senate. There, because of the situation and the numbers, it is sometimes dealt with in other ways.

You could argue that we have had a situation where we have had government by regulation in the past. There are some questions about determinations that have been made under the Telecommunications Act 1997 and those questions go to what can and cannot be done by reference. There is a strong move here, which is supposedly well intentioned—if we take what the minister says at face value and, of course, behind that, what the department says—to change to doing it by reference in order that the work of the department be more easily and more felicitously carried out. So you are back to not having the minister being involved in coming before the parliament to determine that things are being done. The idea is just to leave it up to the department and the minister, trust that they will do the right thing and trust that what they are telling us they are about is correct.

It has been argued by the shadow minister—and I agree with him in regard to schedule 2, but I would argue it for schedule 1 as well—that there is potentially an open door here. As we have always seen in the past, the least examined part of the federal government structure is the public service and decisions taken at public service level. It is particularly the case that, where decisions are taken through the regulation method, an enormous amount can be decided and prosecuted with virtually no scrutiny whatsoever. You get no scrutiny from the media who cover things that operate in this place. Very few people specialise in the effects of government by regulation, or government by reference where the departments are making determinations, or instruments in writing are being taken under the hand of the secretary of a department. So, although we are giving that a tick in regard to schedule 1—the only one we have given a cross to is schedule 2—it does open up that area of: how much do you trust this lot? How much do you trust that process? This is an area where we need, as ever, some check of just how well these processes are being undertaken.

Schedules 3, 4 and 5 contain some matters of interest that give an indication of what can happen over time and how changes that occur within society can pop up in legislation like this. I will deal with schedule 5 first. It deals with the task of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. The explanatory memorandum quite properly says:

quote.para: The TIO's mission statement is “Providing free, independent, just, informal and speedy resolution of complaints”.

speech.para: The explanatory memorandum goes on to set out the case that, because of the way the TIO is currently structured, there is an imposition on the companies to take note of the complaints made by their consumers and to speedily and cost-effectively deal with those complaints.

The situation is that the government has been forced to take action to further declare exactly what the situation is, because it is quite apparent that there have been try-ons by a number of carriers, who have said: `We've got all these extra costs. Complaints have come to us. We think the consumer should have to bear those extra costs.' This amendment has been brought to the minister's attention. Section 128 will therefore explicitly state that the TIO dispute resolution services are free to end users. The carriers talked about the wording: `Are these consumer complaints? If they are not complaints, they are disputes and we should not really pay them. We should be able to force it onto someone else.' This amendment is good because it will keep the onus on the company to quickly ameliorate the situation to the benefit of customers. Customers will not be slagged with it, and it will be in the company's interest to do it as fast as possible to keep costs down. That is a mechanism to keep them honest and true.

There are also some other mechanisms in schedule 5 to strengthen the ombudsman's hand to make sure that this works better than it has in the past. There is another subsection in schedule 5 that I want to deal with quickly, and that is to do with the National Relay Service. This is another example of companies having certain things imposed on them under the legislation and wanting to run away from them. Rightly, this will bring them to task. The National Relay Service is set up to provide normal telephone services to people with hearing problems and disabilities. There is a levy on providers to try to spread the costs over those companies. One.Tel operated on the basis that they took this levy and thought they could put off paying it eternally. The levy debt accumulated and One.Tel went belly up. Who pays for that? The people of the Commonwealth.

This amendment, properly, brings in a new regime: the debt cannot accumulate and quarterly payments are required. It ensures that the people who should be carrying the burden in relation to carriers do so and that the people who need help—people with hearing disabilities and problems—receive it. Anyone who takes this at face value might think that the telephone service provided to those people with hearing difficulties is provided at the same cost as it is to other people. That is not the case. In the wireless broadband inquiry that I was involved in recently, potent and vigorous evidence was given by people so affected that they were at an enormous disadvantage because the telephone systems that they have to use are antiquated and outdated. The cost of using the service is exorbitant because people have to access it through special terminals. Those terminals are very slow, and people have to type in most of the information.

This goes to the question of the cost to the carriers. They are defined in the legislation as `persons' but they are not the people with disabilities, who really have the problems. This is a problem that the government really needs to address and to ameliorate through their provision of wireless broadband. Wireless broadband holds out great hope for these people to be able to communicate effectively and for the costs, which are much greater in order for them to communicate, to be brought back to some semblance of equality with those of other people.

Schedule 4 is extremely interesting. Basically it knocks off an authority that has been around for four years. Some extraordinary things happen. I can understand that, when changes were made four years ago, there was an expectation that it would cost a lot of money, that the Commonwealth would need a mechanism through which it could provide a particular service through the Australian Communications Authority to try to quickly and efficiently sort out the provision of telecommunications towers in difficult spots—without companies that wanted to do it needing recourse to the courts and to other negotiations.

What is the effect of clause 40 of schedule 3 of the Telecommunications Act 1997? A number of people have been paid for four years, I imagine, basically to do zip. The people who were in this particular part of the ACA—the specially constituted Australian Communications Authority—are a group of people who have particular expertise. There are six people, with environmental, heritage and town planning expertise. The explanatory memorandum says:

quote.para: The committee members were appointed as eligible associate members in 1998 for five-year terms.

speech.para: That is fair enough. It continues:

quote.para: The six eligible associate members' appointments will be allowed to continue until their expiry date on 1 April 2003.

speech.para: So any proposed amendment would commence on that date. If there were any residual responsibilities, they would be undertaken by the ACA. I do not know what the residual responsibilities would be, but this mob have not had any work to do for four years—and they will not have any work to do, seemingly, for the year that this is intended to run.

Given that the government said that there is no financial impact from the measures in these schedules, I would like to know from the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, in his reply, what the cost has been over the past four years and what the cost will be over the full five years for all of those people who have been involved in this. In fact, I went to the trouble of tracking down some information from the ACA in terms of their flow charts on how you go about applying for the licences under this and so on. I also had a look at the organisational structure of the Australian Communications Authority, and it is a pretty close guess that there are six people here who are listed as eligible associate members—I will not give their names but that information is available on the web site. It does not specifically say, but my guess is that they are the specially constituted ACA. If they have been provided with remuneration over this four-year period, I would like to know. Have they been involved on a consultancy basis? Have they been required on an as-needed basis? Has office space been allocated to these people? Has there in fact been incorporated into the department's figures money spent in relation to providing this service—a service which nobody wanted in the end and which is now being axed? I cannot blame the department or the government for planning for this. It is a reasonable thing to do, with the expectation that a lot of this would flow. But you would think that the carriers were a bit silly not to use this facility, if it was meant to progress it fully, but to use the courts instead.

I would also like some comment, if possible, on the minister's determination, in having to make this change, on why the process failed, why private industry did not avail themselves of this service and what may or may not have been lacking with regard to that. It is a case of providing the parliament with more information about why this failed and what the real costs were with regard to it. It would be useful for the parliament and, no doubt, it would be useful for a number of people in the department to know that, because we are dealing with an authority not just that fell short of what was required but in which people did not have anything to do at all. We know that there are some people who are superannuated and stay on within the department, but these people, because of their capacities and their experience, would be well used elsewhere. Hopefully they have been able to continue their normal employment and this has just been temporary or tangential to what they would normally do.

The last area I would like to look at—and, again, this is a substantial area—indicates the changes you need to be fleet-footed enough to make in government and where necessary changes can actually flow through. It is the question of schedule 3, which deals with the radiocommunications spectrum and how it is allocated. It particularly deals with the covert surveillance that is undertaken by a number of authorities—not only the state police forces and the Federal Police but also the defence and emergency services and a series of others.

I commend the people who put the explanatory memorandum together with regard to all of these schedules. The part that deals with this section of the Radiocommunications Act is particularly well done. It outlines the National Crime Authority, the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission, the crime commissions in New South Wales and Queensland, the New South Wales ICAC and the Western Australian anticorruption commission as being bodies that are directly involved in this legislation. Up until now licences have been issued by regulation through the Australian Communications Authority to allow these investigative forces to use these services—not just police forces but an extension of that. Often the covert surveillance of suspects in significant crime and corruption cases is not undertaken by police officers, state or federal, but is undertaken by civilian employees or consultants, and they may not be properly covered.

The amendments seek to ensure that not only properly constituted police services but agencies or persons that they seek to use are fully covered and are properly and lawfully operating under the Telecommunications Act. The licences should be able to be given to them not just on a temporary 30-day basis—I think that is what it currently is—even though it is on a renewable 30-day basis. The argument is that, where you have ongoing investigations being undertaken, those investigations could be better serviced—and this almost goes back to schedule 1 again—by using a reference and having a written instrument which is a disallowable instrument under the hand of the secretary of the department. It is an indication of greater flexibility if it is available. Properly constituted, it is disallowable and therefore the parliament can have its say in the appropriate place to allow these services to get on and do their job unhindered and to be as flexible as they can. So I commend that approach.

I just make a point, though, that there is another particular area, and that is in subsection 3(b). There is a question of having guaranteed access to spectrum for these authorities. The one point I would note is that near Mandurah there is a radio short-wave transmission tower which we used to own but which was sold to a private company. I would not guarantee this forever. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to speak on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, which makes minor but crucial changes to a raft of acts, including the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999. As the previous speaker said, there is a raft of issues in this and we cannot speak to all of them, but some of these amendments have subtle overarching national security implications which are of specific interest to me. I find the amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 particularly relevant in this day and age. Schedule 2 of the bill contains provision for the exempting of certain documents related to online services from the application of the Freedom of Information Act 1982.

speech.para: These documents are related to the administration of schedule 5 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. Under the provisions of the amendment, specific material likely to contain either offensive content which is the subject of a complaint to the ABA or information that would enable people to access such material on the Internet will be exempt under the operations of the Freedom of Information Act. Such material and documents relate to categories of Internet content which are prohibited. Such material includes: material containing detailed instructions in crime, violence or drugs use; child pornography; bestiality; excessively violent or sexually violent material—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.
(Mr Barresi)—Order! A quorum not being present, the House stands suspended for five minutes.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.06 p.m. to 6.11 p.m.
The House having been counted and a quorum being present—

talk.start.para: —When I was interrupted, I was talking about the five types of matters that are going to be prohibited on the Internet by this bill. The fifth of those is the real depiction of sexual activity. These amendments have far-reaching implications in terms of both our national security and individual mores. In the year 2000-01, the Commonwealth's first year of censoring, the ABA investigated 550 complaints about Internet content. Investigations showed a full 393 items should not have been available to Australian web surfers, with upwards of a staggering 70 per cent involving child pornography or paedophilia. In that time frame, the ABA also ordered Internet providers to block 104 items of Australian content. The conditions for pornography are that the material tends to deprave or corrupt, that it is a danger in the hands of the young or the unwitting, and that it grievously offends community standards. The material we are talking about today offends all three conditions.

speech.para: On 3 March, following the release of a study by the Australia Institute, we saw a wide-ranging report about teenagers accidentally accessing pornographic web sites. The report's author, the Australian National University's Michael Flood, spoke of his great concern that young Australians were not sufficiently protected from violent images on the Internet. His study involved Newspoll interviewing 16- and 17-year-olds and it pointed towards such web sites being emotionally disturbing to young people. He also expressed a belief that exposure to pornography, especially violent and extreme pornography, will inform young men of the belief that it is okay to pressure a young girl to have sex.

In fact, the study, entitled Regulating youth access to pornography, found that 84 per cent of boys and 60 per cent of girls under the age of 18 say that they have been exposed accidentally to sex sites on the Internet. Indeed, the Australia Institute's director, Clive Hamilton, has urged the government to tighten controls for the sake of teenagers and their families. I note my colleague the member for Page has publicly expressed his support for such measures. A summary in the study says:

quote.para: It would be futile to attempt to use a censorship classification system to address these broader aspects of gender relations in Australian society. However, there may well be a need to develop and apply additional enforcement of existing laws.

speech.para: Of course, the opposition and our civil libertarian friends weighed into the debate, talking about user responsibilities and freedom of choice. But we are talking about young, impressionable people—the future of our country. Don't they deserve some measure of protection from the predators who lurk in cyberspace? The opposition communications spokeswoman, Kate Lundy, says that Labor will not support any greater restrictions on Internet content. I have a great deal of respect for Senator Lundy, but I think this decision is unfortunate. I appeal to my Labor colleagues to reconsider their position. This is far too important a matter for political dogma. I quote from the ABC's web site, as recently as 3½ weeks ago, on the Labor position:

quote.para: The most effective approach to reduce young people's exposure to sexually explicit material and unwanted material on the Internet is to educate those end users themselves.

speech.para: That is an unduly optimistic, if not a rose-coloured glasses approach. Do we want our children and our grandchildren to learn of such acts by stumbling across them on a depraved web site? Young people are inherently curious; they are also computer adept. It is very difficult to convey to a child in descriptive terms concepts such as bestiality, pornography and sexual violence. It is trite to allow a cyber regime where depraved material is freely available and to then hope that somehow you can create an environment in which children will be as all-knowing as to understand it and then reject it. How can children who do not know about those concepts unless they are described to them in intimate detail know to reject them? I may be naive, but have we seriously abandoned our belief in the innocence of children? Have we given up? Have we said: it is all too hard; we cannot stop it? Have we presumed that if we tell our kids all about it then miraculously they will be protected because we told them about it? It just does not follow. To suggest that is dangerous and palpable nonsense.

Quite rightly, the community are on guard against paedophilia. We abhor the abuse of children and under-age teenagers. We have a raft of safety measures in place to shield those young people from potential predators and dangerous situations. For example, teaching staff, before entering schools, require clearance. In some instances, state governments not only require their agencies to give that clearance; they also require printed material to be presented attesting to the person's suitability to enter a classroom. People who work with youth groups, scouts and girl guides and people who are involved in the supervision of sport or recreation now require clearance.

It seems to me wholly and totally inconsistent to go to these lengths to protect children from the moral corruption of potential predators who would abuse their bodies while we allow open slather through the Internet to those who would corrupt their minds. The two things are inconsistent. You cannot on the one hand say, `We've got to protect them to the nth degree,' and on the other hand say, `But it's open slather on the Internet.' It is disingenuous to suggest that you can have both, and I appeal to the Labor Party to reconsider their stance on the matter. Even the Australian Council of Civil Liberties says that 16- and 17-year-olds should have the right to decide what they view on the World Wide Web. If this is the case then I believe I am doing the right thing by standing up and denouncing such nonsense. The head of the Queensland Council of Civil Liberties, Terry O'Gorman—for whom, I might say, I have a great deal of respect—says that `there should be no further censorship until we can clearly prove that the current laws are not working'. (Quorum formed) We should not allow that degree of latitude to potential predators, whether they be on the Internet or elsewhere. Here we have an authoritative study which proves that a huge number of young Australians are being assaulted by offensive if not depraved material when they surf the Web, yet our civil libertarian leaders say that they need further evidence that tighter restrictions are needed. This government will not wait to act on the problem. We prefer to act now and we prefer to act decisively.

The current legislation allows for media promoting child pornography and paedophilia to be removed from the Internet. Without this amendment, any individual can, under the Freedom of Information Act, access that material. Quite frankly, that is a senseless anomaly, and the amendment will remove it from the act.

In addition, this amendment bill relates directly to the horrific and tragic events which recently unfolded in Bali, where around 180 people were killed in a well-planned series of bomb attacks. (Quorum formed) The point I am making is that this does not just apply to paedophilia on the Internet; it also applies to things that are freely available, like cocktail recipes for making bombs. For example, the sort of bomb that was used in the Bali bombing is a relatively simple one that uses ammonium nitrate, which is commonly found in fertilisers. Instructions to make a creation like this should not be allowed to be freely available on the Internet.

I also make the point that any effort to rid cyberspace of this potentially lethal information by removing it from the Internet is negated if the information is then freely available under the Freedom of Information Act. That is what this bill seeks to address. I commend this measure and a lot of other sensible measures in the bill that I was not able to discuss. They are important measures and I commend them to the House.

talk.start.para: —The main provisions in schedules 1, 3, 4 and 5 of the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 are non-controversial and have the support of the opposition.
(Mr Barresi)—Order! Could those members not wishing to remain in the chamber please leave quietly.

—It was nice to have an audience, Mr Deputy Speaker! Unfortunately, we on this side of the House cannot support schedule 2 of the bill, as it only highlights the government's unsuccessful and incompetent Internet censorship regime. The effect of schedule 2 would be to afford four agencies—the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the Office of Film and Literature Classification, the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board—a blanket exemption from FOI documents that contain or facilitate access to offensive Internet content within the meaning of the BSA.

speech.para: Labor oppose schedule 2 and support the second reading amendment moved in the Senate, which condemns the government for attempting to prevent scrutiny of government decisions to censor the Internet and to cover up, but not fix, flaws in the government's online content regime. I will be saying more about schedule 2 later on during this debate. Later I will also address schedule 4 as it relates to the installation of telecommunications facilities, specifically low-impact facilities—an issue that concerns many constituents in my electorate of Lowe. It was the subject of two petitions that I tabled in the House of Representatives because of the concerns of my constituents about the positioning of these low-impact facilities without proper consultation. Everyone accepts that we need mobile phones, but people are very concerned about the location of these towers. I will say more about that later.

Schedule 2 is a technical amendment that will improve the ability of the Australian Communications Authority to make written determinations under the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997—that is, written determinations to define expressions used in its legal instruments. As I mentioned, this is a technical amendment, and, for the benefit of members of the government, I can say that this is one part of the schedule that we support.

I will leave schedule 2 for the moment and talk about schedule 3, because the proposed amendments contained in schedule 3 of the bill will allow the Australian Communications Authority to exempt certain law enforcement and anticorruption bodies from the operation of the Radiocommunications Act, dealing with unlicensed transmissions, equipment standards and interference emissions. This will permit Commonwealth, state and territory law enforcement and anticorruption bodies to use licensed radio communication devices for covert surveillance to gather evidence in serious criminal anticorruption investigations. In other words, specified bodies will be able to lawfully operate covert surveillance devices for the specified purpose of investigating serious crime or corruption.

I am sure that this will enable law enforcement agencies to build, in the public interest, cases against all kinds of corrupt groups and individuals. Take, for example, the case of the former senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, who has 28 charges outstanding for defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts.

talk.start.para: —Shocking!

—The member for Werriwa is right. I have been speaking in this House about the case of Dr Colston and putting questions on the Notice Paper for about four years. That is a matter, like this, that goes to the heart of the public interest, because the Attorney-General is doing nothing to get the DPP to finalise the matter. It is a very serious matter.
—Shame!
—That is right. How many more reviews and medical examinations does Dr Colston have to go through to establish his fitness to stand trial on rorting the Commonwealth?
—He's one of yours; you trained him in the ALP.
—I do not know about that, Member for Dawson.
—The member for Lowe will resist responding to interjections.

—I cannot help it, because the case of former senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston reflects very poorly on Labor. It is, like this legislation, something that goes to the heart of the public interest. Four years ago, two eminent medical specialists said that he had only months to live—
—He was a Labor senator for 20 years.
—We know he was a Labor senator for 20 years; that did not stop him flying around the countryside on 16 aeroplane trips between July 1999 and May 2002.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.30 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Prior to the suspension I was speaking about a matter germane to the public interest, and the member for Boothby interrupted. I was specifically talking about former senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston. The member for Boothby correctly made the point that Dr Colston was a Labor senator at the time of the then Labor government and, when we went out of government, a Labor opposition senator. I need to respond to that interjection, because it was the government that pushed Dr Colston's snout further into the trough, even to the point of putting two trotters in there. He continued to fly around the countryside for a long time after independent expert medical specialists said he was terminally ill and only had months to live—at taxpayers' expense. He was also living at taxpayers' expense with regard to motor vehicle transport. This case is a shocking assault on the public interest. Dr Colston is defying medical science and making a mockery of the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions and a mockery of medical science. Obviously something has to be done about it. It seems nothing is being done about it. It is a matter that goes to the heart of the public interest. I would like to take this opportunity tonight to tell the Attorney-General, again, to get on to the Director of Public Prosecutions and make sure that this matter is resolved.

speech.para: How many more medical examinations by independent experts are needed? We are into the third review. It has taken nine months of medical experts, and they cannot even determine the status of his health and his capacity to stand trial on 28 charges of fraudulent use of his travel allowance. I happen to know something about that, because I have all the files on this case. We want to give Dr Colston the opportunity to have his day in court, because he was in his home city of Brisbane and allegedly claiming an enormous amount of travel allowance using Comcars in other states at the same time. This happened repeatedly. People know that this needs to be tested in the court and resolved. I think it is about time the government did something about this case because it stinks, and it gives us all a bad reputation.

I have said here many times in this House that I do not wish ill of Dr Colston. That is the truth—I do not. But he was found back in May 1999, by two independent expert medical specialists, only to have months to live. In that time he has had 16 interstate, taxpayer funded aeroplane trips with his gold card and 27 motor vehicle trips. There have been numerous other citings of his activities that bring into serious question his alleged state of health. If he and his family want to clear this matter up, you would think he would make himself available. I will stop speaking about this case if the so-called independent expert medical specialists resolve the matter and say that he actually does only have months to live, that he is terminally ill and that he is not fit to stand trial on these 28 very serious charges, which go to the heart of the public interest.

If protecting Commonwealth revenue is not in the public interest then I seriously do not know what is. I cannot understand why the Attorney-General is not doing more to get the DPP to resolve this. I have 12 questions outstanding on the Notice Paper that flow from the numerous questions that I have raised in this House over a period of four years on the status of Dr Colston's health. If he is well enough to fly interstate at taxpayers' expense, and he is well enough to catch Comcars at taxpayers' expense, one could reasonably expect that he is capable of sitting in a courtroom to give evidence and answer these very serious charges—yet nothing seems to happen. It is just astonishing, astounding and amazing to think that, after nine months and a third review, there is no resolution as to the status of his health. I cannot remember how many questions I have asked about this case.

talk.start.para: —How long since they've been answered?

—The last lot went on the first Notice Paper this year, and there has not been one response from the Attorney-General—not one. I would have thought that if Dr Colston, Mrs Colston and his sons thought he was as seriously ill as he is supposed to be, he would be only too happy to make himself available for the most rigorous medical scrutiny to establish the state of his health. But nothing has happened. Nothing. There has been a deafening silence from the Director of Public Prosecutions. There has been a deafening silence this year from the Attorney-General. Nothing. Nothing. Nothing.

speech.para: How long is this going to go on? When are we going to get answers? As I have said many times in this House, if it can be shown that Dr Colston is as seriously ill as he was supposed to be back in May 1999 when, I repeat, independent expert medical specialists—one a professor of medicine, the other a professor of surgery—said independently of one another that he had only months to live. Clearly, as I have said, Dr Colston is defying medical science. He is making a mockery of medical science, he is making a mockery of the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions and he is making a mockery of us, the parliament.

talk.start.para: —He did it for about 20 years, John.

—Yes, he did. This case, more than any other case in respect of a member of parliament, puts us all in bad odour. I think the government could do a great service to all of us by getting a quick resolution to the status of Dr Colston's health. Dr Colston is silent. I would like to know what efforts the DPP has made to establish his capacity to attend a medical examination or an assessment. How can it take nine months to resolve the status of his health when in May 1999 the independent expert medical specialists said that he had only months to live? I have asked questions on this matter and I will give the Attorney-General credit for at least answering my questions—unlike the Treasurer, who does not answer questions. At least Daryl Williams has answered the questions, but they are smoke and mirrors responses. He has indicated to me that Dr Colston had only months to live. Clearly, that points to the incompetence of the expert medical specialists who examined him back in May 1999.
(Mr Hawker)—Order! I remind the member that we are debating the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 and ask him to come back to the bill.

—I will, and thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker. I feel very passionate about this, and I went down this path because the member for Boothby interjected just before the dinner adjournment, making it quite plain that former Senator Colston was someone from our side. He certainly accelerated his benefits when the government made him Deputy President of the Senate, and I think that is a dreadful thing.

speech.para: I support schedule 3 to the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 because it will expand the objects clause of the Radiocommunications Act to ensure adequate radiofrequency spectrum is set aside for national security, law enforcement and emergency use or for use by other public and community services, all of which are in the public interest. That is what I was talking about before the dinner adjournment and before I got on to the subject of Dr Colston.

Other worthy amendments in this bill which Labor is supporting are contained in schedule 5. That part of the bill makes minor amendments to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999 dealing with: one, the National Relay Service—that is, the standard telephone service for deaf and hearing-impaired people; two, customer service guarantee standards; and, three, the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. Importantly, the TIO amendments ensure that carriers cannot on-charge consumers for TIO complaint handling fees, and they give the TIO explicit powers to investigate complaints about charges or fees not directly related to telecommunications carriage services such as early contract termination fees for mobile phone services. In addition, these amendments improve the government's ability to effectively collect NRS levy debts from carriers, and the customer service guarantee standard amendments ensure revocations or variations of customer service guarantee standards are disallowable instruments. Like schedule 1 and 3 of this bill, schedule 5 receives the opposition's support.

The opposition also supports schedule 4 of the bill. The amendment contained in schedule 4 goes to an issue of great concern to my constituents in the electorate of Lowe—that is, the installation of telecommunications facilities, otherwise known as mobile phone towers. Apart from the obvious health fears many residents hold when a mobile phone tower suddenly appears across the road from their home or their children's school, I believe this issue is not only about the level of electromagnetic radiation but also about the process of consultation with residents when these towers are to be installed. Plainly, there is very minimal consultation with regard to these low impact facilities, and there needs to be consultation and education with regard to any potential health risks that might arise from the installation of those towers.

Schedule 4 abolishes the specially constituted Australian Communications Authority from the Telecommunications Act 1997. This body was established to consider carrier applications for facilities installation permits under the act, but for the four years the specially constituted ACA has been in operation no such applications have been made. Telecommunications carriers have used alternative means such as the courts and negotiations to process facilities installation permits.

On 19 August last year, I brought to the attention of this House the serious potential health and environmental issues arising from the installation of mobile phone towers in my electorate of Lowe. Residents and small businesspeople in Wareemba, where I live, and in nearby Five Dock and Abbotsford were very angry about the installation of a so-called low impact facility by Hutchinson Telecom at 286 Great North Road, Wareemba. Local residents and businesses were not notified properly and did not have an opportunity to object on health or environmental grounds. All they got were second-hand empty assurances from the mobile phone company; I thought that was outrageous. I made representations to the ACA which revealed that the Telecommunications Act and the Telecommunications Code of Practice allows mobile phone companies to install the so-called low impact facilities without the need for a local council development application or any written notification to affected residents and local businesses.

About 1,000 people immediately responded to a petition that I took up, and I was pleased to organise subsequently for an expert from the School of Physics at the University of Sydney to come out and test the tower. The level of electromagnetic radiation from that tower was insignificant, so that was good news for the residents. But the consultation was appalling and the Labor Party will do something about that in government if the government do not make changes to improve the consultation process. It is just not good enough to say that these low impact facilities have small levels of electromagnetic radiation and not provide people with the information they deserve.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bruce Scott) adjourned.

debate.para: The following bill was returned from the Senate without amendment or request:

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to speak on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, which seeks to improve the following acts: the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications Act 1999. Quite clearly, quite a lot of acts will be affected with the passage of this bill.

speech.para: These changes relate in part to the control of illegal or offensive online material, with the bill providing a framework to give better powers to the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the ABA, on the dissemination of information. I am pleased to give my support to the latest changes in the bill, which are designed to limit certain content from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act. I believe that, in this global information age, whilst the Internet is an outstanding resource tool for information and education, we have to accept that we live in a modern and privileged world where many adults and children alike have the right to use and can use quite freely a computer. Schools believe it a fundamental right for students to have online access from early in their schooling years through to high school and university. That is absolutely right and something that I support. Such communications empower individuals to access up-to-date information.

However, there is much concern for many people within the community, including myself, who believe there are not enough boundaries to ensure illegal or offensive material does not fall into the wrong hands. We only have to stop and think about the findings of a study by Australia Institute report author Michael Flood, from the Australian National University, which were released this month and confirmed parents' worst fears: exposure of children to pornography on the Internet is an increasing problem in today's new age society. This study found that more than eight out of 10 boys aged between 16 and 17 have visited hard core pornography Internet sites and, furthermore, that 60 per cent of girls the same age had had exposure to Internet pornography. They are staggering figures and should alarm any decent person in this parliament or in Australia. Perhaps even more disturbing is the fact that almost 40 per cent of boys in that age bracket admitted to searching for explicit pornography on the Internet while around five per cent of them admitted to be weekly users of pornography. The Australian Institute said that these teenagers were exposed to sites depicting rape, sexual torture, bestiality and incest.

As a parent myself, it disturbs me that children can even have access to this sort of material, at times right under their parents' noses, without them knowing. Furthermore, similar surveys claim that regular viewing of offensive material leads to violent sexual behaviour and many other societal problems that we see today. The problems with Internet content do not end there. It is my concern that not only pornography but also acts of extreme violence are readily available at the touch of a button. That is how easy it can be to access this material. As well, it is said that you only have to ask the right source for the Internet address on how to make bombs and where to buy the right ingredients to commit another atrocity like the Bali bombings, which brought so much horror and carnage and took the innocent lives of nearly 200 people, including 88 Australians. Even as we remind ourselves of the horror of the Bali bombings, material on producing a bomb of that magnitude, where to buy the materials and how to put it together is readily available on the Internet from those people who will willingly make it available. Of course, they too are people that we should be targeting in our hunt to end international terrorism around the world.

No matter how vigilant a parent may choose to be, without proper laws governing access to explicit material, children will continue to be brainwashed by this filth and depravity. I know I do not want that to happen, I know the government does not want that to happen and I am sure all decent Australians do not want that to happen. Therefore, while current laws allow for censorship on some level, without these proposed changes to the Communication Legislation Amendments Bill, no matter what your age, you only have to send in the paperwork and under the Freedom of Information Act you get access to the information that could prove disastrous. Section 11 of the Freedom of Information Act says:

quote.para: ... every person has a legally enforceable right to obtain access ... to (a) a document of an agency ...

speech.para: This means that, even if you are 18 years or younger, from as little as $30, you are able to apply for your chosen electronic material, available from the Internet—available on your computer at the touch of a button. The government rightly refuses to stand by and watch our children be subjected to unscrupulous online operators who provide this disgusting and dangerous material through the Web to home computers—available in the lounge rooms of the suburban homes of families right around Australia—to anyone who has access to a computer network.

In addition to seeking amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the federal government has been funding a raft of initiatives to arm society—parents, in particular—with the knowledge and the know-how to promote the positive use of the Internet. For instance, in 1999, the federal government established an independent community advocacy and advisory body called Net Alert to educate people on the sensible ways to manage Internet use. Under this initiative, Net Alert works alongside industry and government to achieve safer Internet usage. Through Net Alert, teachers, parents and other concerned individuals can access information on safety tips and resources, all of which promote a safe and secure online environment.

I applaud an initiative of the Australian Broadcasting Authority known as Cybersmart Kids Online. This resource tool is an easy step-by-step guide for parents and kids to understand the need to be smart when surfing the Internet and to look out for and avoid offensive material. As well, the federal government review on the regulation of Internet content in Australia is now in progress. The review of Online Co-Regulatory Regulatory Scheme, established under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, relies on a complaints based legal regime to regulate online content. This scheme adds to this coalition government's efforts to restrict access to highly offensive, highly illegal, and dangerous content, particularly by children.

I understand the bill also includes measures to address concerns of defence, national security, law enforcement and emergency services agencies requiring future access to radio communications. We rely on these law enforcement groups to catch and prosecute those unscrupulous criminals who infiltrate the Web and corrupt our children and our fellow citizens. The bill proposes to further build on current provisions of the Radcom Act whilst acknowledging the importance of defence agencies to covertly monitor and gather evidence for criminal investigations. These changes mirror the need to update legislation to reflect the latest technological advances both within Australia and also overseas.
In terms of prosecution, the amendments include a definition of serious crime, and I welcome that. I would like to quote it for the benefit of the record:

quote.para: ... conduct that, if engaged in within, or in connection with, Australia, would constitute an offence against the law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory punishable by imprisonment for a period exceeding 12 months.

speech.para: Those who are found guilty of fraudulent or corrupt activity should be punished and should feel the full force of the law. There can be no place in Australia today for people to place on the Internet material that is going to affect our children, that is nothing more than depravity, or instructions on terrorist activities and how to make dangerous bombs. We know how that sort of material can be used by those with intentions to create havoc, as we saw in Bali, with the resultant horror caused to so many families in Australia. Furthermore, we need to better regulate the on-line environment and access to freedom of information.

While I am on the issue of communication, I would like to use this bill tonight to bring to the attention of the House a matter of concern in my own electorate—and I am sure it is of concern in other members' electorates, particularly those in country areas. I notice the member for Parkes has just come into the chamber. He may have—if he has not, I am sure he will—received calls from constituents about Telstra's Homelink plan. The Homelink plan was originally designed by Telstra for people living in rural areas. Many enjoy the benefits of Homelink today. The plan was established for children who were away from home out of necessity to gain access to education, particularly at universities or boarding schools. The plan allowed them to ring home without having to incur the burden of the cost of the call from their end.

It has come to my attention that those who have a business listing for their home phone number are unable to access Homelink. This problem would also affect people who are managing a farm business. Their children who are away at school cannot access Homelink because their home phone number is listed as a business phone number, albeit that that number is one and the same. These are people who live in isolated rural areas. My office has been in touch with Telstra Country Wide and Telstra itself. Telstra claim that those who have a business line should not expect the same benefits as those who have a residential line. I am really concerned to hear that from Telstra, because it demonstrates to me their lack of understanding of the situation of people who live in a rural environment and run a farm business. That phone number is for the main part of the operation—the farm—but it is also their private home number. You only have to live in a rural area to know that Telstra's claim is not justifiable. I believe that Telstra Country Wide has raised this issue with Telstra. Tonight I am calling on Telstra to find a solution to this problem so that those families in rural and remote properties will not encounter difficulties when trying to talk to family members who are away from home.

Homelink was designed with the intent of giving children and students who are away from their parents' home—their own home—out of necessity, to study, the ability to ring home at any time. That gives the children and the parents a sense of security. Importantly, the parents can always say to their children: `If there's anything that concerns you, ring home.' Homelink was providing that service. The hurdle we have struck here is that Telstra refuse to accept that a business number in a rural community can also be a personal home phone number. It seems a very simple proposition to fix this problem. I ask Telstra to look at it again. I reject their comments to my office that those who have business lines should not expect the same benefits as those who have a residential line.

This is a social issue, and Telstra ought to be able to fix it. It is not an issue of technology; I think it is more about a will to do it. As my colleague behind me says, this is an issue of equity for children and students from rural areas who, out of necessity, go away to gain access to education. Whether they are the children and students of families who own a business or whether they are children and students of people who manage a business on a rural property, they should have access to Homelink, which has provided so much comfort for so long to parents and children alike. I commend this bill to the House and, in concluding, ask that Telstra revisit that and correct something that I think is causing their reputation as a caring organisation a great deal of harm.
Debate (on motion by Ms Jann McFarlane) adjourned.
