talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr WILLIAMS
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: The Copyright Amendment (Parallel Importation) Bill 2002 will assist the whole Australian community to have access to world competitive software prices. The opposition has suggested that parallel importation will inevitably lead to higher piracy, but there is no such evidence that parallel importation increases piracy. Indeed, this bill incorporates substantial enforcement measures. The government's amendments strengthen the enforcement regime in the Copyright Act. The amendments are strong, balanced and effective. They place the onus on importers to prove the legitimacy of their imports. Penalties for illegal importation have been increased substantially. The difficulties in proving copyright have also been addressed and provision for additional damages has been strengthened. Further, a quicker and cheaper mechanism for copyright litigation has been established through allowing actions in the Federal Magistrates Service, and the offence of advertising infringing material has been broadened. These measures target the key areas identified by the copyright industry. On the issue of pricing, a number of factors are involved, including the value of the Australian dollar, sales, global demand and distribution arrangements. However, it is clear that over time the removal of import restrictions leads to more competitive pricing, as has been the case with sound recordings following the government's 1998 amendments to the Copyright Act.

The government has agreed to an amendment to the definition of `feature film' in the bill. Productions made for distribution for viewing by the public directly for rental or sale are also specifically included in the definition of feature film. The amendment refers to sale or rental where the primary object of the sale or rental is for viewing without `electronic interactive involvement'. These words been included to take account of the fact that, whilst DVD films, for example, do sometimes involve interactive elements, the primary reason for acquisition or rental of the DVD is to view the film, not to experience the electronic interactive elements. Such productions would therefore be included in the definition of a feature film if over 20 minutes in length. This is in contrast with a computer or video game, where the primary intention for acquisition or rental is to interact with the visual material or play the game. The reference to interactive involvement being electronic will ensure that films that include instructions for the viewer to use in undertaking some kind of activity in addition to watching—such as is the case with exercise videos—can be included within the definition of feature films.

The government is greatly disappointed that the Australian Democrats have remained opposed to parallel importation of books, periodical publications and printed music, as has the opposition. As a result, Australian students, libraries, schools, universities and all readers will continue to be subject to the whims of publishers with regard to availability and pricing of material. At least the Australian Democrats were able to recognise the merits of greater competition in the software area. Labor's `use it or lose it' policy favours minority interests—in this case, foreign multinational software producers—over the larger interest—consumers of packaged business software, including Australian small and medium-sized businesses, local software developers and e-commerce businesses. Thanks to the government's commitment to this legislation and the Democrats willingness to compromise, Australian consumers as net importers of copyright material will reap some of the important benefits this legislation will bring.

talk.start.para: —Just briefly, the opposition opposes the motion. We believe that the amendments agreed to in the Senate are not appropriate. Essentially, however, the proof of the pie is going to be in the eating. We believe that the removal of these parallel importation restrictions will in fact open up the software and computer games sector to a greater incidence of pirates bringing in illegal copies. We are concerned that the practices that are adopted in Australia, for instance, in respect of the voluntary censorship of material will not be able to be implemented as a result of imported material coming in without that goodwill from the industry. We are also very concerned about the enhanced protections, as they have been called, against copyright. We recognise there are some recommendations that have been drawn on, as the government says, from the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The report, called Cracking down on copycats: enforcement of copyright in Australia, was really quite sophisticated, but by no means has the government adopted all of those recommendations.

speech.para: Piracy in this industry, as well as in respect of the music industry, is a serious concern. There are all kinds of indications that organised crime is involved; it is not simply something done by adolescents in backyards. The opposition are committed to eradication of piracy. We believe the removal of the parallel importation restrictions will open that up and we believe that the protections—as the quid pro quo, I suppose—introduced in the legislation do not go nearly far enough. But, again, we say that the proof of the pie is going to be in the eating and we call on the government to keep this issue under careful review, otherwise it could very quickly get out of hand.
Question agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to discuss the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. This bill essentially contains five schedules. Four of these are legitimate technical improvements of current federal communications legislation, which I will briefly summarise. However, before I do, I would like to take issue with the comments made by the member for Hinkler in his contribution earlier in this debate. The arguments presented by the member for Hinkler were shallow and superficial, just like the efforts of this government in the area of Internet pornography. I am glad the member for Hinkler has made these comments; it gives me an opportunity to educate him and other members opposite about the total failure of the government to make any significant impact in protecting us from this type of material. Unlike the member for Hinkler, I will relate a real life case to the House and demonstrate just how hypocritical the hollow rhetoric we heard earlier really is. I will show the House just how committed the ministers of this government are to applying the arguments of the member for Hinkler. They are so committed that it has taken three months since my representations to the minister to provide my constituent with absolutely nothing—no response at all. This inaction just shows what a shameless beat-up the contribution of the member for Hinkler really was. But back to the bill.

speech.para: The first provision will effectively enhance the Australian Communications Authority's ability to provide written determinations defining expressions used in its legal instruments. This amendment is logical as it saves time and allows the ACA to get down to more serious matters rather than dealing with administrative difficulties. The third schedule, too, makes sense. This amendment allows for law enforcement bodies of either a Commonwealth or state origin to perform covert legal surveillance involving radio transmissions. The situation we currently experience is unworkable, and law enforcement officials rightfully have an expectation that every aspect of their work is considered legal in this country. To not introduce this amendment would be a hindrance to the dedicated people in Australian policing and law enforcement.

Schedule 4 simply ties up a loose end or, more specifically, ends the specially constituted Australian Communications Authority. In four years of operation, this organisation has not considered one carrier installation permit—its intended purpose. Removing this from Australian law is bland but necessary housekeeping. Finally, the fifth amendment deals with the role of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman and expands the position's powers slightly. This too makes sense, and I take no issue with it.

However, buried within this bill lies the second schedule—a crude attempt by the Howard government to cover its tracks in terms of Internet policy. The schedule exempts four government agencies from the Freedom of Information Act 1982: the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the Office of Film and Literature Classification, the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board. Should this bill be passed, a blanket FOI exemption is made for documents containing or information facilitating `offensive Internet content'. In short, this is appalling. Labor has strong concerns about the implications of this bill should it become law. The explanatory memorandum claims that FOI requests made for documents that enable access to a site containing offensive content frustrate the agencies specified in this bill. While I have every interest in the smooth operation of these agencies, I believe that this reasoning is nothing beyond a cop-out.

The real agenda here is the Howard government covering its own tracks. These agencies, with a particular emphasis on the ABA, have been key players in the implementation of the Howard government Internet censorship regime. Since its introduction, the regime has succeeded in not much more than pushing sites of inappropriate content overseas and further out of governmental control. This regime always has been and always will be unworkable. Labor opposed it upon introduction in 1999 and opposes it now. The best the Howard government can do to address the problem is to try to block the relevant information, rather than to fix the problem. The Howard government is treating the Australian Internet community with utter contempt if this schedule is adopted.

It comes as no surprise to me that the government is trying to block public scrutiny of this issue, as I have personally experienced the fumbling about that has come to symbolise the government's approach to Internet censorship. I hope that the member for Hinkler listens to this constituent's story and feels embarrassed about his earlier remarks. One of my constituents, Wendy Charnell, came to me late last year with a very serious problem in this area. In the months prior to contacting my office, Ms Charnell had received unsolicited child pornography in her electronic mail. These emails arrived almost daily and contained images and links to images of children being abused sexually and subjected to disgusting pornographic acts. Despite my constituent's efforts to unsubscribe to the self-described `service', the emails continued to arrive regularly.

Ms Charnell, alarmed by the material, approached iiNet, her Internet service provider, one of the largest carriers of home-users in Western Australia. After sharing her problem with the firm, they informed her that they would not filter her email from the material as it was not their legal obligation. She then approached the Western Australian Police Service to complain, without success. At this point the constituent, somewhat bewildered, approached my office. I believe that she is one of thousands of people in Australia who are in this awkward situation. Possession of child pornography is a serious crime, and rightfully so. If a law enforcement officer accessed the constituent's computer, Ms Charnell would be charged. In Western Australia, she could be imprisoned for five years. However, the ISP she pays to use would not be charged. Despite her efforts to prevent the flow of illegal material to her, Ms Charnell would still be chargeable under law.

The standard Howard government approach to Internet censorship dictates that any Internet sites deemed to have inappropriate material will be issued with a take-down notice. How does this help Ms Charnell? The emails, images and sites that are being emailed to her all originate overseas. Instead of a solution to her problem, Ms Charnell is left with the possibility of being charged for having—to quote the unsolicited emails—`real underage material', `nude little girls' and `rape' images. Understandably, Ms Charnell was worried about the situation. To address her concerns, I wrote on her behalf to the Attorney-General's office outlining this serious problem. The letter, dated 17 December 2002, did not receive attention from the Attorney-General's office until 22 January 2003. The letter my office received in response indicated that the matter was being forwarded on to the Hon. Senator Richard Alston's office, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Let me reiterate that point. It took the Attorney-General's office over a month to respond and, in doing so, it decided that passing the buck was the most appropriate reaction to that situation. It took over a month to do nothing.

As I stand here—in March—I still await a response from the minister for communications. This is beyond belief. My office has been hounding the minister's office for the past three weeks for a reply but with no luck. My constituent is obviously distressed about her legal status. We live in one of the most Internet aware nations in the world, yet our legislation is inconsistent and full of holes. Five states or territories do not discriminate between possession and knowing possession of child pornography. Western Australia had a case go through the Supreme Court in 2001 that has provided some guidance, but Ms Charnell could be hauled through the legal system and have to prove that she did not solicit this material. Looking at her temporary Internet files would show that these files had been opened, and she would have to prove that she had not accessed this material willingly—a hardworking 61-year-old woman forced to prove she is not a pervert because of amateur policy making. This is a nationwide problem. Should my constituent cross the Nullarbor, she would be charged immediately in South Australia, New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Intent does not matter here.

I cannot believe this matter was forwarded from the Attorney-General's office. To state that this is not a legal matter is contrived and plain incorrect. The only solution here is standardisation. The Internet is a borderless medium. It is not slowed down by boundaries, be they geographical, political or anything else. I challenge any member of the government to stand up and say that they have never received unsolicited emails in their time as an Internet user. However, the government's inability to create a national standard on this matter suggests that they feel unsolicited illegal material cannot be emailed by these indecent people. Either force all carriers of data in Australia to try to filter email flow at a user's request or standardise the law to protect people like Ms Charnell.

We must remember that right now these holes not only endanger the innocent but also create attractive opportunities for those who willingly acquire child pornography. If an offender of this nature sees a legal precedent set in some states but not in others, surely this would present itself as an attractive means of circulating this disturbing material. The onus is upon the federal government to plug this leak. There must be people all over Australia like my constituent not wanting to speak out for fear of prosecution, waiting for something to be done. And while the various ministerial offices bounce letters from one to another, refusing to confront the issue, people like Ms Charnell continue to wait in fear.

Ms Charnell's problem is indicative of the government's contempt for serious Internet policy. Instead of sitting down and designing regimes that will actually fix the problem, this government has decided it would be easier to simply block the flow of information about the problem. The Labor Party vehemently disagrees with this gagging of agencies funded by taxpayers. I would like to remind Prime Minister Howard and Minister Alston that the ABA, the OFLC, the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board are agencies paid for by Australian citizens. Taxpayers, like any other form of consumer, have the right to see how their money is spent. The successful passage of this bill would ensure that, when it comes to the Internet, the taxpayer no longer has the right to know what the government will and will not let them see. Because of the disregard demonstrated by this government, people like Ms Charnell will not have their problems solved.

As it currently stands, FOI requests can be rejected by the ABA and the other agencies on a case by case basis. These decisions can be appealed through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I believe that this is a perfectly legitimate means of protecting sensitive information. If, in any case, release of information pertaining to offensive material should inhibit one of these agencies from doing its job, then by all means block the FOI request. However, to give a blanket exemption to the peak Internet censorship bodies is to allow them to be unaccountable.

I am not saying anything the Howard government has not already heard. One of the major Internet users groups in this country, Electronic Frontiers Australia, has been raising this matter with the government for a long time. However, these concerns are falling on seemingly deaf ears. I quote the Chairman of EFA, Irene Graham, who said:

quote.para: It is disgraceful that the law fails to take into account the nature of the technology and so fails to protect ordinary Internet users from criminal proceedings concerning events that are beyond their control.

speech.para: And what does the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts have to say about the organisation? In November 2002, he said, `We gave up on them a long time ago.' In reply, I say this to the Howard government: you gave up on the Internet a long time ago.

We on this side of the House refuse to give up on solving the problems of new mediums. Let us take advantage of what accountability is left in the Australian Internet censorship regime and use it to build credible processes and create a system of censorship that actually works. Instead of passing the buck and pushing offenders and viewable content offshore, let us work on getting the job done and eliminating illegal material. The poor policy making that continues to hinder the Internet in Australia must come to an end. The Labor Party is committed to a communications policy which would not legally strangle innocent Internet users and citizens but which would efficiently deal with the issue of censorship. How can Australia possibly be expected to continue as a leader in technology development and implementation when we have patchy laws that muddy the waters? Instead of trying to blindfold the Australian public, I implore the government to come up with real solutions.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. When is enough enough? Ours is an information age, and when it comes to accessing information we are spoilt for choice. The Internet provides a virtual world at our fingertips and it has allowed our society to progress in ways that we never dreamed were possible. It has opened our eyes to the world and bridged the tyranny of distance for many communities. But everything comes at a price.

speech.para: Wherever there is a means of transmitting information to the mass population, there are bound to be people ready to exploit it—and exploit it they have. The agency CHILD WISE suggest that child pornography is becoming increasingly linked to the Internet, which provides new means to produce and distribute images secretly and globally. They also suggest:
· More offenders are seeking out new destinations for child sex tourism.
· More offenders are sexually exploiting children through the Internet by luring children, exchanging information and distributing child pornography.
· More children and young people in developed countries are exchanging sex for survival.
· More children are being trafficked across new routes, borders and between continents.

Child pornography and child sex tourism is not a new concept, and I am certainly not suggesting that it has been created out of the Internet age. But the facts are the Internet age is making it far easier for people who thrive on child pornography and prey on young children to find one another. It creates a means for paedophiles and would-be traffickers to create clandestine networks. It allows for the easy distribution of sexual material and the exploitation of innocent children. What price do we have to pay for complete freedom of information? Is a child's life or a child's innocence worth this democratic right? Where is the line drawn between freedom of information and the gross violation of a child's rights?

The Communication Legislation Amendment Bill 2002 proposes that specific material likely to contain offensive content which is the subject of a complaint to the ABA or information which would enable people to access such material on the Internet will be exempted from the operations of the Freedom of Information Act. There is a great argument that censorship should be at the user level and that we should leave it up to the individual to be proactive, to monitor the material accessed on their computer and to purchase equipment to block certain offensive materials. Critics say the solution is to educate people: to educate kids at school about Internet use and the effects of pornography, and to educate parents on how to control what their kids see.

I am all for education but I see a giant loophole in this suggestion. Once again it is left up to the individual to be part of an educational program. Busy parents do not always have or take the time to monitor what their children are doing, let alone be part of an educational campaign that teaches them how to monitor what their children are accessing. Like TV, the Internet can become a babysitting service. In an environment where both parents work long hours and come home to domestic chores in the evening, children can be left, rightly or wrongly, surfing the net without supervision. Children are curious by nature, and this leaves them wide open to stumble across a world of seedy information and images.

It is true that parents have the option of limiting what their children can access when they choose to connect to an Internet service provider. But many parents are not computer literate and are not even aware of what is out there on the World Wide Web. Many parents do not know enough to ask about blocking devices. I must say I am sick to death of the argument that it is too hard to regulate the Internet. People say, `It is an impossible task; it is a pipedream.' That is rubbish. I would rather be part of a government that works to overcome the so-called impossible than bury my head in the sand with the Labor Party and the civil libertarians.

A study by the Australia Institute concluded that young Australians were not sufficiently protected from violent images on the Internet. The study by Michael Flood involved Newspoll interviewing 16- and 17-year-olds and pointed towards violent images being emotionally disturbing to young people. He expressed the belief that exposure to pornography—especially violent and extreme pornography—will inform young men of the belief that it is okay to pressure a young girl. The study, called Regulating youth access to pornography, found that 84 per cent of boys and 60 per cent of girls under the age of 18 say they have been exposed accidentally to sex sites on the Internet.

Almost every form of communication in the world is regulated to some degree. We are told what to expect from a movie. We have the right to choose a movie that is suitable in relation to the age of our child. With respect to our children witnessing violence, harsh language or sex scenes, we are informed whether the movie contains these things and have the option not to allow them to watch it. Television shows also give us these warnings. Violent, sexually explicit movies are toned down for television viewing and aired later in evening. News programs warn us if a story contains violent scenes and we can choose to switch them off. To an extent we can regulate that which our children see. But the Internet is not a familiar concept to many parents. There are very few occasions where a parent views Internet material with their children. Mostly kids are left to their own devices to conduct research, send emails and surf the Net. Let us help parents to protect their children. If this bill offends a few civil libertarians and freedom of information activists, it is a very small price to pay. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 makes a series of minor amendments to the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Radiocommunications Act 1992, the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Act 1999.

speech.para: Schedule 1 to the bill makes an amendment to the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997 to enhance the operation of section 54 of that act. Section 54 empowers the Australian Communications Authority to make a written determination defining expressions used in its legal instruments. Due to the effect of sections 46A and 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, the ACA cannot apply, adopt or incorporate certain documents including legal instruments within a determination made under section 54 of the ACA Act 1997.

The proposed amendment contained in schedule 1 to the bill will allow the ACA to incorporate other documents by reference when making a written determination under section 54 and, in doing so, will make section 54 consistent with the existing determination powers under the Telecommunications Act 1997 and the Radiocommunications Act 1992.

Schedule 2 to the bill also makes a number of amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 to exempt from the application of that act certain documents related to the administration of schedule 5 to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. Schedule 5 to the Broadcasting Services Act, which has operated since 1 January 2000, provides the regulatory framework for the control of illegal or offensive online material. This framework enables the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) to investigate complaints from the public about online content, including material that is, or would be, refused classification or classified X by the classification board.

Since the release of material acquired during the course of an ABA investigation would undermine the policy and objects of the framework, it has become necessary to ensure that such material in the possession of the ABA is adequately protected. Once material is released under the FOI Act, the subsequent use or dissemination of that material cannot be controlled. The amendment contained in schedule 2 to the bill will ensure that material containing prohibited, or potentially prohibited, online content or the means of accessing such content is specifically exempt from disclosure under the FOI Act.

Schedule 3 to the bill makes a number of amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1992 in relation to law enforcement bodies. Commonwealth, state and territory law enforcement and anticorruption bodies use licensed radiocommunications devices for covert surveillance to gather evidence in serious criminal and anticorruption investigations. Covert surveillance devices are usually operated under warrants issued by Commonwealth, state or territory courts and for evidentiary value must also be properly licensed under the Radiocommunications Act.

The proposed amendments contained in schedule 3 to the bill will enable the ACA, by disallowable instrument, to exempt the personnel of certain law enforcement and anticorruption bodies from the operation of some sections of the Radiocommunications Act dealing with unlicensed transmissions, equipment standards and interference emissions. These bodies do not fall within the traditional definition of a `police force'.

talk.start.para: —The Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 contains a number of provisions, most of which we support. They are noncontroversial, they do improve the operations of the legislation and, for those reasons, we think they are a pretty good idea. Schedules 1, 3, 4, 5 and 6 therefore enjoy the support of the opposition, but schedule 2 has been controversial and the subject of most of the debate on this bill.

speech.para: Schedule 2 amends the Freedom of Information Act to exempt four agencies from freedom of information requests in relation to certain documents containing offensive Internet content. The problem that we have with it is that it is a blanket exemption from the FOI legislation. It continues the trend of this government to draw back from the FOI legislation that was implemented by previous Labor governments, which was a genuine attempt to provide access to the general public to documents that governments hold, so that people can be better informed and understand what is going on in terms of the internal processes of government and the basis on which decisions have been made.

I want to place on record my objection to any offensive Internet content. I think everyone on this side of the House would join with the government in saying that we should do everything we reasonably can to stop offensive Internet content from being made available, particularly to young people, or minors, in this country. But the government, in trying to achieve that, has not done it very well. The effect, for example, of schedule 2 to this bill would be to prevent any public scrutiny through FOI of various agencies' Internet censorship roles. So, if the schedule were enacted, there would be no way at all to access the material on which an agency based a censorship decision in order to challenge the lawfulness or reasonableness of that decision. The point is that it would cover up but not fix flaws in the government's online content regime. That is why we are objecting to schedule 2 to the bill.

If the government have evidence that the FOI Act is being abused, then fine, they should produce it. But it is certainly not apparent, from the one and only FOI request each agency has received in three years, that this is actually a problem. We are left to suspect that this is just another example of the government winding back the operation and the effectiveness of FOI legislation. Those concerns are compounded by the retrospective operation of this legislation.

Here is a government that objects very strongly to—and I see my colleague the member for Kingston is here, who has a long and proud history in cracking down on tax avoidance—and rejected time and time again when Labor was in office, any attempts to crack down on tax avoidance where it has any retrospective impact. But that objection to retrospective legislation has really been abandoned here because this particular schedule, schedule 2, would in fact have retrospective operation. So our concern fundamentally is that this legislation winds back, yet again, the FOI legislation that was implemented by previous Labor governments. I have had some unfortunate and recent experiences with the government's treatment of FOI legislation and its interpretation. It is for that reason that I support the second reading amendment to this legislation, which says:
whilst not denying the Bill a second reading, the House:

(1) expresses its strong objection to the fact that the Bill seriously undermines the Freedom of Information Act by exempting certain documents created with respect to decisions regarding offensive Internet content by the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the Office of Film and Literature Classification, the Classification Board and the Classification Review Board, from the scope of the FOI Act; and

(2) notes that this removal of FOI scrutiny will seriously undermine the level of transparency and accountability of the decision-making processes of these agencies and that the Government is seeking to disguise the fact that its attempts to censor the Internet have proved ineffectual.

So, in speaking to that second reading amendment, I lament the successive winding back of the operations of the FOI legislation under this government. My most recent experiences are in relation to an application under FOI to obtain a suppressed report, produced by ACIL, into the US-Australia free trade agreement. I will not go into great detail about this other than to point out that that report was suppressed. When I applied under FOI, the government used every day that it had under the legislation—30 days and then another 30 days—to reach a decision that denied me access to the report. I was reassured that if I objected to the decision that was made I could apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, if I could find $574, for a review of that decision. So the government used every day that it possibly could, and every dollar that it possibly could, to deny the opposition and the Australian people access to that report. The fact is that the report was finally leaked and the government's efforts to thwart the operation of FOI legislation were finally defeated. But that is just one example.

Another example is that I applied under freedom of information legislation for the requests that had been made of Australia by 22 countries in relation to the General Agreement on Trade in Services. I have a lengthy tome here from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade explaining why the government denied FOI access—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We have been fairly tolerant in allowing the member opposite to range across FOI issues, but they have to relate to the legislation before the House, which deals with content regulation online.
(Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Rankin would be aware that he has to speak to the bill before the House, and I ask him to tie his remarks to that bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your guidance. I do, in fact, speak to the second reading amendment, of which the minister may be unaware, so I will reinform him of the content of that second reading amendment, which says:

speech.para: whilst not denying the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) expresses its strong objection to the fact that the Bill seriously undermines the Freedom of Information Act...

So I am speaking to the second reading amendment, and I would appreciate your assistance, Mr Deputy Speaker, in ensuring that we do not get such frivolous objections in the future. I think that there is a compelling case for this government to be far more open in what it does and what it says. Certainly, I think there is a case for the government to reveal what it has had to say—and I am now referring to the Prime Minister's own circumstances that are covered in a number of articles that emanated from a dinner at the Lodge on 19 February. I am seriously inclined to apply under FOI legislation for details of that particular dinner, because I know that invited to the dinner were three journalists from News Limited: Dennis Shanahan, Glenn Milne and Malcolm Farr.

talk.start.para: —I am finding it very difficult to see how this relates to the bill.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker; I am getting to that. It has been suggested that at that dinner there was a discussion about the operation of the freedom of information legislation. I was not there. I did not get invited; a number of staff members did. I am reliably told that at that dinner the Prime Minister briefed these three journalists—Glenn Milne, Dennis Shanahan and Malcolm Farr—on matters that were pertinent to the future course of the government. I am now seriously contemplating applying under FOI legislation for details of the diary to see which other journalists were there, although I do know that all were from News Limited. There were none from Fairfax, of course.

speech.para: The purpose of the dinner was to inform these three journalists that the Prime Minister was batting on beyond his 64th birthday, and he did so. He did not want to sell the Treasurer, Peter Costello, this message directly, so he thought that he would get these three journalists to do it for him.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order going to relevance. The honourable member is testing the patience of the House. He is speaking to the second reading amendment; that makes his comments regarding FOI and the legislation before the House even more narrow than in a speech in the second reading debate. There are many other forums in which to raise these issues. Please do not take my intervention as anything to be concerned about, except that the time of the House is being wasted. We need to get back to this important legislation.

—I think the member for Rankin made it very clear that the second reading amendment allowed him to talk about FOI. I would ask him, if he is going to continue in the same vein, to link it back to FOI.

—One of the matters discussed was paid maternity leave, and one of the three journalists subsequently wrote about paid maternity leave. It was discussed at the dinner and subsequently the journalist dutifully reported it, on great authority from the Prime Minister. I indicate that I will be applying under FOI legislation for the relevant documents. The point is that the Prime Minister got these three journalists together—all from News Limited; none from Fairfax—to advise them that he was not going to announce on his birthday his retirement or his plans. He wanted them to go into the public domain with this so as to facilitate smoothing over the problems that he was going to have with the Treasurer—and they did so. Mr Dennis Shanahan said on Friday, 21 February—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on the same point of order that I raised previously. I seek your ruling on this issue. Is the member being relevant to the legislation?
—I have to overrule the minister and say that there is no point of order, because it is being tied back to FOI and the second reading amendment did mention the FOI legislation.
—The Prime Minister had this dinner with these three journalists. I can point out, by referring to the public record, that Mr Dennis Shanahan dutifully wrote on 21 February:

quote.para: John Howard has shifted the goalposts again. Just when everybody thought they had him pinned down to a definitive date and a decision on his future, events and his capacity to adapt have changed the landscape.

speech.para: Further on, he wrote:

quote.para: ... he had to act to kill off the expectation that he would suddenly announce on July 27 that he was retiring and at the same time not close all the options for Costello ...

speech.para: So Dennis Shanahan did his little bit in communicating through the media to Peter Costello that the Prime Minister was not going to make any big announcement on his birthday. Malcolm Farr also communicated this on 21 February in an article headed `Hawkish Howard: `hell no, I won't go'.

talk.start.para: —I am starting to wonder how the member for Rankin can tie this back to FOI.
—Yes, I will, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—There would be no need to use the FOI legislation for discovery, because you are quoting from the documents.

—That is true, Mr Deputy Speaker; I am quoting from a document. I would be interested in your views, if you wanted to share them with us, on whether we would be able to apply under the Freedom of Information Act for the Prime Minister's diary of that particular night. I am told reliably that these three journalists were there—
—My immediate reaction to that is that I do not think you are.
—You do not think I am eligible to access that under FOI?
—No.

—I will try. Referring to the penalty of being unsuccessful: you can only appeal to the AAT, with an application fee of $574. I reckon that for my $30 it would be worth a few laughs to see who else was at that dinner. These three journalists—Milne, Farr and Shanahan—all did the right thing by the Prime Minister: they wrote that he really was not going to rack the cue on his 64th birthday, and he needed their help in conveying that to the Treasurer.
—Unless the member for Rankin can tie this back to the bill, I am going to have to ask him to resume his seat.

—I will close on this point: they did the right thing. The Treasurer, according to the Age, got very upset about it. It is well known around the gallery that this dinner occurred. I think the Fairfax media are probably feeling entitled to wonder why they were not invited.

speech.para: I have just been passed a disturbing note saying that one of my colleagues might have been at the Lodge on that night—surely not! Member for Kingston, surely you were not there! You had not shared that with me at all before now!

Enough of that—it just shows that this government operates under such secrecy that the Prime Minister has to have a dinner at the Lodge to say that he is batting on past his 64th birthday. He gets three journalists up at the Lodge and then he tells people, through the media, that he is batting on past his 64th birthday.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —That speech is a measure of the seriousness of the member for Rankin and the opposition's approach to this very important legislation. Many members on both sides of the House have taken the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 very seriously because it affects the access of children to pornography and other aspects of online content. The member for Rankin, who has trailed his own leadership credentials throughout the last few months, is one to talk about leadership, isn't he! What about the front-page report in the Australian on Tuesday morning that the member for Rankin had joined a coalition to attack the Leader of the Opposition?

(Hon. I.R. Causley)—I am asking the minister to come back to the point. The member for Rankin has risen to make a point of order, which I am sure is to ask the minister to come back to the bill. I ask him to do so.
—Perhaps I should take out an FOI on Monday's shadow ministry meeting to see whether or not an alliance, led by the member for Rankin, was formed to attack the Leader of the Opposition!

speech.para: Getting back to this very important legislation: the issue of FOI has been the major issue that members have concentrated on. The amendment to the Freedom of Information Act is small but important. The amendment is designed to ensure that the FOI Act cannot be used to undermine the online content regulatory framework contained in the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. That is why we need the amendment to the FOI Act: because as it presently stands it has the potential to seriously restrict the provisions of the Broadcasting Services Act and therefore we would not give young people the full protection intended by the government. That is the seriousness of the issue before the parliament, and it is not to be trivialised by game-playing of the kind that the member for Rankin has displayed.

The online content framework allows the Australian Broadcasting Authority to investigate complaints from the public about material online, including information that would be refused classification or classified X by the Classification Board. In order to carry out its investigations into this potentially prohibited material, the ABA has to acquire the material. The sort of material we are talking about could include depictions of child pornography or paedophilia. That is the seriousness of the issue, but the member for Rankin and others on the other side have not approached this legislation with an appropriate degree of seriousness.

The amendment to the FOI Act will specifically exempt from disclosure, under FOI, material that is prohibited or potentially prohibited. If prohibited content in the ABA's possession was disclosed under FOI, there would be no mechanism for controlling the use or dissemination of that material once disclosed. This amendment brings Australia into line with other countries with similar mechanisms for investigating complaints about online content. For the opposition to oppose this amendment to the FOI Act means that they are not serious about restricting young people's exposure to pornography or paedophilia.

It is very disappointing for this bill to be treated in this way by the member for Rankin and others. That is yet again a measure of their inability to realise the issues that really matter to Australians and to Australian families. Who can ever forget the opposition's attacks on Senator Alston and the government's plans for controlling online content, as it affects young people, only a couple of years ago? Now they are again continuing to undermine the government's attempts to restrict pornography to young people. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Melbourne has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

interjection.para: Question agreed to.
Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Dr STONE (Murray—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage) (10.02 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Question agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered forthwith.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be disagreed to.

speech.para: The government will not be supporting the Senate amendments. The temporary residents measure demonstrates the commitment of the government to address barriers to international competitiveness in the tax system. The proposal will create employment and investment in Australia by removing competitive disadvantages to the development of Australia as a strong financial centre. This objective has been supported by successive federal governments, by state governments and by a wide range of industry groups. The changes will remove counterproductive taxes imposed on foreigners posted to Australia, including taxing them for deemed capital gains on assets held offshore during their stay in Australia.

It is disappointing that the opposition appears not to see that these unfair taxes apply to the many middle ranking management and specialist staff who come to Australia to grow business, provide better products and enrich financial sector skills in this country. It is also disappointing that the Labor Party appears not to recognise that this measure will help meet identified shortages in registered nurses, pharmacists, occupational therapists, radiation therapists and other professionals. Shortages of these kinds are often temporary, and the short-term contribution of foreign workers assists the Australian community greatly during these periods.

It is regrettable that the opposition cannot support a sensible policy change to make Australia a more attractive place to these foreign workers. As it has done before, the opposition attacked the measure as a special concession for rich foreign executives. In my view, this Labor criticism is entirely unfair. Some parts of Labor have clearly misunderstood the benefits that these measures will bring to the very people that they would normally support. The measure will apply to people who would have been Australian residents for tax purposes but who are only here on temporary entry visas.

Labour market intelligence undertaken by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations in the latter part of 2001 identified that there was a national shortage of accountants, registered nurses, pharmacists, occupational therapists, radiation therapists and information and communication technology professionals. People granted a temporary resident visa to come to Australia to alleviate the above skill shortages could benefit from the temporary resident tax exemption. In 2000-01, the top five occupations sponsored by employers under the business long-stay visa were computing professionals, applications and analyst-programmers, general managers, registered nurses and accountants. These are really the kind of people who will benefit most from this measure—not the rich foreign executives that Labor talks about.

I think the next question is probably why an Australian accountant, for instance, should be taxed differently from his or her colleague who does the same work but is here on a temporary visa. Actually, in effect, they will not be taxed so differently. Both the Australian accountant and the temporary resident are taxed here in Australia on their salary and wage income. They would pay the same tax on the same income. The difference is in relation to offshore assets. As an Australian resident, the Australian accountant pays tax to the Commonwealth on his worldwide income, including income generated by overseas assets. A temporary resident, however, will now have a period of four years during which he or she will be exempt from Australian income and capital gains tax in relation to foreign assets. Instead, subject to any treaty obligations, he or she will be likely to pay tax on income from that asset overseas. It is not as though the income escapes tax altogether.

In relation to the exemption from withholding tax liabilities for a period of four years, this will mean that temporary residents will not incur additional expenditure in borrowing money. An Australian resident does not have to pay interest withholding on his or her mortgage payments. Now a temporary resident can also pay the mortgage without any withholding tax issues. The exemption from the foreign investment fund rules lasts for as long as the temporary resident holds a temporary visa. These rules are largely intended to address anomalies which arise because, otherwise, the temporary resident is taxed in Australia every year on the increase in value of a non-employer sponsored superannuation fund. This can be particularly unfair if a credit is not given in the home jurisdiction because the fund is not taxed until realisation.

There were convincing representations made to the Ralph review and to the government about the impact of tax considerations on the willingness of firms to bring temporary employees to Australia from overseas. The extensions to this measure were announced in October 2001 and formed part of the Howard government's election platform which was resoundingly endorsed by the Australian people. (Extension of time granted) Australia has grown up. It is no longer a closed, isolated economy. We have major trading partners and major investments, and we recognise the benefits of skilled labour and the introduction of new ideas from overseas.

Costs relating to temporary resident employees are an important consideration in establishing regional offices and headquarters and in making Australia a financial centre. Other countries in the region that compete for this kind of investment also have special arrangements for temporary employees. The New Zealand government has indicated that it will be considering a similar measure. Singapore is extending its already concessional tax treatment, and China is emerging as a further competitor in the international skilled labour market.

So the sad reality is that Australia is falling behind in this respect. Japan, Hong Kong and the Netherlands are all streaking ahead of us now, and the Labor opposition to this measure will continue to penalise businesses that rely on specialist skills that can come from abroad. Under the government's proposal, Australia will benefit from the dynamic effects of having more and better businesses located here, as well as from the expenditure and local employment they will generate. Australia also benefits through the transfer of new management and other skills that key personnel can bring to Australian business.

talk.start.para: —With great respect to the parliamentary secretary with regard to his comments about the Labor opposition to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 2003, I have to draw to the attention of the House the culpable behaviour of the government in not responding to the revelations that were made just over two years ago about the high priests of our society, the barristers, who were employing serial bankruptcy and family law to avoid paying tax and the fact that not one amendment has been made to any Commonwealth law since that revelation.

speech.para: I want to quickly go through the questions that I have put on the Notice Paper, because this matter goes beyond the barristers, where it all started. You can even point today to the findings in the Cole Royal Commission into the Building and Construction Industry and why the government is very anxious to talk about the behaviour of some elements of the union movement. While none of us on this side condones that, the government is silent on those shonky directors of the phoenix companies who have stripped their companies and avoided paying creditors, principally the Commissioner of Taxation, and workers their lawful entitlements.

If you do not believe me, just look at volume 1 of the final report of Royal Commission into the Building and Construction Industry. Yesterday and today, all 23 volumes of this very important report were tabled in this House, and I want to draw your attention to page 108 of volume 1. You do not even have to get past volume 1 to look at the findings and recommendations of Commissioner Cole. Chapter 12, at page 108, goes right through the phoenix companies, and chapter 16 goes through tax evasion. This is very serious, and I want to go through the questions on tax evasion that I have put on the Notice Paper to demonstrate just how serious the government is about cracking down on tax cheats.

I put question No. 43 on the Notice Paper on 13 February 2002, and it took the Treasurer 12 months to answer it. He gave me a smoke and mirrors response, and I put a follow-up question to that question. Question No. 1171 was put on the Notice Paper on 3 December last year, and question No. 1203, in relation to the Treasurer's news release of 30 August 2002 titled `Strengthening Laws to Prevent Tax Abuse', was put on the Notice Paper on 5 December last year. The Treasurer, along with the Attorney-General, the Australian Taxation Office and the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia, indicated from the task force's report that they were going to do something about the weaknesses in our laws that enable people to use family law and bankruptcy to avoid paying tax. But when I finally got an answer from the Treasurer, what did he say? He said:

quote.para: The Government is giving further consideration to these issues.

speech.para: That means he is doing nothing. Look at question Nos 1331, 1332 and 1346 and at question No. 1347, which I put on the Notice Paper on 4 February this year. We had that outrageous case of John Cummins QC, eminent barrister, who did not lodge a tax return for 45 years. What was the Commissioner of Taxation doing about that and what is the government doing about that? Mr Cummins is not the only person. If you look at those questions, you will see that as I stand in the House of Reps tonight it is lawful to avoid the payment of personal income tax by the utilisation of bankruptcy or insolvency. Clearly, bankruptcy, insolvency and family law have become tools to permit corrupt individuals to avoid their obligations and not pay their fair share of tax. I ask the government: what are you doing to crack down on these rorts? Nothing has happened since the revelations of the barristers. I am not focusing just on the barristers tonight, because it goes wider than that. As I said, I will come back to the Cole royal commission report.

Have a look at question Nos 1357 and 1356, which I put on the Notice Paper on 5 February. Have a look at the scandalous case of Mr Stephen Archer QC. (Extension of time granted) My question No. 1415 relates to Mr Stephen Archer, a very prominent barrister who has been made bankrupt three times, put his assets out of the reach of the taxation commissioner and very kindly into the hands of his wife and owes the taxation commissioner something in the order of $4 million. That is outrageous, and the public interest is haemorrhaging when nothing is done about that. Nothing has changed since these high priests of the legal profession were exposed more than two years ago. Have a look at question Nos 1416, 1417, 1419 and 1420, which also appeared on the Notice Paper of 6 February. All of these questions are still outstanding.

Have a look at question No. 1433, which is my question to the Treasurer about Mr Robert Somosi, who racked up a debt of $835,000 in unpaid tax and penalties and was convicted of failing to lodge a tax return for 17 years—that is, for the entire time he was at the bar. That is just outrageous. Nothing has changed. Have a look at question No. 1441 to the Treasurer on the Notice Paper of 11 February, where I asked about the government's public accountability and about whether the public interest was being served by privacy laws and other statutory powers prescribed in section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Of course, the taxation commissioner is impotent because of the secrecy provisions of section 16. He cannot advise peak bodies of the corrupt behaviour of some of their members. For example, the taxation commissioner, if he is aware that someone is rorting the taxation system in becoming bankrupt, cannot even write to the New South Wales Bar Association, the Law Society, the Society of Accountants or, indeed, the AMA and say, `This particular individual is bringing great discredit to your profession and moreover is not making his or her contribution to the running of this country by paying a fair share of tax.'

Have a look at the Notice Paper of 11 February at question No. 1441 and at question No. 1442 to the Attorney-General. Then go to the Notice Paper of 12 February and look at question No. 1457, which I put to the Treasurer, and at question No. 1458. Question No. 1458 is a perfect copy of the question the member for Barton put on the Notice Paper as far back as 26 March 2001. I am very pleased to see the member for Barton walking into the chamber. He will remember this. He is probably not as forensic as I am with his questions on the Notice Paper, because he is probably busier in his shadow portfolio. Unfortunately, the 39th parliament was dissolved before he got an answer to question No. 24555. I will repeat for Mr Robert McClelland, the member for Barton, his question, because it is now reflected in question No. 1458:

quote.para: (1) Has the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) at any time over the last seven years retained any barrister who has used bankruptcy as a means of avoiding taxation obligations; if so, (a) which barrister or barristers, (b) on how many occasions was each barrister retained and (c) what was the most recent date that each barrister was retained.

(2) Has the ATO at any time over the last seven years retained any barrister while that person was bankrupt; if so, (a) which barrister or barristers, (b) on how many occasions was each barrister retained and (c) what was the most recent date each barrister was retained.

speech.para: The Treasurer did not answer that question in the 39th parliament and he still has not answered it.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Can I remind the member for Lowe that this is not a second reading debate; the whole bill is not before the House. The question is that the amendment be disagreed to. The amendment, as I see it coming back from the Senate, is about exemption for foreign workers. I think the member is outside the leave of the discussion at the present time.
—On the contrary. With great respect—
—I am sorry, but you cannot argue with the chair.

—I respect the position of the chair, but this is serious because the parliamentary secretary—whom I have regard for—has had a crack at us for our failure to support those elements of the bill. Okay, he is entitled to say that, but I am entitled to put a bit of balance into this debate because I think the government is very slack on cracking down on tax evaders and tax avoiders. It is here starkly in the Cole royal commission report. We have heard nothing from Minister Abbott, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer or the Assistant Treasurer—

—I am sure the member for Lowe has been in this House long enough to know how to raise those issues in the House. That has nothing to do with the debate at the present time. The member for Lowe will resume his seat.

—It is an absolute disgrace that the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer in the Senate, when she was confronted by the fact that the minor parties and the Labor Party were going to pass this amendment, turned around and said, `Well, the rest of the bill won't go through.' There are four other schedules to this bill and the House ought to be aware, and the parliamentary secretary at the table who is handling it ought to be very aware, that one of those schedules relates to a tax exemption for Defence Force compensation when the deployment allowance is not paid. That is, if somebody who is serving in Iraq at the moment is injured, is repatriated to Australia and ceases to be eligible for the deployment allowance because they are no longer deployed, they will be eligible for a compensation payment in lieu of that deployment allowance but that compensation payment will be taxable.

speech.para: They will have been injured in a war, serving their country, and the government's compensation to them in lieu of the deployment allowance will be taxed. That is the decision that the revenue minister took this evening in the Senate when she decided that, if she could not have all of this bill, she was not going to have any of it. I think that she will stand condemned if there is an unfortunate eventuality and one of our troops serving in Iraq is injured.

There are some other schedules attached to this bill which will also not pass if the government uses its numbers in this place to stop the amendment and stop the bill passing. They are a tax exemption for the Commonwealth Games Federation for the 2006 Commonwealth Games in Melbourne. They are adjustments to deductibility for amounts repaid for income that was received in previous years, which will cause some grief for people who had been paid income, were taxed on it in previous years, had to repay the money and now find that the repayments are not deductible against their income this year. They are not able to get adjustments to their previous tax returns to compensate them for the fact that they were, therefore, overtaxed in those years.

The government is also forgoing the revenue it would take from increasing the medical expenses offset threshold from $1,250 to $1,500. That is $54 million over the next three years—$18 million a year—off the budget bottom line. The opposition were perfectly prepared to accept that; in fact, we were prepared to not only increase it but index it so that it would continue to protect the revenue and protect the budget bottom line. The revenue minister did not want that. The only advantage I can see to this bill not passing is that we will protect the revenue to the tune of another $40 million or $50 million a year, because these tax concessions will not be available to foreign expatriates.

I listened to Senator Murray's, the Democrats's spokesman on taxation matters, speech in the other place. He took exactly the same view as the Labor Party on foreign expatriates' tax concessions: that they are something that should be dealt with in the context of the review of international tax arrangements. They are contained in, I think, chapter 5 of the discussion paper that was put out by Treasury, which the tax board has been consulting with tax professionals and industry on. They all believed that they were part of the review of international tax arrangements. I had a meeting with the Business Coalition for Tax Reform, that group of peak industry bodies that has been so helpful to the government in recent years in pursuing some aspects of its tax reform agenda, particularly the goods and services tax. I had a meeting with them two weeks ago, and they were stressing their interest in this measure. They were certainly stressing it in the context of the review of international tax arrangements. As I said earlier in the day, all of the major reform aspects of the review of international tax arrangements are going to cost money. There are not too many offsets in that group of measures. Because there are not any offsets, it is entirely appropriate that they all get considered together.

This government has been running a very slack fiscal policy. It has dissipated the large prospective surpluses that it always reports in every budget in the outyears. It spends them, it pork-barrels and it gives in to whatever political pressures that it faces. At the end of the day, we find that it cannot actually afford to do two things. One of them is to provide an internationally competitive tax system. One of the big discussions I had with the Business Coalition for Tax Reform established that the biggest impediment to international tax competitiveness in this country is the spending habits of the government, because it makes international tax competitiveness unaffordable. This government has already increased the total tax take as a proportion of GDP from 23 per cent to 24.9 per cent—two per cent of GDP.

I know precisely what the parliamentary secretary at the table is going to say. He is going to present another set of figures that does not include the GST. The fact is that, when the Labor government left office in 1996, it used only 23 per cent of GDP to do two things: Commonwealth own purpose outlays and payments to the states. It now takes 24.9 per cent of GDP to do those two things. The IMF, the ABS and the Auditor-General all take the view that the GST is a Commonwealth tax. It is not a state tax. It is one of the great deceits of Treasurer Costello that he pretends that it is not a Commonwealth tax but a state tax. The Commonwealth has total discretion about the rate at which it is collected; it does the collections. And it has total discretion about how that money is distributed. That is why the IMF, the ABS and the Auditor-General all believe that the GST is properly classified as a Commonwealth tax, and that is why the total tax taken as a proportion of GDP under this government has gone up from 23 per cent to 24.9 per cent.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Kingston is now ranging fairly widely, too, on the amendments.

—This is the highest taxing government we have ever had in this country, and now we have a situation where the revenue minister has taken a decision that if she cannot have the whole of this bill then she wants none of it. (Extension of time granted) She is leaving a situation where, if our troops serving in Iraq—who are in a very dangerous war and who are facing enormous risks—are injured in that war and repatriated to Australia, they will cease getting the tax exempt deployment allowance. They will receive compensation for not getting that deployment allowance for the period in which they would have been deployed overseas, but that compensation will be taxed. It is an absolute disgrace that the revenue minister has decided that she will forgo this measure because a majority of the members of the Senate have decided that they will not pass one other aspect of this bill.

—I would like to thank the parliamentary secretary for his consultation privately with me during the member for Kingston's speech. I will make only one more contribution on this bill, because I understand he wants to wind up the debate. I appreciate having the opportunity to further go through unanswered questions that I have on the Notice Paper, including: from 12 February, question Nos 1460, 1461, 1462, 1463, 1464, 1465 and 1466; from 13 February, question Nos 1501 and 1502; and, from 5 March, question Nos 1545, 1546, 1547 and 1548.

speech.para: I will say something about question No. 1548 because it is a very important question, and I am pleased the member for Bradfield has come into the chamber. Have a look at the annual report of the taxation commissioner of 2000-01. There is a segment here called `the legal profession project'. This is a very valuable group in the tax office, which seems to have disappeared. In the current annual report of the tax commissioner, there is no reference to the work of the legal profession project. I want to know about the activities of this group; it appears it has been wound up. I would like to know who in the tax office is doing the work of the legal profession project group.

Question No. 1549 was put on the Notice Paper on 3 March, as were question Nos 1550, 1551 and 1552. That last question relates to another scandalous case; I should talk about that. It is the case of Mr Clarrie Stevens, another QC. He did not pay any income tax for 15 years. He practised for 28 years, was a senior counsel for 11 years and specialised in tax advice for much of his career. That is a shocking case. It is not as bad as Stephen Archer, but it is a shocker. On 5 March, I placed on notice question Nos 1571 and 1572, again with regard to Mr Clarrie Stevens—and that raises very serious issues too. I believe that Mr Stevens has acted for the taxation commissioner. I would like to know what the taxation commission does to check barristers and lawyers—indeed any people that are hired by the tax commissioner—before it retains their services. How does it ascertain whether they are of good fame and character? This bloke is a scoundrel.

Going to the Notice Paper of 6 March, I refer to question Nos 1587, 1588, 1589, 1590 and 1591. Mr Bill Davidson, senior counsel, is another shocker. He has been made bankrupt twice, he has paid no tax for four years and he has approximately $2 million in unpaid taxes; yet still his wife owns a million-dollar home and they both drive Mercedes Benzes. It is little wonder that people are haemorrhaging with these cases. Question No. 1592 deals with Mr Timothy Wardell. He apparently has no assets, earns $350,000 a year, drives a BMW and lives near the waterfront. Question No. 1593 relates to Mr Wayne Baffsky, a barrister practising in criminal law. He owes the tax office $442,000 and still drives a $70,000 red Mustang car. Also on that Notice Paper are question Nos 1594, 1596, 1597, 1598, 1599, 1600, 1601 and 1602; on 18 March, question Nos. 1618, 1619 and 1620 through to 1641; on 19 March, question Nos 1651, 1652, 1653 right through to 1671; on 20 March, question No. 1714; and, on 26 March, question Nos 1761, 1762 to 1766. On today's Notice Paper there are some scorching questions: Nos 1782, 1783, 1784 and 1785. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Lindsay)—The member for Lowe's time is up. The member for Lowe will resume his seat.
—Could I just ask, while the parliamentary secretary is here, if he could follow those questions up with the Treasurer and the Attorney-General.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —In the interests of bringing this debate to a successful conclusion, I will undertake to forward a copy of the member's speech to the honourable Treasurer.
—Could I have a copy?
—The minister at the table could also have a copy.
—Could you also forward a copy to the Attorney-General?
—The parliamentary secretary will resume his seat. The member for Lowe, do you have a point of order?
—No, it is not a point of order. On indulgence of the chair, I would ask that a copy of my speech be forwarded to the Attorney-General as well as to the Treasurer.
—The member for Lowe will resume his seat if there is no point of order.

—The member for Kingston raised some issues that we canvassed previously. Given the time of night, I will not go through those matters. The member for Lowe, in his largely irrelevant contribution proceeding along the road of criticising legal practitioners, accused the government of not being serious about clamping down on tax evasion or tax avoidance. This government has a very proud record in that area. The one thing I want to say to the member for Lowe is that the government and the tax commissioner do look very closely at groups that are high risk. For instance, the Commissioner for Taxation has advised that the tax office is undertaking a project looking at legal professionals that matches tax file numbers with membership details obtained from bar associations and law societies to help identify those outside the tax system. There is a whole range of other measures designed to try and find those people who are outside the tax system, and I believe that the tax commissioner is being very much more successful. I commend to the House my motion that the amendments be disagreed to.

—In finalising this debate, I would just make a clear offer to the government that, any time they want to pass the schedule relating to the tax exemption for compensation for loss of the deployment allowance, the Labor Party will be back here to pass that instantly, without equivocation. You ought to do it tonight.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I present the reasons for the House disagreeing to the Senate amendments and I move:

motion.para: That the reasons be adopted.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill returned from the Senate with further amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered forthwith.

para.inline: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (lines 3 to 5), omit the clause, substitute:

quote.para: The objects of this Act are to:

subdebate.1.para: (a) improve the administration of the tax laws for the benefit of all taxpayers; and
(b) provide independent advice to the government on the administration of the tax laws; and
(c) identify systemic issues in the administration of the tax laws.

quote.para: (2) Clause 8, page 5 (lines 30 to 32), omit subclause (2), substitute:

(1) The Minister must cause a copy of each report under section 10 to be tabled in each House of the Parliament, or to be otherwise made publicly available:
