talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the further amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: These amendments are amendments that the government is prepared to accept. The Inspector-General of Taxation Bill 2002 has been passed with amendments by the Senate. To ensure that there is a clear and unequivocal understanding of the role and responsibilities of the inspector-general, clause 3 of the bill has been expanded. The clause now specifies the role of the inspector-general in improving the administration of tax laws, the independent nature of advice being provided by the inspector-general, and the ability of the inspector-general to identify systemic issues. It should be clearly evident now to all taxpayers what is trying to be achieved by this legislation: improved administration of the tax laws for the benefit of all taxpayers.

The government wants to ensure that any systemic tax administration issue can be reviewed by the Inspector-General of Taxation. At the same time, the government has made it clear that the operations of the inspector-general should be open and transparent. The government is therefore proposing an amendment to clause 8(2) of the bill, which would ensure the minister is still able to direct the Inspector-General of Taxation to conduct a review. The amendment would, however, allow the inspector-general to prioritise that direction after taking into consideration his or her other work priorities in accordance with clause 9 of the bill. The amended clause provides that the inspector-general need not immediately commence a review directed by the minister. The inspector-general may continue or start other reviews which the inspector-general considers have a higher work priority. The inspector-general has ultimate discretion in prioritising his or her work program. Clause 41 remains, whereby the inspector-general must outline in his or her annual report to the parliament any directions given by the minister to conduct a review.

The final amendment relates to when reports by the inspector-general would be publicly released. I note that the government agreed that it was important for the inspector-general's reports on reviews into systemic tax administration issues to be released publicly to maintain the respect and cooperation of taxpayers and their advisers. However, there is also a need, in many instances, for the government to release a response to the inspector-general's recommendation to avoid ambiguity for taxpayers. The government has therefore decided to amend clause 11 of the bill to require the minister to table or publicly release a report by the inspector-general within a specified time frame. Normally this would be within 25 sitting days of the minister receiving a report. The amendment also provides that the inspector-general may recommend that, due to special sensitivities or complexities in a particular report, the publication deadline may be extended. The government believes this amendment addresses some concerns raised about transparency of the inspector-general reports, while at the same time addressing the legitimate concern to ensure that the public release of reports is done in such a manner as to avoid unnecessary speculation or uncertainty in the tax system.

In conclusion, I note that the amendments to the bill maintain the government's commitment to establish an Inspector-General of Taxation to strengthen advice to government on tax administration, to be an advocate for the concerns of taxpayers and also to respond to stakeholder views. In particular, the three amendments provide greater clarification of the inspector-general's role and responsibilities. The passage of these amendments will enable the establishment of the office of Inspector-General of Taxation and will support an improvement in tax administration for the benefit of all taxpayers. I commend the amendments to the House and I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Inspector-General of Taxation Bill 2002. The Labor Party's position was that we opposed the setting up of an Inspector-General of Taxation. The reasons for that were twofold. Firstly, it was a waste of money because all the things that were intended to be done by the inspector-general could have been done by the Tax Ombudsman, in particular looking at systemic issues in the tax system. The second reason was that this was a rather toothless proposal, with the government having the power to direct the inspector-general, the inspector-general having to report not to the parliament and to the public but to the Treasurer or to the revenue minister and the Treasurer or the revenue minister then having total discretion as to whether to release the reports. That was not acceptable.

speech.para: Labor opposed the entire bill. Senator Murray, in the other place, proposed a raft of amendments. I have been consulting with tax professionals, and they expressed very similar concerns about this bill both to me and to Senator Murray—that it was a bit toothless, there would be no public reports, there would be this power to direct and it was underresourced. I am not advocating increasing its resources but certainly, given there was a risk that the legislation might pass, I thought that it ought to be strengthened somewhat. We supported Senator Murray's amendments in the other place. The bill came back here and went back to the Senate. I sought a meeting a couple of days ago with the revenue minister and made an offer to her that, if she would include in the bill amendments that would provide reporting to parliament and would remove the power of direction, the Labor Party would support the bill. We had a bit of a discussion about that. She came up with a fairly watered down proposal to remove the power of direction, but it is probably acceptable. Certainly the reporting to parliament is what we felt needed to be ensured.

In that respect, I am pleased to advise the House that the bill is actually stronger than the Ombudsman's Act in terms of transparency, because the Ombudsman's Act allows the Ombudsman to report to parliament if he wishes but, in this case, the Inspector-General of Taxation has to report to parliament on every issue. So there is greater transparency there. I think the professionals in the tax industry will be very pleased that the government, the Labor Party and the Democrats have come to an accommodation on this. Although the professionals are not sure what they will get out of it, they are hopeful they will get something out of it.

We are still a little sceptical. We will watch how it performs and take a view after that as to whether it is producing anything and whether it is a worthwhile organisation. It will certainly be interesting to see who is made Inspector-General of Taxation, the sorts of issues they manage to address and whether the government responds to them in any meaningful sort of way to improve Commonwealth tax administration. On this basis, I am happy to support the government's amendments.

talk.start.para: —I spoke previously on the Inspector-General of Taxation Bill 2002 in this chamber with the member for Kingston, and I shared his concerns about this bill. I want to pick up on what the parliamentary secretary just said about the Inspector-General of Taxation being able to start other reviews. I would like to ask the parliamentary secretary whether he could review the outstanding questions on the Notice Paper. That would be a good place to start.
—What numbers, John?

—I could go through them all again, but I have listed them all in the previous contributions here tonight and I will not delay the House by going through them again. It will provide invaluable insight into the level of tax evasion that is going on in this country as we speak, confirmed here today with the tabling of the final volumes of the Cole royal commission report. I want to direct the parliamentary secretary to bring page 122 of the report to the notice of the Inspector-General of Taxation. I will read you one sentence from Commissioner Cole's report in volume 1. It says:

quote.para: The evidence, including evidence provided by the Australian Taxation Office, establishes that there is significant evasion of income tax by persons and entities in the building and construction industry.

speech.para: That is very tragic, because we are not hearing anything from the government about that and something has to be done about it. These phoenix companies, which are run by shonky directors, are rorting their creditors—and the principal creditor is the Commissioner for Taxation. These are shonky companies. The directors of Company A decide at the time that it goes belly up to change the company's name to Company B. It goes belly up, and they cry, `Oh, tragic!' The same directors start another company and they call it Company C. What do they say to their workers, and what do they say to the taxation commissioner? They give the taxation commissioner the sailor's farewell, and they do the same to their employees in terms of their legitimate entitlements to holiday pay, long service leave, leave loadings and sick leave. It is scandalous, shocking and outrageous.

talk.start.para: —I know. The minister is saying yes, but nothing has happened since the revelations in relation to the barristers of whom I spoke earlier.
(Mr Lindsay)—Member for Lowe! You are talking about the Inspector-General of Taxation. Will you relate this to the bill, please?

—We are. The inspector-general has a very important role and, as I said, the parliamentary secretary said that he can take on any reviews. If he has a look at the stacks of questions that I have on the Notice Paper, it will provide him with great insight into the levels of tax evasion that are going on in this country as we speak. I want something done about it, as I am sure the parliamentary secretary does, because he is grinning at me. I am deadly serious about this, and I am going to talk all through 2003 about this issue because people are very concerned about it. I will be putting more questions on the Notice Paper, you can be sure about that. The Treasurer is outrageous: he took 12 months to answer a very simple question about the percentage of barristers and solicitors that pay the top marginal rate of tax.

—I would like to know, member for Kingston, why he does not answer them. I want to draw to the inspector-general's attention my questions on the Notice Paper and those of other honourable members on this side of the House who are very concerned about the loss of public revenue and the protection of public revenue and who wish to make sure that we collect the revenue that is due. I bet all these shonky directors who are not paying their contribution have a Medicare card. I bet they drive on our roads, and I bet they use our hospitals and our facilities, but what contribution are they making? They are making no contribution to the coffers of the Australian Taxation Office. They are not doing the right thing by their employees.

speech.para: The concern I have is that some of the big builders in Australia like Multiplex, Mirvac, Meriton and the like know about the contractors, the subcontractors and the rorts that are going on, yet they seem to be complicit in what is happening in the building industry. There are 23 volumes to this. It will keep me very busy over the next six weeks, because I am going to go through it with a fine toothcomb and you will see more questions on the Notice Paper. I am interested in the tax evasion and the tax avoidance industry that is going on in Australia as I speak, and the government seems reluctant to do anything about it. I heard what the parliamentary secretary said, but that is not substantiated by the facts. I invite him to come to my office, and I will take him through the Notice Paper. He will have no doubt as to the shocking and outrageous level of tax avoidance that is going on in Australia today. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: I move that with no great enthusiasm. The purpose of this Dairy Industry Service Reform Bill 2003 was to give control of the dairy industry to the dairy industry levy payers, the farmers and the shareholders of the new services company, which is established under this legislation. The amendments that have been moved in the Senate distract from that essential purpose. They add bureaucratic requirements that are not really within the spirit of the endeavours of the government to give industry control of its own destiny. This is not the first legislation of this kind to come before the parliament. Indeed, many industries have, over recent times, developed a modern corporate structure, and the dairy industry is following that path. The requirements that are imposed as a result of these amendments have not been included in any of the previous legislation in this regard. They have not been demonstrated to be required in other sectors, and there has certainly been no call from the dairy industry or from others associated with the industry that these sorts of amendments should be included in this legislation. It is simply a wilful exercise of the numbers in the Senate for no useful purpose.

However, the industry is keen for its new company to start on 1 July. With that in mind, the government does not wish to thwart that purpose and, for that reason, will accept the amendments. The amendments add additional bureaucratic requirements in relation to reporting to the parliament, both by the industry company itself and by the minister. I was interested to note the concerns of the opposition in relation to the discussion on the previous bill that the measure in question would cost money. They seem to have forgotten that principle when it comes to the dairy industry. These amendments will cost money—not great amounts of money, but they will cost money. Nonetheless, the opposition seem to be insisting that these sorts of additional reporting requirements be put in place.

In many instances, it will be a duplication of information that is already being provided through the tabling of the company's reports. If the opposition is insisting that we do these things two or three times, then essentially, if that is the price that has to be paid to enable the dairy industry to move to a corporate structure, the government will agree. I might add that the industry has no enthusiasm for the opposition's amendments. They did not request them. They made it clear that they would live with them in order to get the legislation through. But it is really a demonstration of what happens when you have an opposition that does not understand the industry and does not care about it very much but wants to exercise, on frequent occasions, their numbers in the House to enforce what are essentially changes to add to the bureaucracy rather than to achieve a more efficient industry.

We believe that it is important for the industry to be given the opportunity to take control of its own destiny, that farmers be given an opportunity to choose the size and nature of the levy and that there be effective reporting to the shareholders of the new company. Those objectives are so important that we are prepared to accept these amendments in the interests of smooth passage of the legislation.
Question agreed to.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the further amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: I would like to speak very briefly because I know the member for Hindmarsh is particularly impatient, along with many others in the chamber. This is a historic occasion because the Australians Working Together legislation, which is a significant financial commitment by the government to improve the welfare system, has been amended, has been passed through the Senate and of course it comes back to the House of Representatives tonight. The coalition government has improved Australia's social security system for working age people not with handouts but with policies that will deliver real benefits to individual Australians and, of course, Australia as a whole. The AWT package is already making a significant difference. We are providing Australians with improved personalised assessments and services, and more opportunities for training and work experience. The passage of the legislation will complete the balanced package of better incentives, reasonable requirements and more assistance. Most of the major measures will now commence on 20 September 2003. This delayed commencement will enable the measures to be implemented properly with the necessary systems of support.

Briefly, these measures include: the working credit, which will encourage people on income support to take up employment by allowing them to keep more of their income support when they work in part-time and casual jobs; and the language, literacy and numeracy supplement which is a payment of $20.80 a fortnight paid to eligible people who undertake approved language, literacy and numeracy training to cover the extra costs associated with training. Further measures are the closing of access to mature age allowance and partner allowance. Most people who had previously claimed mature age allowance or partner allowance will be able to get Newstart, which is paid at the same rate but gives better access to services to help them to engage with the community and move into the work force. The next item is more flexible participation requirements for mature age people—that is, 50-plus Newstart allowees—which include a wide range of activities for this age group to meet the Newstart activity test. Finally, there are new requirements for parenting payment customers. Parents whose youngest child is aged 13 years or more will get access to Centrelink personal advisers to develop participation agreements which are to try to help them get off welfare and return to work.

The delay in the commencement of these measures will also require the tabling of the evaluation of the measures to be delayed until, naturally, 30 June 2006. Other measures in the bill will commence as previously planned. These are the compulsory referral to the Personal Support Program which will commence 28 days from royal assent. The use of Centrelink records for the Family Homelessness Prevention and Early Intervention Pilot will also commence on royal assent. A very good initiative is that an extra 400 personal advisers will begin work in Centrelink offices around the country starting in September 2003. They will assist mature age and parenting payment customers to meet these new requirements.

I am very pleased that the compromise on breaching agreed in the Senate means that we can keep the AWT package together. It is most rare that I would say this, but the Democrats proposal represents a responsible and affordable balance. It provides an incentive to comply and substantially reduces the penalties, but allows us to maintain a system that is tough on those who persistently refuse to meet their obligations. I congratulate the Democrats for getting back in the game and negotiating with the government unlike the Australian Labor Party. I think everyone now acknowledges that we have done a lot over the past year and a half to reduce the impact of breaching on the most vulnerable job seekers and that our efforts have resulted in a significant decline in breach numbers. Of course, we must continue to have a strong compliance regime but we must also continue to provide a safety net for those who are vulnerable.

From September 2003 job seekers who have done the wrong thing, like missing an interview with their Job Network members, will be given a second chance to attend the interview. If they attend, their rate reduction period will be reduced from 26 weeks to eight weeks and this will provide a strong financial incentive for them to attend. This option will not be available to job seekers who naturally persist in not meeting requirements, such as those who have been breached more than once in the last two years. (Extension of time granted) Nor will it be available to those who have committed more serious breaches like refusing a job offer or lying about earnings.

We have always said that the government cannot lose sight of its responsibilities to the broader community to maintain a penalty system that is tough on those who are not genuine in their efforts to find work. The coalition government is pleased with this package. It represents a balance of incentives and reasonable requirements that complement the Australians Working Together package, and it is certainly consistent with our view and the spirit of welfare reform. I have great delight in commending this amended legislation to the House.

talk.start.para: —Whilst Labor will not oppose this message from the Senate, we do not support the bill in its entirety. Labor have set out in the other place why we do not believe that the deal done by the Democrats and the government today represents any real reform to our country's welfare system. This deal will be remembered alongside the GST deal and the industrial relations deal as yet another of the Australian Democrats' low points.

speech.para: Labor's position in relation to welfare reform and this legislation in particular has been clear. We support wholeheartedly the proposition that our system of social security confers both rights and responsibilities on Australians, but the grounds on which there has been almost constant disagreement between Labor and the Howard government have been the balance between those rights and responsibilities of social security recipients.

Since coming to office the Howard government has dramatically increased the responsibilities placed on Australians who do not have a job, those who are incapacitated or sick, and families. At the same time, critical labour market programs and support services have savagely been withdrawn. Nothing better illustrates the lack of balance in our welfare system today than the system of breaches and penalties that apply to people on social security. It is now beyond argument, after numerous independent reviews, that our system of breaching is flawed and unfair. It has impacted disproportionately on young people, and perhaps the most telling statistic is the fact that over a quarter of a million breach penalties were meted out last financial year alone—70 per cent of those to young people under 30. This is clear evidence of a system of arbitrary penalties that have in many cases been misapplied.

Labor took a decision when this bill was introduced to draw a line in the sand on breaching. We took a stand to address the growing one-sidedness of our social security system, and our amendments gave effect to the recommendations of the Pearce review. Today the government and the Australian Democrats are scuttling those amendments. I want to register my disappointment and the disappointment of the Labor Party with the Australian Democrats. They initially voted with us to create the Senate inquiry which brought the Pearce review recommendations into consideration, but today they have walked away from those recommendations. The government and the Australian Democrats may think this cosy deal is good enough, but we do not. Labor will remain a strident critic of the current breaching regime until Professor Pearce's recommendations become a reality.

The amendments that the government and the Democrats have agreed today do not restore the balance that is needed in our system. The Democrats and the government will no doubt argue that they have done this deal to save the working credit, but they will have to live with the fact that this initiative is being paid for by a breaching regime that will still be levied unfairly against unemployed people who are trying to play by the rules.

While Labor wholeheartedly supports the working credit and remains committed to its introduction, it is, in fact, a program that existed before. It was introduced by Labor in the mid-1980s, but it was criticised at that time and then abolished by this government in 1997. Now they expect accolades from us for reintroducing this scheme. I do, nevertheless, welcome the elements of the bill that return some of the spending required to the social security system, and the minister has mentioned a number of those tonight.

Labor was also successful in amending the government's bill to provide comprehensive safeguards for parenting payment recipients and the mature age unemployed, but these alone are not enough. Despite the government's constant hyperbole about sweeping welfare reforms since Senator Newman's Press Club address in 1999, they have achieved little of substance. This bill restores only a very small portion of the welfare to work initiatives that have been lost over the life of this government.

A final, important issue that I would like to speak about tonight goes to what is missing from this message, as I understand that a majority of the deal between the government and the Democrats is not, in fact, contained in legislation but will be in the form of an agreement or an exchange of letters. We are expected to trust that the government will be true to its word and that all its reviews and its monitoring are actually going to take place. But I would like to remind the Democrats that Senator Newman made a similarly non-legally binding promise to review the operation of shared care rules in relation to family payments in 2000. Now, three years later—and, strangely, on the very same day that the government is trying to rush this legislation through the House—Senator Vanstone has tabled that review. By all accounts, it is a very shoddy document and shows that the government is not at all serious about the issue of shared care arrangements and family payments and is just using this as a way to show the Democrats getting on board for yet another deal. It seems that they have fallen for that again.

It is precisely for this reason that Labor insisted on amendments to this bill to ensure that a review of the changes relating to parenting and mature age unemployed people occurred. (Extension of time granted) The reported commitment to a task force to review and monitor arrangements is, therefore, a strange one. The Pearce report represents the blueprint of independent arbiters and has been endorsed by the non-government sector, but the government has not adopted its recommendations. Why, then, do we need a new process which is not included in the legislation? We must ask whether it is because a non-legislative measure would not be so enforceable.

In conclusion, Labor believe that, without including the Pearce recommendations on breaching, this bill goes nowhere near restoring the fairness needed in the system. The government have perpetrated this unfairness and the Democrats have aided and abetted them. They have thumbed their noses at Australia's many unemployed people, they have thumbed their noses at young people and they have thumbed their noses at the charities and community groups that have to support those who are unfairly breached. Having taken a strong and principled stand before Christmas, the Democrats have now abandoned it for very little. Labor will not be party to continuing the current unfair breaching regime virtually unchanged. We will not support something that is not fair to the many individuals and families who want to move from welfare to work but who, through no fault of their own, are not afforded the opportunities to make that transition. For this reason, we will be opposing the bill.
Question agreed to.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to advise the House of the response in my electorate to the immoral and unjust war in Iraq. Earlier this month, I sent postcards to my constituents advising them of my position. I told my constituents that their local federal member of parliament says, `No war in Iraq.' I invited them to have their say and to demand to be heard. On the postcard, my constituents had the opportunity to ask me to tell the Prime Minister whether they supported or opposed Australia's involvement in the war against Iraq. I also told them on the postcard that I would be presenting the postcards to the Prime Minister to make sure that he knows the views of the people of the Charlton electorate.

speech.para: Of the postcards returned to me so far—and they are still coming in—870 opposed and 51 supported Australia's involvement in the war. I would like to take the opportunity to read some of the comments that were written on the postcards by people who opposed the war. Mr Brown of Wangi says:

quote.para: You say demand to be heard now! This Prime Minister only listens to himself or his master George Bush.

speech.para: Norma Miller of Cooranbong says:

quote.para: Thanks for doing this Kelly. Here's hoping and praying he'll change his mind. They're not listening to us are they?

speech.para: Mr and Mrs Colling of Coal Point wrote:

quote.para: Oppose violently. It is immoral and disgraceful.

speech.para: Mr and Mrs Ternovey of Arcadia Vale say:

quote.para: NO WAR. Oppose yes. Thank you Kelly!

speech.para: Mr and Mrs Fulton of Argenton say:

quote.para: We are on 100% opposed to any war against Iraq.

speech.para: T. O'Brien of Barnsley says:

quote.para: Write NO WAR on back of all envelopes in mail.

speech.para: The Radcliff family says:

quote.para: God doesn't want war. If we go to war we can expect retaliation and it won't stop terrorism. Let the leaders go to war and not the innocent people, our beautiful young men. I have five nephews who could go to war and get killed. It's not right to go into war. Howard won't get my vote. Send Howard to war and not our boys.

speech.para: Of the 51 people who stated that they supported the war, five particularly questioned whether or not I would pass on the views of those who support the war. I say to those 51 constituents: I advised you that I would and I am. Today I will be taking all these postcards to the Prime Minister to make sure that he knows the views of my constituents. One last comment: this morning we have seen on the television and heard on the news dreadful reports about civilian casualties in Iraq. We hoped there would be none, but unfortunately there have been some. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Members of this place may have received an open letter from the Chairman of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, Jeremy Jones, alerting political, community and religious leaders to incidents of public vilification against Australia's Jewish community as a result of our military engagement in Iraq. The letter was a timely reminder of the role that we all can and must play in ensuring that international events like this do not lead to the harassment—either physical or verbal—of sections of our great multicultural community. Unfortunately, this kind of vilification does occur in Australia. Mr Jones highlighted a number of specific instances of attacks against Australian Jews in the last week, including graffiti in Condell Park, Sydney, which read `Kill the Jews'; an arson attempt on a synagogue in Sydney's south-west last Friday night; an attack on the Jewish museum in Melbourne last Saturday; and anti-Semitic graffiti at the entrance to the University of Sydney on Monday. They are just a few examples. I know from the experiences of the Jewish community in my electorate that they are not isolated instances. Although not directly related, the violent demonstrations that occurred in Sydney yesterday and the protest on the steps of parliament on Monday strongly indicate that some elements opposed to the war will resort to unlawful and intimidatory behaviour which completely undermines the credibility of their antiwar stance.

speech.para: The attacks upon members of the Jewish community follow comments made by some entering the debate on the war with Iraq which suggest that American foreign policy is controlled or directed by the interests of Israel. I have spoken before in this House about the duty that we as members of parliament have to ensure that our words and actions do not encourage or inflame this kind of irrational prejudice. Unfortunately, these warnings have not always been heeded. Comments by some members opposite—such as those made by the member for Sydney, who described Israel as a rogue state and its Prime Minister as a war criminal; or those made by the member for Fowler, who referred to the Jewish community as arrogant and cruel—would have served only those who want to stoke the flames of anti-Semitism. Our multicultural society depends on tolerance and respect for people of other faiths and cultures. Just as we should condemn generic attacks on Muslim communities, we must resoundingly reject the types of actions that make Jewish Australians feel unsafe or uncomfortable in any part of our nation. Australian and American foreign policy towards Iraq has been based on nothing more than our desire to see a tyrant overthrown and weapons of mass destruction destroyed. To suggest sinister motives founded on an absurd understanding of Jewish culture or outlook is patently wrong and deserves our condemnation.

Finally, I mention the honour that I had last night here in Canberra to meet the former Labor Israeli Prime Minister, Mr Ehud Barak. I am pleased to say that the gathering was well attended by all sides of the political spectrum. Interestingly and importantly, Mr Barak strongly supported the present engagement against Iraq as the key to dealing with contemporary problems of international terrorism and rogue states, and he warmly endorsed the actions of the Australian government in Iraq.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to draw the attention of the House to the impending decision of the Howard government in the 2003 funding round for Playing Australia. Playing Australia was initiated by Prime Minister Paul Keating under the Creative Nation banner and has been continued by this government. The current funding for Playing Australia sits at $3.6 million per annum and is ongoing; but if all applicants who applied for this scheme were awarded financial assistance, the amount needed would exceed $6 million. As a consequence, two-thirds of all applications are knocked back because of funding restrictions.

speech.para: Playing Australia allows people in rural and regional Australia to have access to some of the best productions that we have in our country today. It allows all people in the Ballarat region to participate in live theatre and performances. One theatre in my electorate has contacted me concerning the impending decision. Her Majety's Theatre is concerned that the decision made by the cabinet in the upcoming budget session will not adequately reflect the importance of theatre in the Ballarat region.

I stand in the House today to urge the government to continue its commitment to arts and culture, as the previous Labor government did. Ballarat has a fine history of art and theatre, with its origins going back to the early days of the gold rush, with the building of the Theatre Royal in 1858. Throughout its history, the theatre has been on the list of many major productions that have toured Australia. Her Majesty's Theatre continues to play an important role in bringing theatre to people in my electorate. Recent productions include Circus Oz, Mavis Goes to Timor, Speaking in Tongues, David Williamson's A Conversation, the Melbourne International Comedy Festival Roadshow,Bell Shakespeare's The Servant of Two Masters and the Australian Ballet Company's production of The Nutcracker. The Sydney Theatre Company's production of The Christian Brothers is coming soon. These productions represent the cream of Australian theatre performances. To not allow these productions to visit would disadvantage the people of Ballarat and the surrounding regions. These performances are a way that people in my electorate can have access to top billing shows like those produced by the Bell Shakespeare Theatre Company.

Students at the Arts Academy in the new Camp Street precinct also benefit greatly from the work that Her Majesty's Theatre does in bringing these productions to Ballarat. Playing Australia gives many of these students the opportunity to witness—and, in some cases, to participate in—nationally acclaimed performances. As I have said previously, the Playing Australia fund is to come before cabinet in the current budget discussions. I call on the Howard government and Minister Kemp to strengthen funding under the Playing Australia fund so that people in my electorate can continue to enjoy the fabulous shows that Her Majesty's puts on.

talk.start.para: —I rise this morning to bring attention to the appalling behaviour that took place in the streets of Sydney yesterday—behaviour, I might add, that is being encouraged by far too many members of the opposition. I am absolutely disgusted that we have such noises made about how, on the one hand, we ought to be supporting the right to demonstrate and, on the other, being appalled at the idea of war, disruption and violence; yet actions by those opposite encourage demonstrations on the street and unlawful acts carried out by ill-informed minors, encouraged by adults.

speech.para: It is almost treasonous that some members opposite would encourage our youth, our future, to go out there and break the law, rise up against law and order, and denigrate our armed forces that go overseas to do their jobs. They create a sense of shame in our Defence Force personnel. It is disastrous for our future as a nation. Everyone I speak to deplores exposing minors to violent acts. Yet schoolchildren are being encouraged to give up their learning process—a process that will equip them for tomorrow—and instead go out onto the streets and take part in collective thuggery. It is a disgusting situation which does nothing for the future of this nation. What example is being set for the youth—the leaders of tomorrow—and how few real leaders are we going to get if they are encouraged to become rabble who will mindlessly rise up against law and order?

It is no coincidence that these people are encouraging such performance. Such performance and use of minors to push one's political will is the sort of stuff that we expect to see in countries which are dominated by a totalitarian government. It is appalling. More Australians ought to be going public and deploring this sort of behaviour and the encouragement that is so frequently given to this sort of behaviour by members opposite. I hear time and time again people standing up and saying that, if children want to march, it is their right. It is their right in a democratic country, but I wonder whether such advice given to ill-informed minors creates a future where this democracy will be maintained.

talk.start.para: —Today I would like to bring to the attention of the House the issue of unsolicited child pornography by email. One of my constituents, Wendy Charnell, came to me late last year with a very serious problem. Ms Charnell was receiving unsolicited child pornography in her electronic mail. These emails were arriving almost daily, containing images of and links to images of children being abused sexually and subjected to disgusting pornographic acts. Despite my constituent's efforts to unsubscribe to the self-described service, the emails continued to arrive regularly. Ms Charnell, alarmed by the material, approached her Internet service provider, one of the largest carriers of home users in Western Australia. After sharing her problem with the firm, they informed her that they would not filter the material from her email as it was not their legal obligation. She then approached the police to complain, without success. Ms Charnell, a 61-year-old mother, then approached my office.

speech.para: Possession of child pornography is a serious crime, and rightly so. But, if a law enforcement officer assessed my constituent's computer, Ms Charnell would be charged. In Western Australia, she could be imprisoned for five years. Despite her efforts to prevent the flow of illegal material to her, Ms Charnell would still be chargeable under law. Ms Charnell was worried about the situation. I wrote on her behalf to the Attorney-General's office, outlining this serious problem. This letter, dated 17 December 2002, did not receive attention from the Attorney-General's office until 22 January 2003. The letter my office received in response indicated that the matter was being forwarded to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. I still await a response from the minister for communications. My office has been hounding the minister's office for a reply for the past three weeks with no luck.

My constituent is obviously distressed about her legal status. Five states and territories do not discriminate between possession and knowing possession of child pornography. Western Australia had a case go through the Supreme Court in 2001. This provided some guidance, but Ms Charnell could be hauled through the legal system and have to prove that she did not solicit this material. Looking at her temporary Internet files, which show that these files have been opened, she would have to prove that she had not accessed this material willingly. This is a nationwide problem. Should my constituent cross the border, she would be charged immediately in South Australia, New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Intent does not matter there. The Internet is a borderless medium. It is not slowed down by boundaries, be they geographical, political or anything else.

I challenge any member of the government to stand up and say that they have never received unsolicited email in their time as an Internet user. However, the government's inability to create a national standard on this matter suggests that they feel unsolicited illegal material cannot be emailed by these indecent people. I am not saying anything the Howard government has not already heard. One of the major Internet users in this country, Electronic Frontiers Australia, has been raising this matter with the government for a long time. However, these concerns are falling on seemingly deaf ears. I quote the Executive Director of EFA, Irene Graham—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The environment is receiving tremendous value from the federal government working in partnership with local community groups. One example is the work of Rod McKelvey and his team of volunteers who have done extensive river care and land care work on the Orara River near Coffs Harbour. The work carried out by the Orara Valley Rivercare Group Management Committee has involved regenerating some 85 kilometres of the river. The work of more than 200 community-minded volunteers associated with river care work was recognised last year when the project won the Natural Heritage Trust Rivercare Award.

speech.para: The federal government has also funded a number of Envirofund projects throughout the Cowper electorate. In the latest round of commitments the government has provided an additional $540,000 in my electorate for environmental projects. The project money will be spread right across the electorate and will bring real results on the ground. Recently I enjoyed the opportunity to meet with representatives from a number of Landcare groups who will carry out the Envirofund work. The common thread that existed in all cases was partnerships which were being formed between local communities as a result of federal government assistance. For example, major weed eradication work in the Woolgoolga Creek Flora Reserve will be facilitated as a result of federal government funds. In addition to that, Carl Freeman from Envite Environmental Training and Employment has forged close ties with Gordon Abbott of the Woolgoolga Chamber of Commerce. The chamber is also providing some financial assistance and is assisting with volunteer numbers for the work to be completed.

In the Bellingen shire the same cooperation was evident but through different channels. Eleven projects in that shire have just received $228,000 of Envirofund funding. The projects are focusing on environmental issues around creeks and rivers. I recently visited a property at Dorrigo owned by Dennis Atkins. The work Dennis is doing with the Mountain Top Landcare Group is exceptional. I would like to particularly thank Ted and Geraldine Harrington and Harold Griffiths, who gave me a valuable insight into the ongoing work of their group and showed me around their properties and the remarkable work that is being achieved.

There are other examples in my electorate, including the work of the Nambucca Valley Landcare Group, which is led by Tim Ryan. Greencorps projects have been a great success in my electorate by involving many young Australians. Recently I launched a Greencorps project that will see significant environmental work on Macauleys Headland, north of Coffs Harbour. The work they are carrying out on the headland is a tribute to their supervisor, Allan French, and the whole team.

Next Tuesday the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government will join me to launch another Greencorps project at Dorrigo. I would like to recognise the good work Nat Redman is doing with regard to the site at Rocky Creek. All these projects are linking communities with the environment, and the federal government is pleased to assist. I very much commend all those involved with this very good work being done in environmental areas.

talker.name: Gallus, Christine, MP
Mrs GALLUS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: The National Gallery Amendment Bill 2002 amends the National Gallery Act 1975 to enable the National Gallery of Australia to gift a work of art, whether or not that work has saleable value, subject to approval by the gallery council and the minister.

Section 9 of the act sets out the process for disposing of works of art from the national collection. Subsection 9(1) provides that, where the gallery council is satisfied that a work of art is either unfit for the national collection or no longer required as part of the national collection, the council may resolve that the work be disposed of by sale, gift or destruction. However, subsection 9(4) provides that the council shall not resolve that a work of art be disposed of by way of gift or destruction unless the council is satisfied that the work has no saleable value.
Subsection 9(5) requires any decision relating to the disposal of the work of art be put to the minister for approval.
The bill amends subsection 9(4) to allow the disposal of works with saleable value by gift. However, council and ministerial approval are still required.

One example of the difficulties imposed by subsection 9(4) relates to the Arthur Boyd works of art that were formally presented to the British Museum by the Ministerfor the Arts in July 2000. Presently these works of art are on long-term loan to the British Museum, but are unable to be publicly displayed due to an internal policy of the British Museum that prohibits the public display of works which are not in the collection. The Boyd works are therefore only available to scholars wanting to view them.

The amendment is expected to broaden the scope for the gifting of works to other institutions, including regional galleries within Australia. It will enable the National Gallery to have better long-term planning over the management of its collection and will also assist the regional galleries with their collection management. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

talk.start.para: —I have a great deal of pleasure in speaking on the National Gallery Amendment Bill 2002. Only yesterday, I had the great pleasure of attending—with my colleague the shadow minister for the arts, the member for Fraser, Bob McMullan—a two-hour full briefing by the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts which, of course, featured the National Gallery and the excellent work it does. The discussion of this bill gives me an opportunity to highlight some features of that. The bill amends the National Gallery Act 1975 to enable the National Gallery of Australia to gift a work of art with saleable value, subject to approval by the gallery council and the minister. The opposition supports this bill.

speech.para: At present, the act allows that a work of art may be disposed of by way of gift or destruction only if it has no saleable value. The bill amends the act to allow works with saleable value to be donated. Section 9 of the act sets out the process for disposing of works of art from the national collection. Subsection 9(1) provides that, where the gallery council is satisfied that a work of art is either unfit for the national collection or no longer required as part of the collection, a work of art may be disposed of by way of sale, gift or destruction. However, subsection 9(4) provides that a work of art shall not be disposed of by gift or destruction unless it has no saleable value. This bill proposes to amend the act to allow for the gift of works with a saleable value, keeping in mind that council and ministerial approval are still required.

The need for this amendment arises because of constraints on disposal of minor works of art considered to be no longer needed in the national collection. In particular, the gallery has acquired a series of prints which sometimes duplicate existing items in the collection. When there are duplicates, the gallery has identified the best copy and sought to dispose of the other. One example mentioned by the Minister for the Arts and Sport, Senator Rod Kemp, in his second reading speech, relates to prints by Arthur Boyd presented to the British Museum in July 2000. Because these have the status of a long-term loan they cannot, under British Museum policy, be publicly displayed.

Senator Kemp said that the amendment would allow the donation of works to other institutions, including regional galleries in Australia. His office says that it is not intended to make donations to commercial galleries. The risks of inappropriate donations are minimised by the requirement for gallery council and, as I mentioned earlier, ministerial approval. According to the second reading speech presented by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Ian Campbell, this measure is expected to broaden the scope for making gifts of works to other institutions, including regional galleries within Australia.

I am indebted to the Parliamentary Library research staff for some of the following information, which I think it is important to put on the public record, if only for interest's sake. The Council of the National Gallery of Australia approved a disposal policy in April 1995. The objectives of the National Gallery of Australia disposal policy are to dispose of works of art by exchange or transfer in order to refine and improve the Gallery's collections; to transfer works that may be better placed in another gallery or similar public collecting institution; and, finally, to deaccession works of art, using financial proceeds, if any, for the development and improvement of the collection.

For interest's sake, the National Gallery of Australia argues that the purpose of review and disposal is to improve the quality of the collection. The decision to dispose of a work is made by the gallery council and approved by the minister. When considering a work for disposal, the council must consider, among other things: whether the significance or aesthetic merits of the work fall below the general level of the collection; whether the work lowers the overall level of quality or representation of an artist or an area of the collection; whether the work has deteriorated to such an extent that it is no longer able to be exhibited and is beyond restoration to an acceptable standard; whether the work has been found to have been falsely documented, described or attributed or is indeed a forgery; whether the work is duplicated in the collection where duplication serves no scholarly or educational purpose—a duplicate means a work produced as a multiple or in an edition, for example, a work struck from the same dye or printed from the same block or plate; and, finally, whether the work is one that is no longer representative of the collection as characterised by the gallery's acquisition policy at the time of disposal.

It is important to note that the gallery does not dispose of a work by a living artist, except with the written permission of the artist. A work that was the subject of a gift or a bequest is not disposed of without first obtaining the consent of the donor, the relevant trustee or the personal representative of the donor's estate where this is possible. Details of the disposal of any works of art are included in the gallery's annual report, which is tabled in this parliament.

In 1998, the Australian National Audit Office conducted a performance audit of the country's major collecting institutions. These included the National Library of Australia, the National Gallery of Australia, the National Museum of Australia and the Australian War Memorial. In its report entitled Safeguarding our national collections, the Australian National Audit Office found that disposal was not a high priority activity of any of the institutions it examined. It reported that, since 1990, the gallery had disposed of only one work of art, which was returned to its previous owner. The Australian National Audit Office recommended that, in order to ensure the continuing quality of its collection, the gallery along with other collecting institutions should allocate a higher priority to identifying items for possible disposal. That was in 1998. Since then, the latest annual report of the National Gallery of Australia records that ministerial approval was obtained to dispose of 670 objects during the financial year 2001-02. The items disposed of comprised a group of 20 photographs by an unknown artist of the 19th century and an archive of 285 glass and 365 film negatives.

The National Gallery of Australia has an extended program of loans of works of art to other galleries and through touring exhibitions. The latest annual report of the gallery states that during 2001-02 the gallery loaned more than 2,000 works for exhibition, including travelling exhibitions and works loaned to Commonwealth official residences. In October 2002, the National Gallery of Australia announced that, as part of the celebration of its 20th anniversary, the gallery would be sending some of its most treasured works to 20 galleries around the country over the next 12 months. The program was given the name 20/20 after the National Gallery of Australia asked the directors of 20 state and regional galleries to choose their top three works from a list of 20 possibilities. The works available include some of the gallery's most valuable and most popular works. Galleries to be loaned a major work from the NGA's collection include the state galleries and the regional galleries in Kalgoorlie, Bunbury, Darwin, Alice Springs, Cairns, Rockhampton, Mount Gambier, Albury, Broken Hill and, closer to my electorate of Braddon, Launceston.

I found it interesting to go to the web site of the National Gallery to have a look at the travelling exhibitions program, and I think it is absolutely vital that that program continue. I know that it is eagerly anticipated and supported by regional Australia. I note, for example, that more than three million people have visited National Gallery travelling exhibitions since the program began in 1988. I understand that in that time over 50 exhibitions have been held at over 300 locations in every state and territory, and more than 4,000 works of art from the national collection have travelled well over 600,000 kilometres. For instance, Techno Craft; Seeing the Centre: the Art of Albert Namatjira; Douglas Annand: the Art of Life; Life in the Emperor's Tomb; Islands in the Sun; Rough Cuts; and the Good, the Great and the Gifted are currently touring regional Australia and our capital city galleries as part of the travelling exhibitions program. We encourage and congratulate the gallery on the program and hope that this work continues.

I would like to take this opportunity to note another issue concerning the National Gallery, which worries me greatly. The gallery is one of 15 institutions being examined by what can only be called a secretive government review. The secrecy of the government's agenda has prompted considerable anxiety among the institutions concerned and the broader arts community because—inevitably, and certainly in the economic circumstances in which we find ourselves at the moment—a government review means cost cutting. I think that, of all the great institutions and activities in our country, it always seems to be the arts that people tend to target in terms of cost-cutting measures. I have to say that the arts are probably the leanest area to target for cost cutting. If that is the intention with this review, it should be open and transparent.

The government has refused to release the terms of reference for the review in spite of valiant efforts by Labor's Senator Lundy in Senate estimates. It will not consider public submissions. Why is that? The government has not even published a list of the institutions included in the review—although we do have the list, thanks to media reports that inform us that the review covers the following: the National Museum, the National Gallery, the National Library, the National Archives, ScreenSound Australia, Questacon, the Old Parliament House National Portrait Gallery, the Film Finance Corporation Australia, Film Australia, the Australia Council for the Arts, the Australia Business Arts Foundation, the Australian Film Commission, the National Maritime Museum, the Australian Film Television and Radio School, and the Bundanon Trust. So what is the government up to?

There are a few things we do know about the review. It is being undertaken jointly by the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, the Department of Finance and Administration, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Treasury. It is clear that the one motive for the review is to cut spending. In one of the government's scarce public comments on the review, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston, said:

quote.para: you need to make sure that you are getting people through the door

speech.para: Those comments, along with Senator Kemp's refusal to rule out the possibility of reintroducing entry fees for the National Gallery, are cause for concern. The imposition of entry fees would be a retrograde step. In his evidence at recent estimates Senator Kemp gave us a few clues about the review. He said that it would:

quote.para: address a range of current and emerging issues across the portfolio, including things like collection storage capacity, costs into the future, digitalisation, the application of new technologies for collection management and access, potential resource challenges for conservation expertise and services, and the need to establish a consistent policy framework across the range, where appropriate.

speech.para: Dr Stretton, the executive director of the department's art and sport division, told estimates that the review would examine ways for the institutions to share services, make more use of partnerships and work more collaboratively. All that points to is an effort to squeeze resources to these institutions, many of which are already trying to do more with less. Finally, the opposition supports this bill, which will help the National Gallery to manage its collections and improve access by other galleries to art works. But we are concerned by the government's broader agenda for cultural institutions and about the secrecy surrounding the review of those institutions. By failing to be more open and transparent, the government is inviting us to fear the worst.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to support the National Gallery Amendment Bill 2002, which proposes a minor amendment to the National Gallery Act 1975. Currently, section 9 of the act sets out the process by which works of art can be disposed of from the national collection. Subsection 9(4) stipulates:

quote.para: The Council shall not resolve that a work of art be disposed of by way of gift or destruction unless the ... work has no saleable value.

speech.para: The proposed amendment will remove the words `gift or' from subsection 9(4). The effect of the bill will be to allow the National Gallery to gift works of art where they are unfit for or no longer required by the National Gallery.

It is interesting that the member for Braddon, who provided us with some details in his speech, spent most of it in relation to the proposed review of this portfolio and the galleries. It was all on what could be called hypotheticals. He had no actual basis on which to make this broad sweeping attack on the government, rather it was: it could be this, it could be that, it could be something else. It filled in his speech, but there was no substance in what was actually said. It was a good try. I am sure it keeps the branches amused in Braddon, but in terms of a basis for his accusations it was very thin pickings and very hypothetical. Anyway, I am sure that it will keep the member for Braddon amused, and we look forward to the announcement when the review is completed.

Basically, this is a technical review. It takes out some minor wording in relation to the disposal of works of art. They were previously prevented from disposing of works of art unless they had no commercial value, nor could they give a work of art as a gift unless it was valueless. This removes the gift provision so that, even though the work of art has some value, if it meets certain criteria—such as there being other copies of it or it is not seen as fitting in with the overall collection in the gallery—it can be gifted to some of the national regional galleries. It seems like a sensible proposal, and I am glad to see the shadow parliamentary secretary is supporting this proposal. It would have been nice if we had had a speech which congratulated the minister on this proposal and these initiatives making it possible for regional galleries to be given these works of art. These changes will be useful and important. The fact is, a number of such works are currently being held on long-term loan by regional galleries around Australia, so the financial impact from the amendment is expected to be minimal as works of significant value are not likely to be disposed of from the national collection.

The government is committed to the regions and this has been evident through the arts. The idea has been to take art to the regions to allow people the opportunity to see works they would not ordinarily be able to see. Of course, my colleague the member for Hinkler would be able to appreciate that in his own area and would know that now there is a great opportunity for regional galleries—

talk.start.para: —The Bundaberg Regional Arts Centre.

—Yes, the Bundaberg Regional Arts Centre. It is not only the arts community that benefits—tourists will also be able to see the works of art. I am sure that the member for Hinkler, an outstanding member, welcomes these proposals to assist regional Australia through the provision of these works of art.

speech.para: The National Gallery of Australia has over the past few years extended the program of loans of works of art to other galleries and through touring exhibitions. During 2001-02 the gallery loaned more than 2,000 works for exhibition, substantially enhancing the significance of regional galleries. In October 2002, the gallery announced it would be sending some of its most treasured works to 20 galleries around the country over the following 12 months as part of its celebration of its 20th anniversary. This was done in consultation with the directors of 20 state and regional galleries, who were able to nominate their top three works from a list of 20 possibilities. It is a good initiative and I am sure that the members for Clarence and Hinkler would appreciate and support these changes.

In addition to this initiative, the government has initiated several other programs to assist arts in the regions. One of these is the Visions of Australia program, which aims to make exhibitions of cultural material accessible to more Australians. It does this by providing grants to cultural and community organisations to develop and tour exhibitions of historical and scientific material, visual arts and crafts, multimedia and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture throughout Australia. The Regional Arts Fund is a further federal government initiative that supports the arts in regional and rural Australia.

The government takes very seriously the issue of the arts in the regions. This is in stark contrast to Labor, which ignored artists and audiences in rural and regional Australia whilst in government and, really, nothing has changed while they have been in opposition. The member for Hinkler, who is a former state secretary of the Arts Council of Australia, would know that it is this government which has done much more for rural and regional Australia. When the former government were in power there were some eight arts ministers. They were rotated at a great rate through the portfolio. It would appear that nobody wanted it. It was held for a while and then there would be a change. Since they have been in opposition—and long may they stay there—they have had no fewer than six shadow arts spokespeople. They have downgraded the portfolio—no offence to my colleague—and have given it to a shadow parliamentary secretary. That is how it is being regarded; it is not being given any serious consideration.

I was very pleased to see that the government committed $1 million to a regional art gallery in my electorate. The total cost of the gallery, completed in 2000, was some $7 million, with $6 million coming from the council and $1 million provided by the government out of funding from the Federation Fund. The Hazelhurst Regional Gallery and Arts Centre have provided me with figures showing that they have had more than 127,000 people through the doors since opening almost three years ago. They have held significant exhibitions at the gallery, including the Archibald Prize exhibition in 2002, the Tony Tuckson exhibition, which was on loan from the National Gallery of Australia, and the Imants Tillers exhibition in 2002. It is a very popular institution. People in the Sutherland shire have warmly received the Hazelhurst Regional Gallery and Arts Centre. It is always full of people at the various exhibitions and is one of the great initiatives of this government.

This bill will enhance the collections of regional galleries with very little impact on the national collection. The benefits will flow on to the communities who will have better access to a wider range of works of art. It is an important initiative that will continue the government's commitment to rural and regional Australia through the arts.

We have a very fine national art gallery and its collection of works is of world standard. Governments of both political persuasions have been committed to this gallery. The gallery has fine works of art which are seen not only by Australians but by international visitors as well. International visitors to Australia regularly visit the gallery, acquainting themselves with Australia's cultural development and history. The range of works is outstanding.

The gallery is attempting, with its wide range of works, to provide opportunities to regional Australia. This government is committed to regional and rural Australia and the many regional art galleries we have throughout the country. It is important that we have top quality art works in our National Gallery and that, where they are redundant to the requirements of the National Gallery, they are provided to the regional galleries. It is important that we continue to provide assistance to regional Australia by ensuring that works which are surplus to the needs of the National Gallery are provided to the regional galleries. I am pleased to have been able to speak at extended length on this bill. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I wish to not only reflect upon the comments of the previous speaker, the member for Cook, but also thank him for illuminating this important issue and expanding my understanding of it to such an extent that I can now rise and make some comment upon the National Gallery Amendment Bill 2002. Not so long ago I spoke to the member for Brand. He attested to me in that discussion how important it was to him when he travelled through the regional cities of Australia to witness the regional art galleries. We have enormous riches in our country, and therefore I think it is important to reflect upon those things.

speech.para: The Victorian cities of Bendigo and Ballarat—and even Castlemaine, close to my electorate—boast art galleries of national significance. The casual visitor to either of those grand buildings could not help be impressed by the authority with which these structures impress themselves on the street. As we know, they represent a culmination of the wealth that was accumulated during the gold rush era of Victoria. One of the great manifestations of that gold rush is these places where art can be displayed.

The city fathers of the late 19th century, their pockets bulging with newly acquired gold revenue, were anxious to establish their credentials as cultured citizens of the empire. That is apparent to anyone who has spent some time visiting these great places. This anxiety was most keenly felt in the cities, which only a decade or two before had been the homelands of Aboriginal people. It is almost as though, the more grand and permanent the structure, the more safely and comfortably the recent memories of the people who once lived and hunted there could be consigned to the past.

They were very interesting times in our history. Theatres, opera houses, chambers of commerce, courthouses, banks, town halls, parks, civic squares and art galleries sprang up with a speed that reflected the new colony's prosperity. These galleries were filled with art that reflected the popular taste of the day. They were hugely popular and successful, fulfilling the Victorian principle that everyone—even the working classes—should be elevated and improved by exposure to culture. From Castlemaine to Sale, from Geelong to Mildura and across the continent, there now exists a network of galleries containing the cultural history of the entire nation.

As well as containing collections of the art of the 19th and 20th centuries, these institutions are now vital. They are a vital part of the cultural life of the towns and cities which they serve, not least because they host and initiate exhibitions of contemporary and historical importance, which travel the country forming a kind of national dialogue about our past, present and future. They are places where ordinary people can celebrate and reflect upon the art and expression of this country's citizens.

Absolutely central to this function is the ability of the regional galleries to borrow and exhibit works that would often otherwise languish in the storerooms of our large state galleries and in Canberra's own National Gallery—largely unseen and unappreciated by the general public. According to a recent publication by the gallery, making works available for loan by regional, metropolitan, state and international galleries is a high priority, profiting all the parties involved. I am not sure if you are aware of this, Mr Deputy Speaker, but since 1976 the gallery has loaned over 13,000 works of art to various borrowers for exhibition and display. Among them are pictures borrowed in order to make the conversation flow more pleasantly before dinner in the Governor-General's residence and paintings that fought the plasma screen TV for attention even in the Prime Minister's home. Beyond the issue of simply loaning works for exhibition, the National Gallery Amendment Bill 2002 is intended to extend the ability of the national arts institution to donate works presently owned by the Commonwealth, even if the work has saleable value. Proposed donations will be subject to the approval of the gallery council and the approval of the arts minister.

The present National Gallery Act, which is now almost 30 years old, provides for the disposal of a work only if it has no saleable value. The act as drafted undoubtedly requires refining. For example, what is meant by saleable value? I would have thought that even a damaged work had at least some saleable value. Strangely, the act provides for a circumstance in which the gallery council can resolve that a work of art be disposed of by destruction. Call me precious, but I cannot think of a possible set of circumstances where a work of art that was previously owned by the Commonwealth and that at one time was thought worthy of being included in the national collection could warrant outright destruction. Having wondered from time to time how many things could have found themselves in the collection, I can certainly understand some impassioned members of the public or even an employee of the National Gallery deciding to take matters into their own hands and take to a dubious work of art with an axe. But I do not think it is in the place of the national parliament to sanction vigilante violence, even on the grounds of good taste. The proposed amendment to subsection 9(4) of the act allows works of saleable value to be donated but makes no proscription as to who may be the beneficiary of the donation.

Senator Kemp's office has advised my office that there is no intention to make donations to commercial galleries and that the risk is minimised by the requirement for council and ministerial approval. The risk might be minimised, but it certainly is not ruled out by the present bill. The bill also gives no assurances, nor could it, that works would not be resold in future to commercial interests—resulting in an obvious loss to the Commonwealth. Presumably, the gallery council is guided by the terms of the gallery's disposal policy when giving approval for the disposal of a work from the Commonwealth collection.

I think it is important to add that the policy does not constrain the council, since it seems that the council itself can amend the policy at a general meeting. The current policy was adopted by the gallery council in April 1995. The parliament is being asked, by the gallery's council and the minister, to pass legislation to allow the disposal of works currently in the collection and owned by the people of Australia. The minister is not, presumably, an expert on aesthetics or an authority on the state of the collection under review and so would inevitably take the advice of the gallery council. The gallery council, therefore, can rewrite its own guidelines; so one is entitled to ask: where is the transparency? This bill before the parliament relies to an unwise extent on the goodwill of the gallery council and the minister to do the right thing by the Commonwealth. No slight is intended on the present gallery council as I speak on this issue; but I have to say that, given the government's willingness to stack any committees or boards with present and former Liberal Party figures—the ABC board and the board of the National Museum of Australia come immediately to mind—I would have thought that this was a misplaced assumption at best.

The gallery's annual report is tabled in parliament, and it includes details of the disposal of works from the collection—but presumably only after the disposal has taken place. I say that genuine scrutiny of the gallery's procedures is not, therefore, guaranteed. The National Gallery's disposal policy is a contentious document. It states that the purpose of review and disposal is to improve the quality of the collection, but the disposal will not occur `in response to current trends' or `on the basis of personal taste'. The matter of personal taste is circumvented to a degree by the need for consensus among the members of the council, but the proscription on current trends is more contentious. Nothing could be more obscure or ambiguous than the idea of what constitutes current trends. No-one regards their own opinions or prejudices as arising from current trends, even when they do. We all think that our opinions are our own commonsense formed by rational consideration of the facts.

I recall that the member for Lalor articulated, in the papers only last week or the week before, the broad sweep of culture wars are currently being fought in the trenches of our media and national institutions by those sympathetic to, on this occasion, the current government on a range of issues but particularly on matters of our history. This is a time when many of our national institutions are being openly attacked for supposed political bias. The National Museum of Australia is currently under scrutiny for the crime of daring to tell stories about Indigenous people's experiences, in their own voices, of white contact. Further examples proliferate by the day. It is now commonplace to hear the High Court of Australia being condemned in the media and in the parliament for judicial activism necessitating the appointment of capital `c' conservatives in order to achieve something called, as it is now referred to, `balance'. If you look at the Industrial Relations Commission, 13 of the last 15 appointments—

talk.start.para: —Come on—
—Thank you. The minister has reminded me and, therefore, I think I should stop and reflect upon how many are now on the commission—
—I rise on a point of order on relevance, Mr Deputy Speaker. The High Court and the Industrial Relations Commission—
(Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Order! There is no point of order on relevance. The member has just started going down another track.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. The first sentence I speak on anything outside of the bill, the minister is on his feet—and so he should be. He should be defensive. Why should he be defensive? Because he is aware, as most of us are aware—and we have to make sure members of the public are increasingly aware—that this government has employed 13 of the last 15 commissioners from the employers' side, even on the Industrial Relations Commission. While there was always balance with the former Labor governments, there is no balance now.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 10.41 a.m. to 11.07 a.m.

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, this is an important bill. It is seen as rather an innocuous bill, but it is an important bill.
