Whilst the way in which art is disposed of may not be the priority of the nation, it is important. Therefore, you have to look at who may decide to dispose of art. As I was saying, when you have a government that appoints predominantly their own to some sort of retirement village that includes most of the institutions of this country, we have a problem. I indicated only recently that there was a convention that in the Industrial Relations Commission you would have a balance of appointments between employer and employee representatives. But since 1996, 13 of the last 15 appointments of high-level commissioners—mainly senior deputy presidents—to the Industrial Relations Commission have been from the employer base.

speech.para: The reason I make that point is that you just do not know any more whether there will be any balance in our institutions. Even now, figures such as the reviled former member for Flinders and a former Howard speech writer have been openly canvassed for positions on the ABC. The ABC now gives a national voice to right wing commentators on its Sundaymorning political comment program, apparently in the interests of balance, while giving no right of reply to anyone from the broad Left. So there are concerns about this bill. I think the intention of the bill is generally well meaning, but anybody who is concerned about who the decision makers in this area are should start looking at the way in which people are appointed to that group which makes decisions with respect to the art of Australia. They may have some concerns about that.

In this current atmosphere, it is right and proper for members on this side of the House to ask for safeguards to ensure that transparency in all processes regarding assets belonging to the Commonwealth is respected. It is our responsibility to ensure that we are not unknowingly allowing the national collection to be possibly adulterated, censored or distorted according to some conscious political or other agenda. The collections are expanded and nurtured by curators who are the best in their field and, I think, the best this country can produce. They do their work in a spirit of open-minded research and inquiry in a stream of intellectual conversation with their colleagues, with themselves and with the work of art itself. They must be allowed to continue to do that unhindered.

The National Gallery of Australia is one of our most vigorous and fertile cultural institutions, and it is an indispensable part of the nation's intellectual capital. Still one of the world's newest national galleries, it has in only three decades established itself at the heart of the nation's conversation about its past, its future aspirations and its very identity at a time when this nation has undergone unprecedented reappraisal of everything it previously held beyond question. This process continues today at its highest pitch of intensity. I hope that every gift from the national collection to a regional art gallery nourishes this nation's conversation with itself and, if it does this, then this bill has served the people of Australia. It is within that spirit, and having regard to some of the comments I made about the potential risks of this bill, that I recommend the bill to the House.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —I wish to thank all members for their contributions to the debate on the National Gallery Amendment Bill 2002 and for their interest and involvement. It is such a delight to have a considered debate about matters cultural, specifically regarding the National Gallery of Australia. The members for Cook and Hindmarsh spoke extremely well on behalf of the government. They have considered the legislation and again demonstrated their interest in and commitment to the National Gallery of Australia and, more generally, our cultural institutions. I also thank the members for Braddon and Burke for participating in the debate. I cannot say I agree with everything they said, but at least they had enough interest to participate in the debate.

speech.para: The member for Burke made some very good and sound points but then, sadly, blotted his copybook by straying into areas like the Industrial Relations Commission and the High Court and making some suggestion that the government makes appointments not on the basis solely of merit. It is disappointing that he should say that, but he did recognise the importance of the legislation before the parliament. In addressing some of the issues that members have raised, we should bear in mind that, when the gallery opened 20 years ago, the focus was clearly on acquisitions. But, over time, it is important for an established art museum to have the flexibility to implement its disposal policy even if in a small number of cases the work might be deemed to have a saleable value. If passed, and I presume it will be in both this place and the other, the proposed amendment will allow the gallery to gift works to other institutions, including regional galleries within Australia. I am glad emphasis has been put on that by the members contributing to the debate.

Currently, the National Gallery is forced to permanently loan works to recipient institutions by way of a series of loan agreements. This is not satisfactory as it does not enable long-term collections management planning for either the gallery or the recipient institution. The proposed amendment still requires the approval of the gallery council and then the minister for the arts before the works can be gifted. I respect the member for Burke's questioning of the safeguards inherent in this process. It hardly needs to be said that deacquisition is one of the most sensitive issues for any gallery or museum. No director or council makes these decisions quickly or without considerable thought. Given the transparency associated with the National Gallery of Australia especially, the deacquisition of any work is highly accountable at all levels, whether it be within the gallery's structures of management and council or outside the gallery in the parliament or the media.

There are no secrets with regard to the National Gallery of Australia when you have the Senate estimates poring over each and every aspect, whether minor or major, of the gallery's management and operations on a continuing basis—to the point where I would say that the Senate estimates questioning of the National Gallery of Australia in recent times has been merely mischievous and designed to slur the reputations of senior management staff. That saddens me. It is in stark contrast to the interesting and worthwhile debate we have had today in this chamber.

I believe that today's amendment is yet another on the growing list of achievements by Dr Brian Kennedy, the National Gallery's director. Dr Kennedy has been significantly and personally responsible for a whole range of reforms of immediate, short-term and long-term benefit to the gallery. There was the lifting of the ministerial approval for the acquisitions of the gallery from a limit of $1 million to $10 million. That was a vote of confidence and an investment of trust by the Howard government in Dr Kennedy and the gallery's management and council. There was the abolition of entry fees, which has been a reform followed by a number of state bodies and institutions. Dr Kennedy's success in increasing philanthropic donations to the gallery has been astounding—literally millions of dollars have come into the gallery for the first time for the express purpose of major new acquisitions. That is not a reflection on previous gallery efforts to increase the level of donations and private sector support, because it has to be said that we are, thanks to the government's initiatives, living in an environment which is much more friendly towards philanthropists and donors. In fact, we changed the tax laws very significantly in 1999, which has led to a rush of new donations of both finance and works.

Dr Kennedy's major acquisition program has created a lot of interest, although not always universal support—and how could there ever be, in the art world, total agreement on acquisitions? We know that Dr Kennedy has vitality, energy and knowledge which is refreshing and which has swept away a number of cobwebs that had, over a period of time, grown at the National Gallery, and perhaps in the art world more generally. He has never received sympathetic media coverage, and much of the reporting on Dr Kennedy and the gallery has been unfair and, on more than a few occasions, totally inaccurate. However, Dr Kennedy has a great many more admirers and supporters across the length and breadth of the nation and within the art world than he has detractors. When I was minister for the arts, I always found him to be a straight talker, passionate about Australian art and visionary in outlining the gallery's role, nationally and internationally. Above all else, I found him to be a very fine person, and I am personally as well as professionally disappointed when I hear critics in the Senate—who are dancing to someone else's tune—attack and criticise him.

It is not that he or the Gallery seeks to avoid such scrutiny but that, on my observations, the scrutiny is too often of a personal rather than professional kind. Dr Kennedy stands out amongst heads of cultural institutions across Australia, and he has some fierce competition. I think that the directors of most, if not all, of the state art galleries have extraordinary capabilities. I do not think it would be overstating the case to say that Australia is enjoying the best collection of national and state art gallery heads it has ever had. In Queensland there is Doug Hall, who is an outstanding director in every way, as is Alan Dodge of Western Australia. He is a man of enormous imagination, character and talent. There is Gerard Vaughan in Victoria, who has done a great deal to restore the National Gallery of Victoria to pre-eminence. In South Australia we have Ron Radford, whose irresistible charm and personality have led to extraordinary donations and support for his gallery. He is a man of great energy, experience and wisdom.

Then we come to Edmund Capon of New South Wales. I have had my differences with him in the past, but I admire him as a gallery director. I was disgusted and dismayed that he lowered the Australian flag when the conflict in Iraq started the other day. But I was much inspired by Bob Carr's personal intervention when, as reported, he rang Edmund Capon and said, `I will personally come over, raise that Australian flag and restore it to its place on top of the gallery if you don't.' Edmund Capon may not be the easiest person in the world to deal with on a number of fronts but there is no doubting the successful gallery he runs.

Brian Kennedy has to deal with these state directors, and not all of them make his life very easy. Sadly, I have to admit that some of them have been behind some of the stories. But all of them are interesting people. All of them are talented and world-class. As a result, art galleries across Australia are in excellent shape. So to Alan Dodge, Doug Hall, Gerard Vaughan and Ron Radford I send, by way of the parliament, my very best wishes. I have met with them on more than a few social occasions, and they are, like Brian Kennedy, excellent company.

In conclusion I address the member for Bourke's specific concern about the gifting of works to other galleries and what would happen if those galleries, in turn, gifted or even sold the works. The National Gallery will only gift a work to another institution when it is significant to that particular institution. The disposal policy, which I will table at the conclusion of my remarks, is so detailed and so careful that works are only going to leave the National Gallery of Australia under exceptional circumstances. Therefore, it can be assumed—given the policy as written, the attitude of the National Gallery on this issue and sensitivities throughout the art world—that the recipient institution will not just go ahead and sell or regift the item.

The gallery would not gift a work to just any institution without some link or need being identified. If that were the case the gallery could sell the item, which is permitted under the current legislation. Finally, I say to the member for Burke that the National Museum of Australia, the National Gallery of Victoria and the Art Gallery of New South Wales all have the ability to gift. This is excellent and timely legislation which will assist, over time, a large number of galleries, not least regional galleries. I thank all members again for contributing and I table the disposal policy of the National Gallery of Australia.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 December 2002, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is designed to amend the Criminal Code Act 1995 to re-enact federal counter-terrorism offences and thereby give them comprehensive national application. The bill will strengthen Australia's national antiterrorism laws. At the same time, it represents a significant development in cooperative Commonwealth-state relations. The bill will re-enact part 5.3of the Criminal Code, which contains federal terrorism offences enacted in June 2002 and as amended in October 2002, so as to attract the support of state references of power in accordance with section 51 (xxxvii) of the Constitution. These offence provisions were the subject of considerable debate within this parliament and were substantially amended by the opposition in negotiations with the government and during the debate in the Senate. They were eventually adopted with strong bipartisan support. Even the Prime Minister acknowledged that the legislation had been improved as a consequence of the debate.

speech.para: This bill would, in effect, re-enact the terrorism offences as Commonwealth provisions capable of operating throughout Australia without any potential limitations arising from existing limits on Commonwealth constitutional powers. The government has given a commitment that the substance of the current offences would not be affected, as the offences would be in the same terms as the current offences but for the constitutional `reading-down' provisions. This legislation has arisen from a concern that the scope of the terrorism offences currently in place is limited by their reference to the patchwork of existing Commonwealth constitutional powers relied upon. While this patchwork is extensive and includes the Commonwealth's defence and external affairs powers, the government is advised that it is also complex and that it is therefore impossible to rule out gaps in coverage. Any legal complexity or uncertainty could become a focus for litigation about the effectiveness of the new federal terrorism offences.

Consistent with the agreement at the leaders summit in April 2002, the states are making constitutional references to top up the Commonwealth's power so that the offences can have comprehensive national application. The bill assumes a twofold reference by the states. State reference legislation refers the text of the new federal terrorism offences in part 5.3 of the Criminal Code, together with a power to amend those offences. The first reference by each state of the text of the federal legislation ensures that the Commonwealth has power to validly enact that text as a comprehensive law of national application. The second reference—the amendment reference—ensures that the new federal legislation, once enacted, could be amended from time to time by the Commonwealth parliament. This transfer of powers follows a similar model to that used in other Commonwealth-state cooperative arrangements such as corporate law.

It should be noted, however, that this bill takes the `corporations model' of cooperative legislation schemes a step further, in that it reflects an agreement between the Commonwealth and the states and territories that future amendments will not be made without the approval of a majority of the states and territories and of at least four states. Under this model, once the Commonwealth and the states have agreed on the form of the legislation, the states progress the relevant bills through their parliaments. Commonwealth legislation should then accurately reflect the precise text of the bills passed by the states, meaning that the Commonwealth parliament should refrain from any amendment to the bill under consideration. This is also the reason why the Commonwealth can only enact this legislation after all the state and territory laws have been passed and commenced. References of power have now been passed or are awaiting assent in most Australian states. The timing in Victoria has been affected by last year's state election, and the bill is presently before the Victorian parliament.

This is an important measure designed to ensure that there are no constitutional loopholes in the fabric of our national antiterrorism legislation. The opposition are pleased to give bipartisan support to this legislation, as indeed we have to all measures which strengthen our nation's security while safeguarding the rights and liberties that Australians hold dear. Over the course of the past year, Labor have supported an extensive array of new antiterrorism legislation; however, where proposed legislation violates fundamental principles, as in the case with the current ASIO legislation amendment bill, Labor will stick to those principles and oppose what would be bad law. I made this position very clear in the debate on that bill in the House this morning. In this debate, however, I am pleased to commend the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. This bill will ensure that the government's terrorism offences will function without any potential limitations arising from existing limits on Commonwealth constitutional powers. The bill amends the Criminal Code Act 1995 to re-enact federal counter-terrorism offences, giving them comprehensive national application. The substance of the original measures will not be affected. The bill will re-enact part 5.3 of the Criminal Code so that it would attract the support of state references of power in accordance with section 51 of the Constitution. I think everyone in this House supports antiterrorism measures that are appropriate for dealing with our current situation. Obviously, the strengthening of the Criminal Code is appropriate in today's world. So I believe that all members support this bill and recognise its necessity.

speech.para: The background to the bill is that the government passed legislation giving effect to offences relating to terrorism acts, terrorist organisations and terrorist financing on 5 July 2002. These offences rely on a number of Commonwealth constitutional powers, and it is possible that any legal complexity may open the way for legal challenges undermining the effectiveness of these measures. The states agreed at the leaders summit in April 2002 to make constitutional references to complete the Commonwealth power so that counter-terrorism offences would have a comprehensive national application—and that is occurring for the first time.

The bill can be amended at a future date, but any such amendments will not be made without the approval of the majority of the states—at least four—and territories. The bill allows concurrent operation of state offences that might deal with similar activities so that there will be no displacement of state laws. This bill will assist in ensuring that the government's counter-terrorism package is fully effective, because the laws will be assured of operating constitutionally across the nation. The original package of counter-terrorism legislation was in response to September 11. The new and emerging threats to global security have made changes necessary.

There is no doubt that September 11 changed the world as we knew it and that significant antiterrorism measures have been implemented around the world. The threats were brought closer to home with the Bali bombings, which significantly affected the nation. From my electorate alone, four young people were killed—vibrant young people who were the life and soul of beach life in my electorate. Their funerals brought home to the many thousands who attended the reality of terrorism. We are talking about not theory but reality—about young people struck down in the prime of their life at 29 and 30 years of age and the devastation of their partners, lovers and parents. A very sad situation in particular was one family who had lost two members through the bombing—one died immediately and the other one had very severe burns to 75 per cent of her body. She was transferred to Perth and lived for over 60 days. Her mother was filled with hope that her daughter would recover. Despite the fantastic efforts made by the medical teams in Perth, the young woman finally succumbed to her very severe burns. I regularly see her mother in my electorate, and she is absolutely devastated. She cannot understand how she lost both her daughters in this terrible tragedy.

These acts touched the nation and brought us closer together. We should not forget Bali, as it highlights the need for Australians to work together to combat terrorism. I am, therefore, pleased to see the way in which the states have joined together with the federal government on this issue, referring some of their powers under the Constitution to ensure comprehensive and effective legislation. In respect of Bali, I was privileged to attend the Christian service in Kuta and was at the Sari site there, and it brought it home not only the effect on Australians but also the great impact on Indonesians. There were some 8,000 Indonesians at the service. They have been affected. Their tourism industry has been devastated—150,000 people in the tourism industry have been laid off. Millions of people are involved in the tourism industry.

The member for Curtin, who is here in the chamber, and I are involved in the Australia-Indonesia tourism dialogue, working to find ways of restoring the numbers of tourists in Bali. There is now a 30 per cent hotel occupancy rate, and that level has a devastating effect not only on those who run the hotels but on those who run the restaurants, shops, bazaars and all the activities around the Bali area. What has happened to the Balinese people—beautiful, wonderful people—is a great tragedy. They were shocked and frequently expressed to me their great regret at this occurring. It was also interesting to discuss the issue with the Indonesian Minister of Culture and Tourism during his recent visit to Sydney and discover his concern with what was happening. Most recently, at the ministerial dialogue that I had the privilege of witnessing in Jakarta, when the opportunity was provided for the various industry groups to speak, very high on the agenda were representatives from the tourism industry expressing their concern and asking for Australians to work together. Bali represents the tangible impact of terrorism. Terrorism can strike down Australians in the prime of life. This bill will do much to address the needs that we have for appropriate sanctions.

The government took significant steps in implementing a counter-terrorism package. The most important of these laws were the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002, the Criminal Code Amendment (Suppression of Terrorist Bombings) Act 2002 and the Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism Act 2002. These bills, along with subsequent amendments, have created the following terrorist offences in the Criminal Code: engaging in terrorist acts, providing or receiving training connected with a terrorist act, possessing an object connected with a terrorist act, collecting or making documents connected with a terrorist act, or doing anything in preparation for or planning a terrorist act. Provisions relating to terrorist organisations have also been inserted in the Criminal Code. The definition of such organisations is comprehensive and includes organisations that are directly or indirectly engaged in preparing, planning, assisting or fostering terrorist acts, and organisations that have been declared to be a terrorist organisation by way of regulation by the Governor-General and through the UN. Being a member of, or directing or recruiting to, such an organisation has also become an offence under the Criminal Code. This is part of a comprehensive approach to tackling the major issues, and the bill will ensure that the measures taken are as comprehensive as possible and adhere to the constitutional principles that this nation was founded on.

In conclusion, this bill is bringing together the states, codifying the power, transferring of some of the powers from the states to the Commonwealth and bringing it together in a comprehensive antiterrorism package to ensure that, wherever possible, appropriate steps are taken to ensure that terrorist acts do not occur in this country. We are in a world where there has been a significant paradigm shift in terms of people's attitudes and outlooks. September 11 changed the world as this generation knows it. Terrorism is part of our way of life. We must do all that we can in this parliament to ensure that we have a legislative basis to prevent, wherever possible, terrorism in this world and particularly in this country. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —In considering the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002, I want to put it in a historical context. The 1990s, seen in the rear-view mirror, now appear to have been almost a holiday from history. Like any holiday, it was most enjoyable but, by definition, holidays must end, and we have reached that point. The 21st century now seems to us as Australians a good deal darker and more dangerous than the decade that followed victory in the Cold War. This realisation, of course, is not unique to Australia. Recently, the President of the United States gave a convincing and positive presentation to the American Enterprise Institute on the subject of regime change in Baghdad. Interestingly, 10 years ago present Vice President Cheney, who was then the US Defense Secretary, spoke to the same institute. In the debate today, I want to remind the chamber of his words:

quote.para: We have turned inward as a nation and signed onto the proposition that the only truly important matters on the public policy agenda are domestic issues ... [and] we Republicans bear part of the responsibility for this state of affairs.

We are the ones who acquiesced last fall in the Democrats' assertion that the 1992 campaign for the Presidency should address domestic issues. We bought off on the notion that the public didn't want to hear about foreign policy and national security issues ...

But our first failing was in allowing ourselves and the American people to be lulled into a false sense of security—into believing that all is right with the world and that the end of the Cold War as we've known it for the last 40 years meant that it was safe to devote all our time and attention to domestic pursuits.

speech.para: That was in December 1993. Cheney's self-admonition was certainly prescient. History—the big picture questions of rival ideologies, foreign affairs and national security—has now returned with a vengeance in the form of international terrorism. The 1990s were setting the stage. The signs were already there. There were the bombings, including that by Iraqi agents against US posts in Jakarta and Manila in 1991. Other attacks included: the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires in 1992, the World Trade Centre in 1993, the grenade attack on the American Embassy in Moscow in 1995, the truck bomb used against the Egyptian Embassy in Pakistan that same year, the 1996 attacks on the Central Bank in Colombo by Tamil terrorists, the attacks on London and Manchester by the IRA, the attempts on the US embassy in Athens, on the Khobar Towers in Dhahran, on Tarragona International Airport in Spain, on the Paris Metro, the IRA bombing at Banbridge and Omagh in Ulster in 1998, a bombing at a Tajik church and a Manila shopping plaza in 2000, the bombing of the USS Cole that year and the 2001 car bombing at the BBC studios.

There was a spate of assassinations, including the unsuccessful attempt on former President Bush by Iraqi intelligence in 1993 and the murders of American diplomatic staff in Karachi in 1995, of the Archbishop of Oran in 1996, of the South Korean Consul in Vladivostok, of American businessmen visiting Pakistan in 1997 and of the British defence attache in Athens in 2000. There were shootings, including the Hebron massacre in February 1994, the attack at the Empire State Building in 1997 and the massacre of tourists at Luxor later that same year. There were the hijackings of an Air France flight to Algeria in 1994, of the Japanese embassy in Peru in 1996, of an Indian Airlines flight in 1999 and of an Ecuadorian helicopter in 2000. And there was also the sarin gas attack on Tokyo's subway in 1995 as well as constant kidnappings in Colombia and the steady escalation of deadly violence as a result of the Palestinian intifada, amongst other things.

The Chair of the Australian-Israeli Parliamentary Friendship Group, the member for Sturt, is here, and I commend him on arranging for members to hear a speech last evening by the former Prime Minister of Israel, Ehud Barak, who spoke most incisively of the terrorist threat to the world and of his support for the coalition action in Iraq—which he sees in terms of the convergence of the amassing of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of rogue states in defiance of the international community—and of how terrorism now poses the greatest security threat of the 21st century.

Now—post 11 September, Bali and numerous other murders, attacks, bombings and crimes across the globe—we all realise, as citizens and legislators, that further steps have to be taken by free people to defeat this scourge of terrorism. An important part of the defensive against that threat is the legislation before us today—the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. This legislation will ensure that the antiterrorism provisions—the terrorist act offences provisions, terrorist organisation offences provisions and terrorism financing offences provisions—that were enacted in June and amended in October 2002 by this parliament will be as constitutionally sound as possible. While the bill does not alter the substance of the laws, it will safeguard them against future constitutional challenge, in line with the intention of the agreement reached by federal, state and territory governments in April of last year and the details fleshed out by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. As such, the bill effectively re-enacts part 5.3 of the Criminal Code to support the Commonwealth laws with state references of power under section 51 (xxxvii) of the Constitution. Section 51 (xxxvii) states:

quote.para: Matters referred to the Parliament of the Commonwealth by the Parliament or Parliaments of any State or States, but so that the law shall extend only to States by whose Parliaments the matter is referred, or which afterwards adopt the law

speech.para: Thus the section contains the two powers of reference and adoption. This is probably one of the sections of the Constitution that excites only constitutional lawyers, but it does provide a way of achieving statutory uniformity of terrorist legislation without having to go down the section 128 path—the constitutional referenda—or cooperative legislative scheme path. This reference will have a twofold character, in that state legislation will refer the text of part 5.3, and the associated power, to the Commonwealth. The other part will allow this parliament to amend the laws, within the context of the federal-state agreement that future amendments be agreed to by the majority of states and territories, with a further proviso that the amendments be supported by at least four states. The bill also includes provisions to prevent the inadvertent displacement of state laws and in relation to transitional issues.

The Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is a very valuable tool for Australian counter-terrorism; however, it is not the only measure being undertaken by this government, as is evident from the National Security Information Campaign. The federal government has, since September 2001, substantially increased the number of officers of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. A 24-hour ASIO monitoring and alert facility has been established and closer links have been forged with foreign intelligence services.

The establishment of a new Special Operations Command, dedicated to counter-terrorism, has strengthened the Australian Defence Force. More counter-terrorism personnel have been allocated to the SAS—based in Swanbourne in my electorate of Curtin—and to other special forces. A 300-strong incident response group has been created to deal with the threats posed by chemical, biological and radiological threats. The Australian Federal Police have also been placed on the front line of counter-terrorism, with extensive new resources, overseas based investigators and greater multinational cooperation.

Baggage and passenger screening has been significantly upgraded, with more Australian Protective Service officers and sniffer dogs at our airports and armed security officers in the skies. Likewise, Australian Customs requirements have been made even more stringent, thanks to a new X-ray facility and state-of-the-art facial imaging identification equipment. Emergency services have been upgraded to deal with the potential threats of new weapons employed by terrorists. Antibiotics, vaccines, anti-viral drugs and chemical antidotes have been stockpiled, and a detailed National Counter-Terrorism Plan has been put into place should—God forbid—terrorist attacks be undertaken against Australia.

Sixteen months after the atrocities in the United States and five months after the murder of 89 Australians in Bali, there are the beginnings of some successes as a result of counter-terrorism offensives. Earlier this month we saw the arrest in Pakistan of a Kuwaiti, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. Mohammed was one of al-Qaeda's most influential lieutenants and his capture was a great victory. It is to be hoped that the information he holds will lead to many more such arrests in pursuance of the war against terrorism. It is against that background and in that spirit that I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to rise today to speak on the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. It is an important piece of legislation, and I am very pleased that it is being debated here in the Main Committee. The reason that pleases me is that, if it is in the Main Committee, there is bipartisan support behind this legislation. The people of Australia should take comfort in the fact that there is bipartisan support for this legislation. In so many different ways, it is important that we as parliamentarians send a clear message back to our electorates that we are working in a combined and coordinated way to overcome the scourge that is modern-day terrorism.

speech.para: An important part of overcoming this scourge is the government's A Safer and More Secure Australia policy that it took to the 2001 election. As part of that policy, the government stated that it would, if re-elected, convene a leaders summit to seek outcomes on: (1) ways to improve Australia's ability to combat transnational crime and terrorism; (2) develop options for reforming or replacing the National Crime Authority to ensure we have a national body fully equipped to deal with future transnational criminal activities; and (3) provide a reference of constitutional power to the Commonwealth to support an effective national response to threats of transnational crime and terrorism.

This bill forms part of that third limb, but I will make some brief comments with regard to the second limb; that is, developing the options to replace the National Crime Authority. As a number of speakers prior to me have said in this debate, the world did change on September 11. It heralded the beginning of a substantial shift to the new threat and risk paradigm of a combination of the armies of nation states of old and the individuals of terrorist organisations of new. That is the new threat environment in which we must develop laws and agencies that are flexible enough to meet the fluid challenges of one, two or three people being involved in a terrorist organisation versus the old threat of an entire army.

The National Crime Authority was the front-line vehicle that was historically used but, in recognition of the fact that there is now a new threat environment within this country and internationally, we have had to develop a new body. The creation of the Australian Crime Commission was the way in which the Australian government responded very proactively to this new threat.

I note that the member for Dickson has just joined us and I know that he, as a member of the Joint Statutory Committee on the Australian Crime Commission, has done a lot of work in this area. I am certainly hearing from a number of people both within government and in the community that they are pleased to see the Australian Crime Commission operating effectively and at the forefront of a number of new initiatives that are taking place in law enforcement within Australia.

With regard to the third limb—the reference of constitutional power to the Commonwealth—this bill is the embodiment of that reference. The central element of the Commonwealth and state legislative package that was agreed to at the leaders summit in April 2002 was, in substance, this bill. This bill draws on references of state power to re-enact the terrorism offences enacted last year. It does this because there is an important and necessary need to tie any possible loose ends together.

The legislation which the federal government introduced created a number of offences in relation to terrorist acts, terrorist organisations and terrorist financing. These offences were based on existing Commonwealth constitutional powers. However, because the Commonwealth does not have a vast array of powers that expressly relate to terrorism offences, it has been necessary to develop a patchwork of different powers in order to introduce the laws. The simple fact is that these new laws are extensive and complex. It is impossible to rule out the possibility that there may be a legislative lacuna that could cause unforeseen problems for the Commonwealth and be exploited by those seeking to avoid prosecution. As a consequence, it has been necessary to develop this reference of powers by the states. The enactment of the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 will rule out the problem of a legislative lacuna.

This bill ensures comprehensive national application of the federal counter-terrorism offences. As a number of members speaking in this debate have said, it operates to re-enact part 5.3 of the Criminal Code—the part that contains terrorism offences—such that now it will attract the support of the state references of power. This is provided for under the Commonwealth Constitution in section 51(xxxvii). This is an important but rarely used section of the Constitution, and the government seeks to have it operate now in relation to this bill to ensure that we get widespread coverage as a result of this legislation. Once this bill is enacted it will re-enact those terrorism provisions so as to provide blanket coverage. It means that our terrorism offences will be capable of operating throughout Australia without any potential limitations arising from existing limits on Commonwealth constitutional powers. An important realisation, as well, is the fact that this bill provides for concurrent operation of state offences that might deal with similar types of activity. In no way does the Commonwealth seek to cover the field in this particular area. What it does seek is to work cooperatively with state governments to ensure that Commonwealth legislation is uniform and also respect the fact that states have jurisdictional rights to enforce powers in the same area.

This bill, as I mentioned, is part of a counter-terrorism legislative package that delivers on this government's commitment to ensuring the best possible protection for the people of Australia against those who would commit such egregious acts. The safety and security of all Australians are absolutely instrumental. Western democracies have at their very core liberty and freedom, and an important component of liberty and freedom is the ability to feel secure. I contend that they are mutually inclusive: if you cannot feel secure you cannot possibly have liberty and freedom. You must have both.

On that basis, it is important that we have in place laws that go to the core of addressing people's existing concerns about whether Australia could fall victim to the type of terrorist activity we saw on September 11. Indeed as a nation we have fallen victim: on October 12 in Bali. Whilst the Bali attack was a strike on Australians, it did not occur on home soil. I am sure that is reassuring for some, but it is not the position of the government to be too complacent about these issues. Accordingly, it is important that we have this type of legislation in place to provide the safety that people are looking for. Not only do Australians want to feel safe in their homes, safe in their cities and safe as they go about their daily lives but that safety is a crucial component of the long-term economic wellbeing of Australia. Industries such as the tourism industry—which I would highlight—are fundamentally reliant on the long-term safety and stability of our nation. The tourism industry is vital to a city such as the one I represent: the Gold Coast.

talk.start.para: —A fine city!

—It is a fine city, and I thank the member for Sturt for that interjection. The Gold Coast is rapidly growing. It is the fastest growing city in Australia. The tourism industry is an absolutely vital component of our city, accounting for some 37 per cent of local GDP.
—A wonderful figure!
(Ms Gambaro)—I thank the honourable member for Sturt for his enthusiasm.

—On that basis it is important that this piece of legislation assist the tourism industry to send the message internationally that tourists will be safe when they come to Australia. We can flippantly look at this type of legislation as not being directly tied to the long-term benefit of the tourism industry. But the fundamental fact, as we heard from the member for Cook, is that, if an act were committed within Australia that shook the tourism industry to its foundations, it would have a vastly negative impact on the tourism industry on a long-term basis. When you consider that tourism is our second-largest export industry, accounting for some $24 billion—
—Madam Deputy Speaker, will my honourable friend give way to a question?
—No, the give-way rule has not been renewed. It concluded at the end of last year.
—I thought it had been renewed this year.

—No, we have not yet resumed the give-way rule, but at a discussion of the Speakers Panel the other evening we considered whether we would reintroduce it. So I cannot give way to the member for Sturt on this occasion, as much as I would like to.

—As I indicated, the tourism industry accounts for some $24 billion in exports. It is our second largest export industry. The member for Cook, who spoke earlier in this debate, said that the tourism industry in Bali has been completely destroyed as a consequence of the terrorist act that took place there. The simple fact is that if an act like that did occur in Australia we could, for a very long period, say goodbye to the exports that we generate through tourism. I am very pleased, as the member for Moncrieff, to stand in this chamber this morning and say that this legislation goes directly to the core of ensuring that the people of Australia not only feel safe as they go about their business but also recognise that we are on the lookout to ensure that there is long-term economic growth in industries such as tourism—the kind of growth that can be sustained and protected through legislation like this. I commend this bill to the House. It is an important component of the federal government's terrorist legislation. It is simply one additional tier and one additional response to the way the federal government is ensuring that the long-term safety and security of all Australians is protected against the current terrorist activity.

—The Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is a key element in the government's legislative package on counter-terrorism—a package of legislation that has seen the government move quickly and decisively to prepare laws that will ensure Australians are protected against the evils of terrorism. Following the dreadful devastation committed in the United States in September 2001 and, in particular, following the sickening attacks in Bali last year, I believe our Australian community spirit has only strengthened. The Australian public has a mentality of never give in, and certainly our resolve as a government and as a people to protect our way of life has again only been strengthened. In this spirit, the Australian people understand that it is crucial that we are able to identify, prevent and, if necessary, punish those who would harm or threaten to harm our families, our friends and our communities.

speech.para: The government have already developed a range of measures to provide our security and law enforcement agencies with the tools they need to do just this. Since the horrific attacks of the past two years, the government have shown their commitment to improving our national security and protecting all Australians by providing a number of measures. Firstly, we have increased intelligence capability, including more ASIO investigators and overseas intelligence officers, more resources for ASIS and a 24-hour ASIO monitoring and alert facility. Secondly, we have upgraded Federal Police capability, which includes new joint and federal, state and territory police counter-terrorist investigation teams and a new counter-terrorist coordination centre. Thirdly, we have strengthened defence forces with additional highly trained counter-terrorist personnel in our special forces, a further counter-terrorist Tactical Assault Group and a 300-strong incident response regiment with specialist skills and equipment to deal with chemical, biological, radiological and explosive threats.

This government has also acted to upgrade emergency services, tighten border controls, improve security for air travellers and protect our critical infrastructure. As I speak today, the Australian defence forces are engaged in the difficult conflict in Iraq, working in the Australian interest to rid the dreadful Saddam Hussein of his weapons of mass destruction and to ensure that terrorists are not able to acquire and use these weapons against innocent people, including Australians.

Our goal today is to ensure that our security and intelligence agencies have the capability to do their absolute best to protect Australians at home. And we are almost there. Last year, the government introduced a package of legitimate legislation to ensure that law enforcement and security agencies had this capability. We inserted new provisions in the Criminal Code to make it an offence, punishable by life imprisonment, to murder, commit manslaughter or intentionally or recklessly cause serious harm to an Australian outside Australia. We amended security legislation to make it an offence to engage in a terrorist act and be a member of a terrorist organisation. We made it an offence to provide or collect funds for a terrorist organisation and it was this government that amended the Telecommunications (Interception) Act so that people suspected of terrorist related activities could be better investigated. And we are still working to give ASIO an enhanced capability to investigate and combat terrorism.

Obviously, we are a government which is completely committed to protecting the Australian people from all manifestations of terrorist activity. You only have to look at our dedication to removing weapons of mass destruction from the regime in Iraq to appreciate that. Today we need to pass this amendment to the Criminal Code to ensure that our new legislative framework is fully effective. The current federal terrorism offences contained in part 5.3 of the Criminal Code, which are offences relating to terrorist acts, terrorist organisations and terrorist financing, commenced on 5 July 2002.

The scope of those offences is limited, by reference, to the mix of existing Commonwealth constitutional powers they rely on. These constitutional powers are extensive but they are also complex, and it is impossible to rule out that there may be some gaps in coverage. Any legal complexity or uncertainty could potentially become a focus for litigation about the effectiveness of the new federal terrorism offences. That is why the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 is important, because it will assist in ensuring that the new legislative framework is fully effective by enabling comprehensive and national coverage.

The bill will in effect re-enact the terrorist offences in division 101, the terrorist organisation offences in division 102, and the financing of terrorism offences in division 103. Once re-enacted, terrorism offences will be capable of operating throughout Australia without any potential limitations arising from existing limits on Commonwealth constitutional powers. The government is committed to ensuring that our laws are as watertight as possible, and this bill and the referral of powers by the states will do just that. They will rule out arguments about potential gaps in the Commonwealth's power in certain specific circumstances. The states will have referred powers to the Commonwealth so that there can be no question about the legitimacy of the laws.

This bill signals a new commitment of cooperation between the states and the federal government in the fight against crime and terrorism. At this time I would like to make mention of the newly formed Australian Crime Commission, the body that has taken over from the National Crime Authority. My friend from Moncrieff spoke briefly about the Australian Crime Commission in his closing comments. I commend him on the efforts he has made in respect of the support that he has provided to the police agencies, both federal and state, in the seat of Moncrieff on the Gold Coast, south of Brisbane. It is indicative of the support we are seeing now and the cooperation that is taking place between the federal and respective state and territory governments.

The Australian Crime Commission at its very core aims to do just that—to provide a working relationship, to try and eliminate duplication between the states and the Commonwealth and to try and provide for a safer and more harmonious community, which is one of the great objectives of this government. The Australian people believe very strongly in providing for and securing our way of life; it is at the heart of the Australian way. The Australian Crime Commission, in my opinion—and certainly the body that preceded it, the National Crime Authority—goes a long way towards serving that purpose.

Today I wanted to take the opportunity to pay tribute to the many people—the investigators, the operatives, the intelligence analysts and the staff generally—who are attached to the Australian Crime Commission and to commend the efforts that they undertake on a daily basis in the overall aim of providing sound protection to the people of Australia. This bill delivers on the government's commitment to ensure that we are in the best possible position to protect Australians against the evils of terrorism. For that reason I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that everyone in our community wants to feel safe. All Australians want to feel secure in their own country. Of course we do not want terrorism here and of course we want our law enforcement bodies to have the legal powers necessary to deal with those who plan, finance or carry out terrorist activities. The Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002 forms a small part of the Howard government's commitment to the war on terrorism and potential terrorism in Australia. It does not introduce new concepts or radical changes to the existing laws; it simply tidies up a couple of bills passed by this parliament last year. You might say that it is simply good housekeeping.

speech.para: The aim of this bill is to eliminate some gaps and uncertainties from existing laws. More than that, it is an expression of the cooperation between states and territories and the Commonwealth to ensure comprehensive national application of the law on terrorism offences so that it is not a piecemeal patchwork or uncertain. Australians are certain that they do not want terrorism here; therefore, we do not want uncertainty in our laws regarding terrorism offences. Obviously our world has changed since September 11 and the events in Bali, and our legal system needs to be reviewed to reflect that change, to include safeguards against previously unforeseen crimes against both our people and our society. This parliament has demonstrated its awareness of that need, as a result of which it passed last year a number of laws dealing with terrorism, including amendments to the Criminal Code and the Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism Act 2002.

As we all know, section 51 of the Constitution gives this parliament the power to legislate for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth in a list of areas. That list does not include terrorism, because 100 years ago it was incomprehensible on the scale we know now. The technological and social changes that support the spread of terrorist groups were simply unheard of or undreamed of by our forefathers. This means that, with the best intent in the world, the current federal terrorism offences which were inserted into part 5.3 of the Criminal Code last July rely on a patchwork of existing constitutional powers. This patchwork of powers is extensive but also very complex, so it is impossible to rule out unforeseen gaps. This complexity and the possibility of gaps means uncertainty, and that uncertainty could become the focus of litigation regarding not only individual terrorism offences but also the effectiveness of all such legislation. We do not want our law enforcement agencies wasting resources, time and money on bringing terrorists to justice only to have some court set them free on an uncertainty. When this parliament passes legislation, surely it means it to be enforced, not disputed in courts as a means of avoiding conviction for offences contained in the legislation. That is the crux of this bill.

In presenting its `safer and more secure Australia' policy before the last election, the Howard government said that it would convene a leaders summit aimed at more effectively combating transnational crime and terrorism. This summit of Commonwealth, state and territory leaders was held in Canberra in April last year. At the summit the Prime Minister and all state and territory leaders agreed, regardless of politics, firstly, on the need for comprehensive national coverage of terrorism offences and, secondly, on the steps necessary to achieve the constitutional basis for this national coverage. This bill is designed to implement that important agreement. Because terrorism is not listed under the Commonwealth jurisdiction in section 51 of the Constitution, to enact its counter-terrorism statute the Commonwealth has had to rely on a raft of legislative powers. That is not constitutionally secure. However, under section 51 the states can choose to refer powers in a particular matter to the Commonwealth parliament. At the leaders summit all the states agreed to do this, to ensure that we have a very strong constitutional basis on which to enact national laws against terrorism offences.

New South Wales, South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia have already enacted their referral statutes. In his second reading speech, the Attorney-General expressed his appreciation of the states' efforts in responding quickly to the national need. The new Commonwealth provisions will not commence until a date to be proclaimed, to ensure that all states have enough time to complete their references. Once the legislation is enacted, section 100.8 will ensure that it is not frozen and that it can be amended by parliament in response to evolving security needs.

Having established the aim and basis of this legislation—that is, enacting the states' agreement to refer power to the Commonwealth to ensure a strong constitutional base for legislation against terrorism—let us look at the rest of the bill. Part 5.3 of the Criminal Code, which contains the terrorism offences, was enacted in June last year and amended in October. The bill before us simply re-enacts that part of the Criminal Code so that constitutionally it attracts the support of the states' reference of power. It does not affect the substance of the current offences, and the re-enactment offences are in the same words. Once this bill is enacted, part 5.3 of the Criminal Code can operate throughout Australia without concerns about potential litigation based on constitutional authority. As I said at the beginning, it is simply good housekeeping to tidy up the gaps in the existing legislation.

The terrorism offences found in division 101 of the Criminal Code were inserted by the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002. The bill before us replicates the existing provisions because it is important that they are supported by the referred power of the states to eliminate potential gaps through which terrorists could escape conviction. The same applies for division 102, which deals with offences by terrorist organisations rather than individuals. However, there are two major amendments in section 102.1. There is some renumbering, and new subsections of 102.1 have been inserted to ensure that there is no gap in legislative cover between the two acts.

Let us look at some of the activities that we are ensuring will be categorised as terrorism offences anywhere in Australia. They include engaging in a terrorist act, providing or receiving training connected with a terrorist act, possessing anything connected with a terrorist act, preparing or planning a terrorist act, recruiting a person to join a terrorism organisation, funding a terrorist organisation or receiving funds from it, or providing support or resources to assist terrorist activity. These activities have to be intentional. None of them are terrorist offences under the legislation if they happen as part of a protest or industrial action or if they are not intended to cause harm or create a serious risk to public health or safety. Section 101.1 ensures this. Such acts may still be criminal offences when they hurt people or property, but they are not terrorist offences under this legislation. Acts of terrorism do not just harm individual targets or bystanders; they damage the economic and social welfare of our society and the security of our children's environment.

This parliament has already passed legislation establishing that activities such as those I have just mentioned are terrorist offences punishable by law. We are now seeking certainty in that law. The Commonwealth and state leaders have all agreed—and I believe the people of Australia would also agree—that we want the courts to decide if a person is guilty of a terrorism act or offence. We do not want terrorists using the courts to question the constitutional validity of the law itself to escape conviction. Let us all work together for a safe Australia. I definitely commend this bill to the House.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr WILLIAMS
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —in reply—I would like to thank members who have spoken in the debate on the Criminal Code Amendment (Terrorism) Bill 2002. As the government has indicated, the bill is the central element of the Commonwealth and state legislative package to implement the April 2002 leaders summit agreement. At the summit, leaders agreed on the importance of comprehensive national coverage of terrorism offences. Leaders agreed to refer power to the Commonwealth to support national coverage. The enactment of this bill will ensure comprehensive national application of the federal counter-terrorism offences enacted last year. The bill draws on references of state power in re-enacting these terrorism offences. The existing offences rely on a patchwork of existing constitutional powers. The reference of power by the states and the enactment of this bill will rule out any uncertainty, however slight, arising from unforeseen gaps in coverage offered by offences based on existing constitutional powers.

speech.para: There is only one matter I want to refer to in relation to the debate, and that is a point that was made by the honourable member for Banks, a point that he has made on a number of occasions. He highlighted the success in the enactment of the federal counter-terrorism legislation in July of last year, mentioning the cooperation between the government and the opposition in reaching agreement. The point that he seeks to make out of that is that we have not reached agreement on the ASIO bill because the government has not agreed to the Labor Party's amendments. There is a point of difference, and that is that the agreement reached in July last year in relation to the counter-terrorism offences legislation resulted in a workable bill. The proposals put forward by the opposition in relation to the ASIO bill would result in an unworkable bill. It is on that basis that the government is not accepting the Labor Party amendments. We hope that in the debate in the Senate we will get the cooperation of the Labor Party in reaching agreement on an appropriate bill that will provide a workable and potent set of tools for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to prevent and deter terrorist acts within Australia.

Since September 11, the Howard government has acted swiftly to introduce new policy measures and legislation and to provide more resources for our security and intelligence agencies to bolster Australia's ability to combat terrorism. Last year's attacks in Bali have strengthened the government's resolve to complete this exercise as a matter of urgency. The Commonwealth, in respect of this exercise, appreciates the states' efforts in responding to the national need and referring the power necessary to support the enactment of the bill. The bill is part of the counter-terrorism package that delivers on the government's commitment to ensure we are in the best possible position to protect Australians against the threat of terrorism. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

motion.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Rick is a family man and a constituent of mine in my electorate of Bass. He has been a continuous member of a private health fund for 22 years and considers himself to be a middle- to high-income earner. He recently received a letter from his health insurer advising him that his premium will rise by $91 per month from 1 April 2003. This represents an increase of 42 per cent. Rick and his family are now very seriously considering leaving the private health insurance system; they simply cannot absorb such increases as this into the family budget. He tells me that many of his friends and colleagues are considering taking the same path.

speech.para: Another constituent has advised me that his premiums have increased by 78 per cent over the last 12 months, the latest rise being a whopping 62 per cent. He was previously paying $112.20 for himself and his wife each month; he now has to somehow find $181.30 per month. A further constituent is faced with a new premium of $209.30 per month, up from $147.30 previously. That is just a sample. It goes on from here, on from there, case after case.

The first pages of a petition from anxious constituents has arrived in my office. I am quite sure that it will be the first of very many to follow. I have constituents who are not only angry but really hurting over these increases. The reality is that the system is not working; it is ordinary Australians who are paying the price, and it is a very big price. These recent increases are obscene.

The insurance industry and this government must be held to account for the financial strain they are placing on Australian families. They were the ones who encouraged Australians to maintain or sign up for private health insurance. They said that the government rebate was a magic potion to make private health insurance attractive and affordable. It is neither; it is in fact a disaster. It is a drain on the pockets of ordinary Australians—families, battlers, the mums and dads. Characterise them however you choose to, but whatever you call them they are still faced with the same problem: rapidly rising private health insurance premiums, alongside a rapidly disintegrating Medicare program. My constituents feel that the private health insurance industry is being callous and opportunistic by increasing premiums for profit in an environment in which Australians are being encouraged to take out private insurance with the incentive of the federal government's rebate. In the opinion of my constituents, the 30 per cent rebate has effectively been wiped out by the previous and current price rises.

What is the likely outcome of all of this, without any action on behalf of the Howard government? There is no doubt now that thousands of Australian families will either be forced out of private health insurance completely or find themselves faced with increased financial pressures and family debt as they try to stay in the system with unaffordable costs. This will of course have the effect of putting more Australians onto queues for public hospitals, for the public dental health system and for all other such medical services. As I advised this House on a number of previous occasions, there is already a huge shortage of available medical services in my electorate. Fewer than 50 per cent of visits to doctors have been bulk-billed. We have doctors who are closing their books and who are not taking on any new clients—and now they are saying that they are unable to recognise the gold card for veteran patients. We have a declining public health base through the funding arrangements from the federal government and, at the same time, an unaffordable option of private health insurance. We are not a Third World country but we are heading rapidly towards having a third-rate health system. This is unacceptable, and I call upon the government to act immediately to support those Australians whom it lured into the private health system.

In the time remaining to me I want to touch on the approach to policy and the role taken by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and his department. I find it frustrating that we see absolutely no action from this minister for huge amounts of time and then, all of a sudden, the people in his department have a sudden rush of blood as they realise that they have done no work, they have got no new action happening and they have got no new policies occurring so we get a flurry of bills coming through. Today we saw four new bills from the transport portfolio suddenly turn up in parliament. These bills are to do with aviation transport security and civil aviation issues. So we get four new bills this morning in a complete rush of blood. We have on the list a whole swag of pollution at sea, protection of the sea, ships of shame and other environmental protection documents—simply because the minister has suddenly thought he had better do something about this, as he has simply been not doing anything. My concern is that we have a minister who either does not care enough to understand what is going on and therefore is being incompetent or does care and simply does not choose to do anything. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to put squarely on the table this afternoon that it is time the people of Townsville and Thuringowa got a fair go from the state government in relation to their health services. I have reached the end of my tether with the chronic underfunding and the chronic mismanagement of the health portfolio in Townsville. Townsville has a level 6, state-of-the-art, world-class hospital; yet, week after week, month after month, dreadful stories, which have a significant basis in fact, keep appearing in the press about problems at the Townsville hospital. It is just not good enough that these problems go on and on. The state government is not meeting its responsibilities to the people of Townsville and Thuringowa by allowing these problems to go on and on. We have got three Labor state members in Townsville. They do not seem to be able to say to their government, `We've got to look after the people of Townsville and Thuringowa; we can't allow these problems to continue.'

speech.para: Let me give you some examples. When the hospital was constructed, it was decided that a 24-hour ambulance station would be put in the hospital. That took up much needed space from the design of the emergency department. It is still not running as an ambulance station. It sits there and does nothing. It takes up the space of the emergency department; it makes it crowded and staff have to put people on beds in corridors. It also lengthens the response times of ambulances when they are called out on emergencies.

Look at the step-down facility. There are people who really should be out of hospital and in a step-down facility in the adjoining building—there is no will to allow that to happen. The state government will not allow officers of their hospital to talk to the officers of the federal government. The hospital officers would love to see it happen but the state government will not allow it. I know that the district manager of the hospital must be extraordinarily frustrated that his hands are tied. The spinal pain unit is another example—it goes on and on. Nobody yet seems to know exactly what the new version of the spinal pain unit will be. Meanwhile, patients are left to suffer, and we all know that back pain is probably one of the worst sorts of pains that you can have.

We have the waiting lists. The GPs of Townsville tell me—and I am not being emotive in this, I am just stating the facts—that people are dying on waiting lists. We cannot allow that to continue. Something has to be done about that, but the state government is hiding the true state of the waiting lists. The GPs will tell you. A GP writes to the hospital and says, `I would like you to see patient X,' and the hospital's technique is to not respond. So that person is on a phantom waiting list and never becomes part of the official numbers, but nevertheless they are there. Or a patient will be put on a list for procedures and at the last minute that particular procedure gets cancelled and they have to wait to get back on the list again—therefore, they become another phantom statistic that does not appear in the official figures.

I think it is extraordinarily poor and unacceptable that the state government should treat our community this way. I invite anybody to go to the hospital pharmacy one day and see what happens. You go to a normal pharmacy these days and you can get service within two minutes. It is not uncommon to wait for three-quarters of an hour or an hour just because the hospital will not pay its pharmacists what the market pays them. Therefore, patients suffer. Look at what they have been doing in relation to the cardiac unit. They are writing to all the GPs saying, `Look, let's have all the private patients over here who can pay, and in that way we'll have a two-class hospital: those who can pay and those who can't.' Again you cause further problems for people who are on waiting lists who cannot get procedures that they need.

I am not prepared any longer to suffer the treatment that Queensland Health deals out to the people of Townsville and Thuringowa. I am going to be very active in trying to make sure that these problems are addressed and addressed immediately.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of a coalition of social justice groups and at the request of the member for Fremantle, the Hon. Carmen Lawrence, I am pleased to present the following petitions. These petitions are an appeal for grace and call on the federal government to grant permanent residence to all refugees currently on temporary protection visas who have been law abiding, and also to release into the community all asylum seekers who are not a health or security concern. I am particularly pleased to be submitting these petitions at this point in time. The purpose was to present them to parliament before Easter.

speech.para: I would also like to talk about two major events that I attended in my electorate of Calwell on the weekend that were associated with the celebration of Harmony Day. As everyone in this place would know, Harmony Day, 21 March, is a great opportunity to celebrate the wealth and the strength of our contemporary multicultural identity. Calwell is one of those electorates steeped in cultural and linguistic diversity; it has historically been at the forefront of migrant and refugee settlement. In Calwell we celebrate Harmony Day each year with great pride and a sense of great achievement because our diverse community has achieved much to be proud of.

I had the opportunity last Friday to attend a Harmony Day celebration at the Broadmeadows Secondary College. This was a celebration conducted in partnership with the Victorian Arabic Social Services. The college community organised a multicultural day which was filled with many activities and events. It was a day of mixed emotions, however, because that was also the day that war commenced in Iraq—and about one-third of the students at the school are from Iraqi backgrounds. The school is very sensitive to the difficulties experienced by children of refugee backgrounds. I would like to acknowledge the very special role that the staff play in helping these children adjust in their new home.

We were welcomed at the assembly by hundreds of students, who acquitted themselves admirably as they were subjected to speech after speech from politicians. It was a special day also because the school chose Harmony Day to launch its multicultural charter. Appropriately, it was launched by Hume City Council's Arabic background councillor, Councillor Mohamad Abbouche.

Following that official part of the day's events we all went outside to the school oval and the students released hundreds of orange balloons as a sign of celebration and commitment to their diversity. I would like to say that we managed to get the balloons launched just in time before our permit ran out, because the airport is in my electorate and we have to be mindful of the flight path restrictions. The students felt that was quite cute—that we managed to get them up just before some plane flew overhead.

The future of our society is based on the strength and the conviction of our young people. The staff of Broadmeadows Secondary College, under the leadership of its principal, Mrs Marlene Robinson, and in partnership with the community and community leaders such as Ms Leila Alloushi, understand and appreciate the value of our diversity. But more importantly they are instilling in their students a sense of pride about themselves, a pride that will lead to a sense of confidence and that will also help students make a great contribution to this community.

The second event I attended on Sunday in celebration of Harmony Day was at the Calabria Club in my electorate in the suburb of Bulla. This event was held for the first time this year and its aim was to bring together a number of communities to celebrate Harmony Day. I want to start by congratulating the President of the Calabria Club, Mr Vince Danielli, and the members of his committee, and I also want to thank Mr Brian Shanahan, who, in addition to being the President of the Celtic Club of Victoria, was also instrumental in organising this very successful event.

It is important to note that the communities which took part in this event were a combination of the older established communities, such as the very large Italian community in my electorate and the Cypriot community, and some of the newer communities—in particular the Assyrian community which is settling in Calwell. The day's event included a junior soccer tournament. We were treated to Italy's trademark sport, bocce. I must confess that I did not fare very well in my attempt to play bocce. We were also treated to a whole series of folkloric dancing all the way from Crete and to music from the Middle East and southern Italy.

This was a fantastic convergence of our multicultural community but it makes a more important statement. It shows that these diverse communities are not only living together harmoniously but also sharing each other's facilities—in this case, the Calabria Club, whose members, who have worked hard over the years to build this wonderful facility, are now making it available to other newer communities who are not yet able to provide for their own accommodation. That was one of the highlights of the day—this working together and sharing together. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—Before I call the honourable member for Ryan, I need to point out to the honourable member for Calwell that unfortunately under standing order 117B petitions cannot be tabled during the adjournment debate. The standing order states:

quote.para: A Member may present a petition during the period of Members' statements under standing order 106A or 275A.

interjection.para: You could ask for leave to table the petition as a notice but it will be treated as a paper and not a petition; or it could be tabled at the Table Office as a petition.

talk.start.para: —I will table it at the Table Office.

—I am delighted to rise in the parliament today to speak about a very special project. I am delighted also to see that my friend and colleague the member for Dickson is here because he will take interest in the topic that I wish to speak about. I wish to speak about the multicultural cricket program that is being run by the Queensland Cricket Association and which is very heavily supported and sponsored by this government's department of multicultural affairs and citizenship.

speech.para: Cricket is an established international sport that embraces a wide variety of cultural backgrounds.
