We only need to look at the subcontinent and Africa, where countries such as India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Kenya are at the forefront of developing cricket in those parts of the world. Most of the Asian countries also have national teams. As such, cricket is an ideal vehicle to bring together many different cultures and people generally. It is something that I commend very strongly in the Australian community.

The MCC—or Multi Cultural Cricket project—works to use sport as a tool to break down barriers of racial prejudice and cultural ignorance. It has the potential to breed a new component into the definition of cricket—which is seen to be the Australian game for all Australians. This project involves the establishment of Multi Cultural Cricket project's Have-A-Go program centres, involving children between the ages of seven and 10. They learn cricket skills, the ideas and notions of discipline and teamwork, and some of the great values that are associated with the game of cricket. During the conduct of these programs, parents also have the capacity to be involved and to encourage their kids to get involved and learn about the values I mentioned above, including sportsmanship. Parents and volunteers involved in the program are also invited to help out with the coaching of these programs and to get involved in a volunteer capacity. Schools will be encouraged to participate in interschool cricket activities and to have their children and the parents of those children involved.

One of the schools in my electorate that I am very proud to represent in this parliament is the Darra State School. They have fully immersed themselves in the program, in conjunction with the Centenary Cricket Club. This Have-A-Go program is very strongly supported by the Darra state primary school and the Centenary Cricket Club. I have no doubts that the students involved in this program will benefit tremendously from the merits of the project. The program will involve the development of cricket skills for children, physical fitness, knowledge of the game of cricket and social skills that promote certain acceptable standards of behaviour in our community. It will also facilitate positive relationships with each other and foster good attitudes and values that everyone in this parliament would certainly embrace and aspire to lead on.

I want to take this opportunity in the parliament to congratulate the people involved, including the Queensland Cricket Association's Mr Nev Paulsen, who has the role of developing and coordinating Queensland Cricket's sponsorship of this. I also congratulate very strongly Darra State School, which, as I said, is in my electorate of Ryan. The school is very warmly and generously getting behind it. I very strongly commend the principal of the school, Ms Judith Bennett, for embracing the program and supporting it wholeheartedly by lending the school's facilities to support its students in the program. In fact, recently I had the pleasure of visiting the school to present the school captains and school councillors with their badges. I want to mention their names, because they are young Australians who are already taking leadership roles in our community. Jessica Le and Hao Du are the two young school captains. The school councillors are Jessica James, Julianne Ngyen, Tanya Ord, Lan Phung, Nghi Do and David Tran. They are outstanding young Australians at the Darra state primary school.

It is very appropriate that community-minded Australians are acknowledged in this parliament so, to that effect, I acknowledge the President of the Centenary Cricket Club, Ellen Ferris, in the suburb of Jamboree Heights—which is, of course, in Ryan—and Mr Ray Lindsay, who is the Vice President of the Centenary Cricket Club, for putting their precious time into this program. The Centenary Cricket Club has about 150 young cricketers. It has been going for some 17 years. This is all about our civil society and what is good about our country. It is very important that I also acknowledge the volunteers who are involved in the program, and I pay particular attention to Nev Paulsen, Ray Lindsay and Ellen Ferris, because they are the big drivers of this program. It is important to acknowledge, in light of Australia being the one-day world champions, that cricket is a game that brings people together, and I know all members of this parliament will be strongly promoting the idea of cricket as a community volunteer sport. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We were fortunate in the parliament to welcome last night and this morning the former Prime Minister of Israel, Mr Ehud Barak. It was a most apposite time to have him here. His vision and optimism inspired the members and ministers who met him. It was a great tribute to him that both the Leader of the Opposition and the foreign minister were at the dinner. The nonpartisan support that he received from all sides and from many members is a reflection of the great solidarity between our two countries over many years, and particularly of the support of both sides of politics for his vision of a Middle East peace that would have peacefully put in place 2½ years ago what Australia voted for at the United Nations nearly 50 years ago—that is, a Palestinian state living peacefully alongside an Israeli state. What a shame that offer was not taken up by Arafat. I think many members, having seen Mr Barak in action, will be particularly aware of his positive offer.

speech.para: While I am addressing matters of the Middle East, I want to focus attention on a recent statement issued by four prominent Labor identities—Michael Costello, Michael Easson, Bob Hogg and Jim Nolan. The statement examines Labor's examination in Iraq after this conflict is over. The statement presents some ideas and says that we should insist on a peacekeeping commitment afterwards in which the United Nations is involved. The quartet suggests that Australia might have a role, given its positive experiences in Cyprus, Cambodia and East Timor. Their statement adds:

quote.para: Progressive secular democratic elements in the Iraqi opposition can be assisted—

speech.para: by the Australian Labor Party. The paper from these four prominent Labor identities continues to say:

quote.para: Labor can promote the cause of reconstruction and democracy with conviction. The threat—tentatively made by France—that the Iraqi people might now become the victims of international ostracism because of the coalition's intervention should be strongly resisted.

Prime Minister Blair has been insistent that this intervention in Iraq cannot be viewed in isolation. It must mark a step—undeniably important in itself—but a step on the way to an enduring Middle East settlement.

speech.para: The quartet's world view ties in with the Barak visit. Mr Barak made the point that perhaps one of the positive things to emerge from the dreadful conflict that has opened with Iraq is a window of opportunity for a peace settlement between the Palestinians and the Israelis. He said that Bush, Blair and various other people were moving towards achieving new negotiations, and that there were widely supported moves within his country and amongst the Palestinians—with the elevation, finally, of a moderate Prime Minister, Abu Mazen—that showed that there may be some progress to achieve that.

We should look forward to a happier future not only for the people of Israel and Palestine but also for our friends the Kurdish people. I note with regret that, despite the fact that we seem to be fighting a war partially to liberate—as it is called—the Kurdish people of northern Iraq, they are under threat from intervention by Turkey. Moreover, the Howard government has also been badly advised in that it has failed to have Australian diplomats meet the two Kurdish democratic republics that exist in the north of Iraq. This is apparently some absurd view in the department of foreign affairs that the Kurdish people do not deserve self-determination as the Palestinian people do. I think the dichotomy between the two peoples is something that would only be understood by Arabists in the department of foreign affairs.

Iraq democratic opposition has a plan for a postwar federal Iraq under which there would be Kurdish cultural autonomy within a unified Iraq. That is something the Australian government should certainly consider. It should also consider Prime Minister Blair's proposal to put Iraqi assets and oil revenue into a UN escrow account so that people understand that the war is not being fought for commercial reasons. Those moneys should be spent on the reconstruction of Iraq for the benefit of the Iraqi people.

As Senator Robert Ray said, in anther place yesterday, it is interesting that Michael Costello is now being lionised by the federal government because he made some statements that were used by the government recently. They seek to lionise him now, though they tried to sack him in 1996. His statement, made with Easson, Hogg and Nolan, insists that genocide is no longer okay within the boundaries of a state. We should have an ethical dimension to foreign policy. They also say that in international affairs, as everywhere else, the principles of humanitarianism and practical social justice are a light to the world and should inform our foreign policy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Every so often a young person comes to you looking for assistance, and you know in your heart that you want to do all you can to support them. Recently I was approached by such a young man looking for someone to help him go to London for the International Youth Science Forum. Joshua Binks is a student at Bomaderry High School and has a passion for science. Joshua was chosen by the Rotary Club as one of 276 students from around Australia to attend the National Youth Science Forum early in January this year. He also is shortlisted to join the staff of the National Youth Science Forum in January next year.

speech.para: Joshua has been given the opportunity of attending, in July of this year, the London International Youth Science Forum. As a member of a six-person Australian contingent, he will have the opportunity to gather together with 250 young people from at least 60 countries around the world and discuss the issues of science that will affect the world around us. For two weeks they will live together as an international community and exchange their ideas and experiences of the world, fulfilling the aim of the science forum, which is `to give greater insight into science and its application for the benefit of all mankind'.

The event that really opened Joshua's eyes to this technology world was the Australian Tournament of the Minds competition. It was in the maths engineering section of this contest that he first became fascinated by the physical problems and limitations that engineers are faced with day to day. The strength of the Bomaderry High team and his own enjoyment of the experience resulted in two state titles and a national title. During the same year, he was able to attend the Sydney University Young Engineering Summer School, an opportunity for year 10 students throughout Australia to focus their goals and experience on the opportunities available to them in the real world.

On the basis of his application, Joshua was not only accepted to the school but also awarded the Clough Engineering Scholarship. Joshua was selected for this forum as a result of his participation in the National Youth Science Forum in Canberra during January this year. To be accepted into this forum, Joshua was required to submit a letter detailing his achievements in the area of science and engineering both in and out of school. After passing through this preliminary stage, which was judged by the Bomaderry Rotary Club, he attended an interview in Canberra. At this interview he was examined not only on his science knowledge but also on his public speaking skills and teamwork. Joshua's success at this interview was displayed through his selection to attend the forum.

At the national forum Joshua was able to learn from the knowledge of world-renowned scientists, such as Robin Batterham, as well as be challenged by the views of his peers from all over Australia. It was at the national forum that Joshua was selected to attend the London International Youth Science Forum, based at the University of London. It was his interest in all the areas of science and his outgoing nature that contributed to his selection. During the two weeks in London, the students will be participating in a number of forum discussions, attending lectures and experiencing the educational and sightseeing opportunities that England has to offer. This experience is as much an opportunity for him to learn as it is for him to teach the world how magnificent Australia is. During the forum, Joshua will have the opportunity to give a presentation to the rest of the group, and it is through this avenue that he will have the chance to show off the advantages of being involved in the lucky country and its future.

The total cost of attending the forum will come to $7,500, and he has been given the task of raising $5,000. He is currently in year 12, studying for the HSC. His time for fundraising is quite limited. According to the head science teacher at Bomaderry High School, Josh, as he is called, has a rare talent for science and a high level of social skills to match. This is an increasingly rare commodity in today's youth, with the sciences trailing in the education stakes in higher education. A talent such as this cannot be allowed to go unsupported. It is my hope that the financial support Joshua seeks will be forthcoming. We cannot expect to excel on the cheap, although we have a history of doing exactly that. Now is one opportunity to put it right, and I hope that other members of the House will lend their support. I also call on the community of the Shoalhaven to support their own and to reach into their pockets to give our youth a go. This is a small investment for the future, and if the generosity of support is multiplied then we will all be the richer for it. I commend Joshua Binks's quest and invite business leaders in the Shoalhaven to support him.

talk.start.para: —Today I rise to discuss an issue of significant importance to people in my region, particularly those experiencing mental illness and the families and carers of those experiencing mental illness. I would like to address an issue that has been raised with me by some fine non-government organisations in my area—Eastern Region Mental Health, a mental health advocacy group called Midway and, in particular, the Mental Health Council of Australia. Each of these organisations made submissions to my office about the impact of the recent changes by the government to the Family and Community Services Legislation Reform Bill. Whether or not the government has actually thought about the impact on people who are the least able to protect themselves and are the most disadvantaged among the community is interesting.

speech.para: I want to touch on the particular provision that impacts on those with a psychiatric disability in the area. We are talking about potentially one in five Australians. This relates to the applicants for the disability support pension, who must satisfy a continuing inability to work test, where the applicant must be unable to work for at least 30 hours a week at award wages due to a disability, illness or injury which attracts an impairment rating of at least 20 points on impairment tables.

The Howard government has amended the requirement from 30 hours a week over a two-year period at award wages to 15 hours per week over a two-year period. This change has had a significant impact on people with mental illness, which is one in five Australians at any one time. The psychiatric and psychological disability service pension recipients account for the second largest recipient group of this disability support pension. About 25 per cent of people who receive disability support pensions do so because of the long-term disabling consequences of an enduring mental illness. The amendments to this family and community service legislation will disadvantage a group which is already one of the most disadvantaged in society.

What it did not take into account, when these amendments were put forward, is the episodic nature of mental illness. The amendments that were mooted did not take into account that mental illnesses like bipolar disorder, anxiety disorder and schizophrenia are episodic in nature. So, when you come to assess whether these people can work 30 hours a week or 15—it has been reduced to 15 hours a week—someone who is experiencing schizophrenia and who is on medication may well be assessed as being able to actually work. But in many cases, particularly with people who are experiencing schizophrenia, these people may be able to work for a period of time but, because they experience a series of stresses et cetera or they come off their medication, they are unable to work.

According to this proposal, the changes that have been put forward by the government will mean that a number of people with schizophrenia—which is one of the most disabling illnesses in the community—will be put on to the Newstart allowance. So when these people have been working for a period of time and then they do not turn up to work or they do not fulfil their Newstart job search requirements, they will be in breach of their Newstart allowance. What that means is that someone who is experiencing a severe schizophrenic episode as a consequence of coming off their medication will come off their Newstart allowance and be in effect homeless. In an area like Dandenong, which has a very large number of people of non-English-speaking background, there are people who have suffered a lot of trauma and tension, particularly those from war torn countries—we have the highest uptake of refugees in Victoria. A lot of these people are suffering things like post-traumatic stress et cetera and are not actually getting appropriate diagnosis, treatment and care. These people are being put on a Newstart allowance when they should in fact be on a disability support pension.

There are long-term costs for the community. As a consequence of people with mental illnesses being put on Newstart allowance, they will not be able to fulfil their requirements, they will be breached and they will be wandering the streets without some level of income. In Dandenong we have had a big problem with heroin usage in our streets and there are fairly ruthless, callous drug dealers who are employing people who have psychiatric illnesses, as a consequence of them not having income. In many cases these people are out on the streets selling drugs instead of getting treatment, and over the past number of years a number of them—particularly in our region—have been killed. These are the most disadvantaged people in the community and they should have support provided to them to ensure that they can lead normal, ordered lives. But as a consequence of these changes that have been approved by the government, I am afraid that people with mental illnesses who will be put on to a Newstart allowance—where they will not be able to fulfil their requirements—are going to be put on the streets penniless. Frankly, for any government to put something like that forward with such a consequence is just an absolute disgrace.

talk.start.para: —A few weeks ago a local doctor's practice in Woody Point closed down unexpectedly due to industrial action. Three of the doctors had had a dispute with the principal doctor. My office learned of it the morning it occurred. It was a pretty horrendous experience for all of the elderly residents who live in the Woody Point area. The first thing my office did was get into action, and we contacted local general practices in the area to make sure that they would take anyone who needed to see a doctor urgently, a prescription filled or a test done et cetera. It really highlighted to me the importance of that particular medical surgery and the impact that it had in the general community. There were a number of practices that took on the overload, and the patients were very grateful for that.

speech.para: But then another problem arose, which was the accessing of some 5,000 medical records. I have learned a lot about medical records since then. It seems that they are the intellectual property of the doctor concerned. The doctor at the particular surgery would not release those medical records unless a fee of $20 was paid for each medical record. That does not seem like a lot of money at first until you look at the cost for a family of four. Having to pay $20 for each record is a huge amount. Even though I have analysed the cost of photocopying, the cost of clerical time required to photocopy those records and the cost of postage, I still think it is a huge amount. There is no other way that we can get those records to those patients. We are talking about, fundamentally, some 5,000 records. I know that that is a huge impost on the one doctor remaining. The other three doctors have decided to open up a practice, and I suppose by this stage they would have that practice operating around the corner in Clontarf.

Medical issues are very prominent in the electorate of Petrie. I see the member for Dickson has just joined me. He and I have many similarities in our electorates, particularly outer metropolitan issues regarding general practitioners. These issues have not occurred overnight; they have been occurring over a large period of time because of the suburbs moving further and further out from the main metropolitan area and because of people moving further north and away from the metropolitan area to retire. My electorate has a wonderful peninsula, and there is something about people wanting to retire later in life near the water. The member for Dickson has many beautiful rural areas in his electorate.

This has caused a problem in terms of demand for medical services. I lobbied very hard before the last election to ensure that we had a separate policy for outer metropolitan seats. The rural medical issues have to an extent—I will not say `totally'—been addressed by this government by getting more doctors into rural areas. But outer metropolitan areas now really need some fast attention. At the last election, $80 million was promised to ensure that doctors go to outer metropolitan areas. You might think that is a pretty simple thing but in fact it has been very difficult. Doctors are very reluctant to move out of city areas, and bulk-billing rates are very high in inner city areas because of competition. Doctors do not want to move out. Also, more and more females are graduating from medicine and they are more reluctant to move to outer metropolitan areas as well. They are also working sessional times.

But I will continue to lobby the health minister and the Prime Minister. I think it is a great issue that we really do need to address. I will be working to ensure that bulk-billing rates are maintained for low-income earners, including pensioners and those on a health care card. We really must ensure that more doctors are attracted to those outer areas. I commend the minister for an initiative the other day in providing a $30,000 payment for GPs if they set up a practice in an outer metropolitan area. More work needs to be done, and I will continue working to ensure that we do have more doctors going into this area. Whether we address this through current training of doctors or whether we address this with overseas trained doctors, I will be pushing to ensure that those outer metropolitan areas do have the medical services that they indeed require, a requirement that is increasing all the time.

talk.start.para: —War is always ugly: lives are lost; families are destroyed. Labor is proud to say it is against war, not because the majority of the people of Iraq want to be liberated, not because of the past history of the Saddam regime—the documented horrors that the Saddam regime has committed on its own people and its neighbours—and not because of the slow devastation of over 25 years of Saddam rule over the peoples of Iraq and 12 years of sanctions on the people of Iraq. Labor is against war not for any of these good reasons but because it is not supported by the United Nations and because it is so strongly opposed by many important nations. On that basis, it is wrong—wrong because the process of the weapons inspections was not yet completed, along with the implementation of the final report from Hans Blix. It is a shame that the military timetable did not allow the extra weeks that would have allowed, I believe, the United Nations Security Council to come to a united position on this issue.

speech.para: This of course does not mean that the ALP or the international community do not believe that Saddam Hussein should not be disarmed. He should be disarmed; there is no doubt about that. People should be very clear. It just means, as we heard yesterday from former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak, that we need both moral authority and unity. That has not yet been achieved. By the end of this war I hope and I believe that that moral authority and that unity can be achieved. No matter the reasons of self-interest and national interest for opposition to the war by a number of countries, their concerns and their opposition must be at least recognised and acknowledged.

But now that this war has begun it poses us a very different set of circumstances. The diplomacy may be over at the United Nations Security Council for action on the war but it is diplomacy that is more important than ever now that the war has begun. Australia can play a leading role here and punch well above its weight and stature, as it often does. The reality for all Australians is that we are at war and under these circumstances our efforts should be for a quick and speedy resolution to this conflict. No-one disagrees with that. No-one can disagree with a wish for the safe return of our troops, a lasting peace for the people of Iraq and hopefully a new peace process for the entire Middle East. With our troops now squarely in the front-line battle and in the face of danger, all Australians must unite behind our soldiers. We must decide that they are not there as decision makers but there as loyal Australians who are on our behalf taking up a challenge that has been presented to them by the government to defend our way of life. On that there is no debate or argument.

Labor are fully committed to supporting our troops and their families. We are striving to ensure that their efforts are not caught in the cross-fire of any political debates over the rights or wrongs of the war. In fact, Labor have pursued the government on a number of matters that will directly affect our troops on their return, their wellbeing and that of their families also. Labor want to ensure that veterans are not left isolated or without compensation and full benefits on their return. Too many times in the past this has not been the case and it is imperative that this does not happen in this case. We must learn from the past in relation to our veterans' health.

There has been a strong push from many to bring our troops home and bring them home now. Labor in particular have been very vocal on this matter. We believe that our troops should not have been pre-deployed in what we believed was a charade. We believe that there should have been no commitment to war or any involvement of our troops. We all know that once our ADF personnel had actually departed they were obviously fully committed to war, as we now witness.

But we must also be realistic, and Labor are not in government. The Howard government will not bring them home nor will the PM in a real sense be honest about the circumstances by which they were first deployed. I think we have to be realistic in support of our troops being there now, regardless of how they got there. Regardless of that, we have to support them now. In that vein we must all unite to support our troops. We must show them that we understand that they are doing a good job, that they are the best trained and most professional force in the world and, importantly, that they have no say in their own deployment. We must show that they have the full support of the Australian community, including all of its political parties.

We may or may not agree on a number of issues at the sides in terms of duration or how these things might take place. That will be borne out fully in the public debate that will ensue. On this matter only the PM has a deciding vote. In our contribution, again in a robust democracy like ours, we have to accept that. Right or wrong we all pray for a short war with minimal casualties on all sides, particularly civilian casualities, and we pray for the safe and speedy return of our troops. Labor are against war but that is a simplistic statement. We support our troops, we believe in our democracy and we believe there should be a lasting peace. The peace is the war to be won in Iraq, not just the war itself. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want today to take the opportunity once again to express some of the views and concerns that have been put to me by residents of my electorate of Dickson. It is not too often that we get the opportunity to speak in this place to make the House aware of some of the problems that people are facing. But I like to do that as regularly as I can. Today I want to raise an issue because I have had a number of people contact my office this morning in relation to the disgraceful efforts of some radical students in Sydney yesterday. In this country we stand proud of our record on free speech and on democracy—indeed, they are the hallmarks of the great country that we live in—but the disgraceful episodes yesterday that were undertaken by a small radical element in Sydney should be condemned. Those people, rightly, were arrested yesterday, and should be going to jail for their efforts. In this country we support the right to free speech. I dare say that many of those people involved in much of that action had no idea what they were actually doing there. It was an expression of anarchy, and they should be condemned in the strongest possible terms.

speech.para: I want to acknowledge the people who have contacted my office today—and there have been quite a number—to express their disgust at the manner in which those people conducted themselves yesterday. On Monday of this week, three protesters came to my office and staged a sit-in. They were demanding a regime change in Dickson. As I say, they numbered three and they put signs up out the front. I dare say that they could even be members of the local Labor Party; I am not sure. They demanded democracy and a regime change in Dickson. They conducted themselves in a peaceful manner, and for that I thank them. I want to pay tribute to my very patient staff, who provided them with every cordial response and tolerated and facilitated them being there and interrupting the work that my staff were doing during the day.

We know that there is resentment about the decision the government has made. Many people in recent weeks have further understood that we took a very difficult decision in the medium- and long-term national interests of Australia. That is why we took the decision in relation to Iraq. I think more people are now starting to realise that, having seen the horrendous atrocities that have been uncovered in recent days that have been committed and are being committed against the Iraqi people by the Saddam Hussein regime. I thank the people in my electorate who have contacted me both in support of and against the government—and, as we say, those people against the government can protest and speak their minds freely. I welcome them at any time.

The other issue that is raised with me on a regular basis is the issue of health. I have spoken in this place before about the shortage of doctors in outer metropolitan areas. Certainly, that issue is of grave concern in the electorates of Dickson and Petrie. We heard from the member for Petrie before. It is an issue that I have raised on a number of occasions with both the Prime Minister and the health minister. I am pleased that the health minister announced last Sunday the financial support and encouragement for doctors to come out from inner metropolitan areas, where there is a decent supply of doctors. They will pay doctors up to $30,000 to come to outer metropolitan areas. It will make some people in the community angry that we need to offer that financial incentive to doctors to come out, because many people in the community think doctors are well paid and should not need a financial incentive to come out. By the same token, those people also have an appreciation of the long hours and the difficult and good work that doctors do for our community.

So I am hoping that this is one of the measures that will attract more doctors to regions like Dickson, because the main reason why we are seeing a fall in the bulk-billing rate is the lack of doctors—and, as doctors will tell you, because they believe that they should be getting more from the Medicare rebate. It is an issue that is raised with me on a regular basis. I acknowledge those doctors, small business people and others who have approached me on the issue. I assure them that I continue to work hard on the issue. I hope that over the coming weeks and as we go into the budget process in May the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the health minister will have more announcements and initiatives by this government in relation to health services in outer metropolitan areas. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to speak briefly about the plight of people still being held in detention in Australia. At my request, the member for Calwell tabled an unusual request targeting all elected representatives of the Australian people to act immediately to authorise the end to administrative detention, to grant permanent residence to all refugees currently on temporary protection visas who have been law-abiding and to authorise the immediate release into the community of all asylum seekers who are not a health or security concern. This act of grace petition, as it was called, has obviously been timed to be placed in the parliament before Easter in the hope that, when spiritual leaders in a nominally Christian nation consider their consciences and their place before God, they think about these acts of love and compassion that so many members of their community are calling on them to undertake.

speech.para: It is important that we do not lose sight of the plight of asylum seekers, refugees and others being held in detention. I can reach no other conclusion, having had this material put before me now week after week, that this is a form of institutionalised sadism and psychological torture. It represents, in my view, a serious crime against humanity. With the current war in Iraq we should consider the plight of the Iraqis, in particular. There are 152 of them locked up in camps right at this moment and 4,000 of them on temporary protection visas. I had a visit this morning from an Iraqi gentleman who is a refugee on a temporary protection visa. He has joined an organisation trying to pressure the government to leave them alone and to leave them here. He says, `We'—the Iraqi temporary protection visa holders—`have suffered greatly under the TPV regime. Three years of living with the uncertainty and insecurity of temporary protection has resulted in ongoing trauma and suffering for many of us.' He talks about media stereotypes, and the xenophobia and intolerance directed toward them. They believe they have been unfairly punished and discriminated against. That is a view that is widely shared amongst people in that community. We need to have a look at what we are doing to them.

In reply to a question from Bob Brown on notice, the responsible minister said that there was a certain amount of mental illness in our camps and that it was at such and such a level, but he included in his reply the observation: `Mental illness in this instance does not include depression.' I bet it does not—since it is rife in the detention camps. There are a lot of people, inside and outside the camps, who are suffering severe depression.

I draw members' attention to the work of Dutch psychiatrist Maarten Dormer, one of the few people who have actually been on Nauru, which is the most horrific of all these gulags. He is a trained psychiatrist who has worked in the detention system in Holland. He said that you quickly conclude that you are `participating in a system that only makes people sicker'. He talks about the fact that people become listless and fall into lethargy. In his view, 20 to 30 per cent of these people are suffering from severe depression. He concludes that this is `the heart of darkness'. He could not believe the regime he had stumbled on. He complained to the International Organisation for Migration, which is in control of these camps. These are things that Australian citizens should know, but do not. This is institutionalised sadism.

Recently in Nauru there has been a dengue fever outbreak, which the government did not notify anyone about. It was only when I contacted the minister that he was prepared to even acknowledge there was a risk. Dengue fever is not necessarily life threatening the first time round, but the second time round up to 30 per cent of those infected can die as a result of shock and complications.

People are being held in detention well outside their refugee status having been granted. Just this week, Iraj Navussary in Woomera attempted suicide because he has not yet been released, although he has been shown to have genuine refugee claims. Recently I had drawn to my attention—and I acted as best I could to draw it to the community's attention—the death of Fatima Erfani, from the centre at Christmas Island. She died in hospital in Perth from a brain haemorrhage as a result, in my view, of inadequate care. Now her husband has been sent back to Afghanistan—which we know is under pressure again—with his three children and Fatima's body, which was left unattended for several hours while the IOM staff scrambled around trying to provide appropriate support.

This is appalling at a time when we know that the number of refugees is increasing. It might suit members opposite to be ignorant and to ignore the cases that appear in my email box daily. When I investigate them I find them to be substantiated; they are not exaggerated. This is a form of institutionalised sadism. It is psychological torture of the people in those institutions. An act of grace is the very least we can expect of this government.

talk.start.para: (Mr Wilkie)—Before calling the honourable member for Flinders, could I also pass on my best wishes for Saturday, as did Deputy Speaker Lindsay yesterday.

subdebateinfo.title: Flinders Electorate: Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service

talk.start.para: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I rise to speak in support of the Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service on three fronts: firstly, to congratulate the magnificent staff, administration and board of management; secondly, to highlight a significant funding threat which is posing a great challenge to the staff of the health service which runs the hospital; and, thirdly, to highlight a strategic direction which I believe we should be taking.

speech.para: In relation to the first of these points, the staff of the Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service, which has two principal responsibilities—managing the hospital function and managing the aged care facilities—is a magnificent body of people. It is a group of dedicated staff, of extraordinary capability with great commitment, great compassion and a great passion for the work that they undertake. They are backed up through Terrona Ramsay, the CEO of the Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service, with a tremendous administration and a board which is run and managed by the chairperson of that board, Garry King. To all of those members of this community facility, I offer my thanks and congratulations.

The second point I wish to make is that they are operating under a severe constraint. During a recent transitional program conducted by the state government, they found that they lost a series of their capital resources, which were transferred from their own capital account to other hospitals within the state government system. As a result of that, despite the magnificent work of the staff and the administration, they are suffering pressure on four fronts. Firstly, they have a capital deficiency which has resulted from the write-off provisions which have already occurred under the state government. Secondly, because they will be restricted in the range of activities that they are able to carry out, they will be suffering an operating loss, which would not have occurred but for the changes in the range of activities which they are able to offer. Thirdly, they will be suffering a balance sheet deficiency, again as a result of the change in the administrative arrangements. Fourthly, this will lead to an overdraft that they would not otherwise have had to have experienced.

How can we deal with this problem? I call upon the state government of Victoria to work with the board, the staff and the management of the Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service to produce a strategic direction, in a spirit of bipartisanship, and with cooperation between community, state and federal authorities. I would be delighted to participate and assist in helping with the development of the strategic direction for the Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service. There are, I believe, four elements which are essential to the satisfactory completion of the strategic direction and, above all else, to ensuring that this community has a long-term and viable health service.

Firstly, the state government needs to make a clear and distinctive decision as to whether or not Koo Wee Rup will be incorporated within the metropolitan health strategy. That is a necessary prerequisite for all the other elements which are to be pursued. Secondly, we need to convert the WEIS funding stream to a Healthstreams model. That means that they would be given a single dollar amount and the Koo Wee Rup health service itself would then have flexibility within its own budget to control its priorities, its expenditures and its self-administration. Thirdly, an urgent upgrade to the theatre facilities is needed. The Koo Wee Rup hospital is famous within Victoria for the quality of the surgery carried out within the facilities of the hospital. One of the barriers to even more work is the need for an urgent theatre upgrade. The hospital staff are desperate to make sure that they are in full compliance with Australian standards, and only an upgrade in the facilities will allow them to do that.

Fourthly and finally, we need to encourage the state government to put forward the aged care facility at the Koo Wee Rup Regional Health Service for future funding under the federal aged care program. I would be delighted to do that, but we can only do that if it is endorsed by the state government. I commend the health service and urge the state government to produce a strategic review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 4 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of studies showing high levels of salinity in urban areas of Australia, in particular the Sydney Basin.
(2) Has the Government conducted any studies to assess the impact of increasing salinity on infrastructure in urban environments in Australia.
(3) What funding does the Government allocate to address salinity problems in Australia.
(4) What proportion of funding to address salinity problems is allocated to salinity problems in urban areas.
(5) What steps is the Government taking to address salinity problems in urban areas of Australia.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am advised that there have been a number of studies showing high levels of salinity in urban areas of Australia.

The New South Wales Salinity Strategy recognises that urban salinity is an issue facing parts of Western Sydney, and references a New South Wales Department of Land and Water Conservation study of Salinity in the South Creek Catchment.

(2) The Government contributed $34 million from the Natural Heritage Trust (the Trust) to undertake the National Land and Water Resources Audit. The audit included a salinity assessment, the Australian Dryland Salinity Assessment 2000, which had a comprehensive coverage of salinity issues, including its impacts on urban environments.

The Government has also funded a number of projects under the Trust that have urban salinity as a focus. For example, funding was provided under the National Landcare Program for a project on Management of Salinity in Western Sydney to develop a code of practice to assist local government in education and decision-making in relation to urban salinity.

(3) All states and territories have signed the Intergovernmental Agreement on the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality (National Action Plan), which has committed them to collectively match in new and additional cash the $700 million Commonwealth allocation for the National Action Plan. All states except WA have signed bilateral agreements with the Commonwealth, detailing joint commitments under the National Action Plan. The $1.4 billion National Action Plan was developed to address the critical issues of salinity and water quality, and is additional to the significant Commonwealth funding allocation for the Natural Heritage Trust Extension. National Action Plan funding is supporting the actions of communities and land managers in 21 priority regions across Australia. Funding is being provided to designated regional bodies to prepare integrated regional natural resource management (NRM) plans which are to address the whole suite of NRM issues facing the region, including salinity and water quality issues.

Funding is also being provided to undertake time critical on-ground actions prior to the accreditation of these regional plans in jurisdictions where a bilateral agreement is in place. Once the regional NRM plan is accredited, the Government, in partnership with the relevant state or territory, will invest in actions identified in these plans that contribute to addressing salinity and water quality issues.

(4) There are no area-specific allocations predetermined under the National Action Plan, including for urban salinity. Investment levels for clear and targeted actions are determined on the basis of accredited regional plans underpinned by scientific assessment.

(5) In the event that an action to address urban salinity is identified as a priority in an accredited integrated regional natural resource management plan for a National Action Plan priority region, it would be considered for funding along with other priorities put forward by the relevant regional body. Funding under the Natural Heritage Trust would also be available for regions outside of National Action Plan priority regions to undertake actions to address urban salinity.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 13 February 2003:

quote.para: (1) With respect to his decision to exercise his powers under section 33(2)(b)(ii) of the Migration Act to establish a new type of Special Purpose Visa category for crews on vessels operating under single and continuous voyage permits, how does the introduction of this new category of visa ensure that coastal trading is not opened up in such a way as to remove opportunities for Australian workers.

(2) Can a crew member be issued with subsequent special visas after the expiry of the first; if so, (a) what is the minimum gap, if any, between the two permits and (b) are there any requirements on re-issue, such as a requirement to leave Australian waters; if not, why not.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The new instrument specifies that a person is taken to hold a Special Purpose Visa (SPV) where they are a non-citizen crew member of a commercial vessel operating in coastal trading under a Single Voyage Permit (SVP) or Continuing Voyage Permit (CVP) granted by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.
The instrument specifies that an SPV will only be taken to be held where the SVP or CVP was granted in the following circumstances:
· the vessel is an international vessel engaged in a pattern of business that takes it outside Australia on a regular basis; and
· no suitable Australian vessel is available for the purpose for which the permit is sought.

The instrument further specifies that an SPV may only be taken to be held by the person where the SVP or CVP was granted for a period of up to three months duration. At the end of the three-month period, the ship and crew are required to leave Australian waters to a place outside Australia. This three-month limit was not specified in migration legislation prior to the introduction of the new instrument.

(2) The new instrument specifies that a person can only be taken to hold an SPV where they are a non-citizen crew member of a commercial vessel operating in coastal trading under a Single Voyage Permit (SVP) or Continuing Voyage Permit (CVP) that was granted for a period of up to three months. If an SVP or CVP has been issued for a period of more than three months, the person cannot be taken to hold an SPV.

A crew member who has previously been in Australia on an SPV will be taken to hold a further SPV provided that the vessel on which they are working has been issued a further permit that meets the requirements set out in the instrument.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 March 2003:

quote.para: On the most recent data, what is the incidence of reported crime by type in (a) Tasmania and (b) the postcode areas of (i) 7248, (ii) 7249, (iii) 7250, (iv) 7252,

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (a) I am advised that according to the most recent data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the number of victims by offence category, for offences recorded by Police, in Tasmania for 2001 was as follows:
Homicide and related offences - 22 victims. These can be broken down as follows:
(i) Murder - 8.
(ii) Attempted Murder -12 .
(iii) Manslaughter - 2.
(iv) Driving causing death - 0.
Assault - 3,475 victims.
Sexual assault - 200 victims.
Kidnapping/abduction - 11 victims.
Robbery - 190 victims. This can be broken down as follows:
(i) Armed robbery - 83.
(ii) Unarmed robbery - 107.
Blackmail/extortion - 1 victim.
Unlawful Entry with Intent - 9,253 victims. These can be broken down as follows:
(i) Property Theft - 7,333.
(ii) Other - 1,920.
Motor vehicle theft - 3,459 victims.
Other theft - 13,331 victims.
Source: Australian Bureau of Statistics, Recorded Crime: Australia 2001.

(b) I am advised that the Australian Bureau of Statistics does not produce data on the incidence of recorded crime by local area in Tasmania, including by postcode. However, I am advised that such information may be available from the Tasmanian Police.
